description:
I took my friend, who was visiting for the weekend to dinner at Max's. She ordered a Bombay gin martini with extra vermouth and I got my usual "slightly dirty" vodka martini.

Her martini was really off. She didn't like it and I took a taste and it was not Bombay gin and vermouth. She told the server and ordered a wine instead.

Both of our dinner salads were great and the server was attentive.

As I was about halfway through my martini, I nearly slit my lip open on what turned out to be a gouged out rim that I hadn't noticed when she brought the drink. I pointed it out to her. There was no apology or offer of a replacement drink, or even an unbroken glass.

When the bill was brought, it included both my friend's martini and her wine and my martini as well.

We had to say something to her and she went back to her manager and then took the two martinis off the bill.

1) I believe the manager should have come over to our table and 2) we should not have had to speak to the server.

I can't really blame her if she hadn't received proper training from the management on how to handle customers who encounter a problems with their meals.
author: Stephen S.

description:
Amazing Customer Service!

I brought my girlfriend here recently before going to the San Francisco Symphony and it was definitely one of the best experiences I've had. Though the food wasn't the best I've ever had, all other qualities made up for it. 

I had made reservations for 6pm on Thursday but there was a good amount of tables available. We were sat right away and shortly greeted by out waiter. He was a friendly gentleman who wore glasses. We started off with a Calamari Appetizer which was REALLY good. For dinner I ordered the Paella which was a little lacking in flavor but I like how there was a bunch of clams that came with it. Lovers of this will probably appreciate the dish more. 

What I really liked is being sat near the piano though. In my reservation, I specifically asked for this because I feel it just set the mood for the event to come. That and I just love pianos! At one point our waiter took a minute from serving and started singing with the pianist. It was awesome!! Truly a treat. I really felt at home that night!!

All in all, Max's Opera Cafe continues to be a tradition of me and my girls when we go to SF Symphony. I'm already in a classic mood. I already gotta dress in a classy fashion. I might as well have a classy dinner, right? Max's always delivers consistent good food and service at affordable prices and is why I continue to come here.
author: Anthony W.

description:
Expensive and depressing. 
I paid $20 for a bland vegetarian omelette, paired with a dull salad and burned toast. I ate the omelette only because I was very hungry and left the rest untouched. 
Service? No greeting. No smile. No "how was your food". No music. Slow and inattentive. I commented about the toast and the salad and got "okay" in return.
author: Luba C.

description:
After attending a movie screening and still emotionally high, I wasn't ready to call it a night. remembered Max's was nearby. It's been many years since I'd been there and popped in for a snack. 

The store hadn't changed. In fact, the shine and glamour has gone down hill. I doubt if the decor has ever been upgraded. 

The food, however was still good. A Reuben sandwich with fries were worthy. Nice Pastrami half lean, half fat was delicious between sauerkraut, 1000 Island dressing and grilled rye bread. $18 was a fair price.
author: David N.

description:
It's one of my favorite places in the city!
Good food and excellent service! 
* Bistro Salad. It's my must order! And it is huge! Good for three people!
* Grandma Chicken. Actually it is called the honey roasted chicken. And the sauce is amazing! The carrots on side are somehow better taste than usual. Can't figure out how they made it.
* Crispy Fried Calamari. I didn't know there were slices of fried lemon until it came up. And it taste good! So as the Calamari! I took out the rest of the cocktail sauce back home 
* Stuffed Giant Mushrooms. Delicious. (Out of words)
author: Yantong Z.

description:
Even though it's been over 11 years since I reviewed this place, I have to admit Jamie W. and I have come back periodically in the intervening years, usually after a movie because it's the only familiar place in the area that stays open until 10PM. That isn't even that late, but you pretty much know what you're getting here no matter what you order. Before last year, it was unwisely the lure of gargantuan desserts like the New York Cheesecake or the Ultimate Chocolate Cake. Immediate gratification followed by years of regret. That sounds like the story of my life, but it could actually be Max's slogan if there was truth in advertising.

Anyway, we were coming out of the surreal disappointment that was "A Wrinkle in Time" at the AMC Van Ness and feeling a bit peckish. The place was emptying out at around 9PM on a Tuesday evening. No one was at the piano playing Sondheim, and consequently none of the waitstaff was warbling the intricately sophisticated lyrics. What has remained consistent over the years are the loud patrons at the bar, this time a legion of drunk Aussie tourists. At least we were able to snag a booth where we perused the dinner meal. Yep, no desserts for us. We wised up finally and shared the $8.99 Chopped Vegetable Salad.

It was a bite-size combination of broccoli, cauliflower, carrot, cherry tomatoes, romaine lettuce, spinach, and toasted croutons in a small mound with a balsamic vinaigrette on the side (photo: http://bit.ly/2ptaNFx). Artless but it hit the spot. For a chaser, we each ordered a $9 cup of Max's Famous Chicken Matzo Ball Soup, which is justly famous even though my first choice was the less caloric Russian Cabbage Soup. It was a hearty broth with carrot, celery, and generic egg noodles, dominated by one big matzo ball which readily picked up the flavor of the chicken stock (photo: http://bit.ly/2ppQxFM). So Jamie and I can survive in a post-dessert universe when patronizing Max's. Who da thunk it?

FOOD - 3 stars...no matter what you order, you know what you get
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...unapologetically stuck in the 1970's
SERVICE - 3 stars...no singing but they do their jobs
TOTAL - 3 stars...last of the late night dinosaurs
author: Ed U.

description: Updating my review to 4 stars! Consistently good food with decent portions and hospitable service. Underrated and deserving of praise for the wide variety of food and welcoming attitude of the management and staff here. They even make an effort to remember my name and accommodate my family every time we eat here. Spacious dining room and even when they are busy, the tables have ample room between them so we can enjoy our conversations. This place has been here forever and is famous for providing live music so be sure to ask in advance if you want to go on a night with entertainment.
author: Lucy L.

description: Good place for pre-show dining away from the hustle and bustle of the Hayes Valley foodie crawl.  Both dishes I ordered were excellent - Chicken Matzo Ball soup came out piping hot and very hearty!   Spanish Paella was gigantic with generous amount of seafood and enough rice to get you through a five-hour Wagner opera of the Ring Cycle (which is why I'm in town.)   I would come back!
author: Truman W.

description:
When I've been here on weekends at night, they've always had someone on the piano singing crooner music, which is something I rarely find in the city. The staff is so friendly and welcoming! Warning: the plates are HUGE. I learned that the hard way the first time (food coma!)

It might not be trendy or "instagram-worthy" like other hipster places in the city, but it sure is a place where I feel welcomed. I'd take that over a picture any day :)

Some menu items I've enjoyed:
- Jambalaya Fettucine
- FIsh Tacos
- Sliders
- Max's margarita
author: Lupita D.

description:
If you don't mind eating in a LOT of noise, this is a great place, convenient to any of the performances at the Opera House, Herbst Hall, or Davies Symphony hall.  It was a madhouse when we arrived on Saturday night (I highly recommend a reservation; we didn't have one), but we were only 2, so we did get a table right away, though by the time we left there was a huge line of people waiting for tables.  

I have incredible admiration for the waiters, who have to weave their way through masses of people, and go up and downstairs while carrying trays.  They do it, and are still efficient.

I love crab cakes and ordered their crab cake dinner, which came with cabbage, which looked limp and unappetizing, but was actually fabulous, with bacon, onions, and huge chunks of mushrooms. Almost better than the crab cakes.

But the crab cakes were wonderful, about  2" thick, full of crab (and no overpowering Old Bay, which I hate).  I don't usually use any sauce, but the remoulade was so good, I ate the cakes with that as well.

My husband had fetuccini with huge mushrooms stuffed with spinach and cheese and said it was delicious.

In previous visits, I have had hamburgers (one of their specialties, I think), and also lamb chops, which were not on the menu last night.

I really love this place.  This night was my 75th birthday and as soon as I sat down, the pianist played happy birthday -- of course it was for someone ELSE, but I pretended it was for me.

The only reason Igive it 4 out of 5 stars was because ofthe level of noise, which was ear-splitting (and I'm partially deaf!)
author: Beverly S.

description:
Three stars is generous.

This place used to be my favorite restaurant when I was a kid, so I'm trying to weigh my memory of what Max's used to be vs. what I experienced on my birthday last week.

I remember Max's being a semi-nice restaurant with friendly staff, huge portions, and good service. Only one of those things remains.

The hostess who greeted my girlfriend and I was not particularly warm, but we rolled with it. Our server was soft-spoken and pretty confused about a request for a spicy margarita, offering to make it spicy by putting in Absolute Pepper (or Peppar?), which is vodka, not tequila, and surely would've been awful. He offered to check with the bartender about how they could spice up a margarita without asking what our second choice would be if they couldn't come up with something, which was the end result.

Food was okay. Far from great, but nothing off-putting. The portions are still huge, which warmed my heart.

What's still bothering me today is what happened when we requested to-go boxes, which just about everyone at Max's does. A busser came by and set two plastic to-go boxes on the table with a plastic bag, and then just turned around and left! I was appalled. 

I worked in restaurants for 7 years, from diners to Michelin starred joints, and I never, EVER would've just set boxes on a table, expecting my guests to box the food themselves. 

Max's Opera Cafe, I'm certain, used to be a nice enough place where they would box the rest of your gigantically portioned meal for you. Otherwise, what the heck are we tipping on? You failed to execute a not-that-difficult cocktail request. Never once were we made to feel welcome or taken care of, and then I need to box my food up before I leave? Who's serving who? 

What's next, should I plate the food myself in the kitchen? Heck, maybe I should grab an apron and get to cookin' too. Unbelievable. Sadly, I'd be hesitant to go back.
author: Dan R.

description:
My mom's boss took the company (and family members) to eat an early lunch today after the symphony. The management and staff were so accommodating and the food was so good. They were quick to take the 40+ people's orders of drinks, appetizers, meals, and desserts. The food came out hot and well seasoned! I'm very impressed. I will definitely visit this place again.

My order:

Shirley temple (I don't drink alcohol lol)
Calamari
Chicken parmigiana 
Creme brûlée
author: Nikki G.

description:
** 3.5 stars**

This place was just slightly better than I expected.  We came in on Mother's Day for brunch before going to Hamilton.  I would say the restaurant was about 1/2 full.  We made an on-line reservation which was pretty easy.  Our waiter was attentive and regularly checked on us throughout the meal.   They had four different menus which is good if you are looking for variety, not so good if you are indecisive ;)    I ordered the Joe's special without spinach.  It was ground beef, mushroom, and onion scramble served with a biscuit and potatoes.  Overall the food was good, nothing to die for though.  Prices were reasonable for SF.  Parking is free on Sundays, so it was a good day to go!
author: Andrea B.

description: It was a delicious dinner with tasty drinks.  Great service with nice relaxing music.
author: Irma P.

description: Still one amazing place to eat after all these years. Pastrami on Rye forever and the Niagara Falls cake:)
author: Dan B.

description:
Nice place.
I actually finished my turkey Swiss sandwich.
The Crete brûlée was excellent (for sharing) especially when mixed with their fudgy brownie (also for sharing) :-)
author: Cay A.

description:
As much as I like the fact that Max's Opera Cafe is a San Francisco institution and thus hasn't succumbed to hipsterdom, I have to say that it really was only a so-so experience. 

We'd come here with a group of 7 adults and 4 kids. While service was initially a bit slow, our server seemed to have noticed our impatience and quickly got back into the swing of things. I especially appreciated that she had the kids' meal come out of the kitchen ahead of the adult meals.

Alas, where this place fell short for me was the food: I'd ordered the corned beef hash, which was advertised as one of their signature dishes...it was flavorless and I had to help myself to a good amount of ketchup to put some flavor into it. Similarly, my other half had ordered the Reuben and he wasn't singing praises about it either. 

I'm being generous here by giving this place three stars, because I want such a SF institution to keep being around...
author: Uli B.

description:
We arrived at Max's Opera Café without a reservation on Saturday evening, March 10th. The restaurant was full to the brim with patrons of Davies, the opera, the War Memorial Hall and the Bill Graham Auditorium.

Sanaz, their Maître D', was willing and able to graciously and professionally find a spot for us and we were able to get to the San Francisco Symphony on time.

We had the broiled Salmon and beet salad; both of which were outstanding.

We highly recommend Max's Opera Café. And especially, Sanaz, their Maître D'.

Best Regards,

Jim Bryant
author: Jim Bryant B.

description: I am surprisingly disappointed with Max's Opera Cafe. Every time I've eaten in the restaurant the food and service were great. Yesterday I had food delivered, and I was truly disappointed. I ordered a garden burger and fries. The burger was dry; no mayo, mustard, or any other condiments were sent with this order. The fries were old, as if they had been cooked earlier in the day in old grease, and they were cold and dry. I may go back to the restaurant and see how the food is again versus having it delivered. Maybe; maybe not.
author: Tyree R.

description: I'll just say I'm very pleased with the chicken matzo ball soup!! Noodles, chicken, veggies, matzo balls! Thank you for serving quality food!!
author: Joel G.

description:
had time before an eye doctors appointment and went in for lunch.  Should have gone in after the appointment so i would not have had to see what i was eating.

service was good.  not personal but efficient.  

Ordered the meatloaf.  comes with carrots and add ff.
meatloaf was basically ground beef, in little clumps, lots of salted gravy, and mushrooms.  over spiced.  the beef was not real tasty.  Basically one of those meals that after a couple of bites, you know you will not want to finish it.  
the carrots that came with it were actually harder then when they came out of the ground.  they probably would have tasted better when they came out of the ground.

FF was good.  

I would skip this place.  again, sad that i did not get to the doctors appointment first so i would not have to still see that plate.....
author: Tim F.

description: Yucky! Dirty floors, sticky tables, grundgy bathroom and sub-par food. My hot pastrami sandwich was served on stale rye bread with meat that was fatty and grizzly. I had good memories of the place from years ago so stopped in before a show. Won't be back - EVER!
author: John S.

description: I came here for lunch and the pastrami sandwich was dripping in grease. My co-worker had a tuna melt that was barely edible. I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone.
author: Lo J.

description:
Reservation honored. Seated fast. Waiter took order promptly. Had a good Anchor Steam beer and Reuben. Perhaps management should provide extra napkins.

Tasty, well-done. Will return.
author: Thus S.

description:
My family's go-to dessert place whenever we're around the area and this past Thursday night, they came through yet again! 

We were craving something not ice cream for dessert since it was freezing that night... thus we  got lucky with parking and came here. 

The staff was singing XMAS songs so that added to our chilled vibes... I ended up getting the chocolate and raspberry trifle (my first) and it was good... not too sweet and just right. The bro and sis.in.law shared their typical: niagara chocolate cake. 

I also managed to try Powers Irish Whiskey... which the bro and I became a fan of after. 

Good spot to chill and mellow out before or after any shows or just cause.
author: Cath M.

description:
We had a reservation here before a show and no problems having it honored as others have reported here. Maybe we were lucky?

The salads here are really good. Big and filling. You can pretend to be eating healthy because it's salad while filling up on walnuts and feta cheese.

It's not high-end food by any means, but certainly good enough for quick eats and we had none of the problems reported by others.
author: John R.

description: I love Max's - all of the food is excellent. While it is somewhat a Deli, it is a fancy Deli.  It is close to the Davies Hall and a lovely place to go at Xmas while going to the Symphony, and checking out the Holiday lights. My fav is the Reuben and they used to have a grilled veggie sandwich, which was awesome!
author: Katherine R.

description:
My mom and I came here on a Thursday night before seeing a concert at Davie's Hall. It was very packed but the staff were great at helping everyone out. We put our name down and were given a 20 minute wait time but we lucked out when seats at the bar opened up. 
There's live music to listen to that helps set the mood for the cute restaurant. 
And the food is AMAZING. I had a Roast Beef French Drip with a Lemon Drop drink. They give you a great amount for the price of the food - it can be just a tad pricey. 

The only downside is how small the whole place is! Even the bathrooms were crowded and a line had to start forming outside. Definitely would return again if I'm in the area though
author: Kait P.

description:
An old standby when going to the symphony or opera.  Always enjoy this place for a quick, good meal.  Had the matzo ball soup and pastrami sandwich, but great. Salads are huge.

Been here many times and will keep going back.
author: David J.

description:
This was the worst and terribly expensive "meal" of the year. 
So crowded and unfriendly. A true tourist trap. 
My food was so cold and poorly plated. 
Sloppy and expensive. 
Bah
author: Barbara G.

description:
Food - 3 Stars
Location - 4 Stars
Service - 4 Stars
5 Stars when the piano man is playing!

The Reuben is great. Pasta dishes are bland. The chocolate cake & the Cheesecake are subpar.
author: SayTin X.

description: Max's is a solid staple for good, easy food on Van Ness.  They make a pretty good Bloody Mary as well.
author: Robert H.

description:
There's so much food here! Ah!

It's conveniently located in the SF Civic Center and has a great underground parking garage. Awesome to pop in for a bite before you head to the Arts! (Ballet/Opera, Symphony and Herbst Theater) all just a block or two away in walking distance. 

Prior to the symphony, my friend and I had drinks and dinner here. It's best to call a few days before for reservations if you have tix to an area event because they fill up with the same type of guests headed out to events after dining. 

I've been here on several occasions and they always accommodate with friendly service and great food, large portions! I had the grilled salmon on greens and my friend had the veggie pasta, with vodka gimlet and stuffed shrooms to start, everything was perfectly delish! 

Ended with the chocolate cake which out of all their desserts is the most reasonably portioned! Haha, if you know a Max's location they have huge desserts!

Give it a try if you're in the area, excellent, speedy service and good food.
author: Tiffany M.

description: This place is hilarious. It reminds me of a combination of an old New York deli and a diner. The prices are really just above three dollar signs as we ordered two desserts each and it came out to about $65. The food quality is between three and four stores and the service is OK at best. The interesting thing all the other people that died in there. They remind me of all New Yorkers and come in a variety of sizes and shapes. The food portions a little bit too big for my liking but then hey, where in America.
author: Leung T.

description: Just went here with my mom and grandma am happy to report that the food is as good as ever. I got the fish and chips and the fish and fries were cooked perfectly. My mom and grandma split the chinese chicken salad and told me it was fantastic.
author: Nick S.

description:
I have been going to Max's for 30 years, and I am usually very pleased.
However, Last night I had a TERRIBLE experience. I specifically went there for Prime Rib ( which is usually excellent) because I was reassured by a friend who went there that they had it available. I  ordered Prime Rib. They served me a Rib Eye Steak and tried to pretend that it was Prime Rib!  I was truly disappointed because this was to be my Birthday Dinner.
author: James A.

description: One of my favorite lunch spots when I'm in the City on business. Very convenient with the underground parking garage just below. Great sandwiches and salads, and the freshly brewed iced tea is something to look forward to after the drive from CenCal. The service is always excellent as well.
author: Michael C.

description:
I came here on a work holiday lunch. One thing I like about this place is that when you make reservations for a large party, you are able to pre-order your meal so that way when your entire party comes in, you are all served at the same time as soon as you sat down. 

I ordered the grilled salmon salad. The salmon was definitely over cooked on the outside, yet still somewhat raw on the inside. It had a fishy taste to it still, which I found extremely unpleasant. The salad portions were very large, unfortunately it was all filler in my opinion

I also ordered dessert, the Niagara Falls cake. No matter how full I am, I always seem to have a second stomach for dessert; And this was not a disappointment. Not overly sweet, the cake was a nice consistency where it is dense and not just all air. The frosting was very well-made.

I would like to come back here for happy hour with coworkers sometime. Overall, our waiter was very attentive for our party size of 13-14. anyone who is able to work with large groups and have them leave happy and satisfied is a plus in my book
author: Anh T.

description: We (SF resident of 15+ yrs) needed a quick dinner (had only 45 min) between seeing two movies at the cinema next door. We had been to Max's a few times before, but this visit stood out. We were greeted by the lovely hostess who referred us to the bar. Luckily there were a few seats (on the Saturday after Xmas at half past 7) and were greeted by the personable and dazzling (she was bejeweled for the holidays) Kristy, who put in our order straight away (we told her our situation) and made sure all was well. The fish and chips came out fairly quickly and it too, was a delight - best fish and chips we ever had (and we're well traveled). But even if the F&C weren't great, we'd still go back to see Kristy! Hope you had a great NYE Kristy and will see you real soon! And I hope you did tell the chef we loved the meal!
author: Chance K.

description: Worst chicken piccata I've ever had; who makes it with tomato paste and cream sauce on noodles; no butter,capers or lemon.
author: basil p.

description:
If you're looking for some really great comfort food, this is the place to go.  All sorts of wonderfully delicious high fat, high cal foods.  The portion sizes are huge, and their desserts are incredible!  I often stop by after work to pick up an order of mushroom fettuccine or a slice of their double high carrot cake.  Yum!

​Contrary to what the name might suggest, this is not a fine dining restaurant and ​the music they play is definitely not opera quality!
author: Stephanie R.

description: Despite having a great location and a loyal following, the food at Max's is just not as good as the competition.  Service is also slow even at the bar. The piano and the singing staff are a great touch but this establishment could really use better food/cooking.
author: Andrew S.

description:
This place is my go-to when I'm in the city. Food is always great, service is efficient and attentive and you can't beat the live music. Great cocktails as well. I went with a group of 7 last time and every single dish was delicious. Had enough for leftovers too!

Great value, amazing food, service and atmosphere!
author: Joshua S.

description: Ordered tri mushroom fettuccine for $18.99, order comes soaked in oil with a bland taste, way overpriced for the quality of food
author: Yosia U.

description:
This location is far inferior to the Burlingame location. The hostess is not very friendly. We were given a pager because we didn't have a reservation; were told it would be about 20 mins. Five mins later our pager goes off so we head back to the hostess stand. There was another couple standing there. My husband held up the flashing pager & the hostess started walking off with menus in her hand. The other couple & I were confused; we weren't sure which party she was trying to seat. Turns out it was the other couple. Anyways, the hostess told my husband she didn't call us even though it was clearly flashing. 

My husband & I go back to the seating area, which BTW, are chairs lined up on a ramp so the seats are on a decline. Finally we were paged & led to our table. 

Immediately my husband & I noticed the table was sticky. It's probably not a good idea to paint the table tops. 

Our server took our order. We ordered the avocado fries for an appetizer. The server said OK. I told her I'll have the fish & chips; she said OK. My husband ordered the patty melt; the server said OK. Then, the server asked what it was I ordered. I glanced over & she was still writing down "avocado fries." After she wrote all 3 dishes down, she went to the next table for their order & left our menus on our table. 

The avocado fries arrived, very much lacking in presentation. The avocado fry itself was kind of bland. Avocado doesn't have much flavor; the least they could have done was season the batter. The sauce was glopped on a lettuce leaf making it difficult to scoop. There wasn't even enough sauce; we had to scrape down the lettuce leaf and still had bland avocado fries sans sauce. 

Not once were we offer drink refills but we were FINALLY offered some bread when we were halfway done with our meals. 

I think I'll stick to Burlingame.
author: Rose A.

description:
I would like to file a complaint against an employee of this restaurant. I had a very bad experience in this place and would like to formally file a complaint.

I called in around 11:30am to order "Chicken Cobb Salad" for pick up. A gentleman answered the phone and told me that he will transfer my call to the one responsible for taking food orders via phone. A woman with a hispanic accent answered the phone and asked what I want to order and I told her that I want to order Chicken Cobb Salad for pick up and I said and....and before I was able to say my next order - she hanged up the phone.

I told myself, I will just go ahead and talk to her when I get there...when I got there, I saw a hispanic female working at the "TO GO" area and noticed how rude she was behaving at another customer who has been standing there awhile. She never looked at us or acknowledge us or even ask us to wait. She just let us stood there. She then took his order then she looked at me without saying anything for few seconds as if i automatically know what to do....I then said I ordered cobb salad...she left without saying a word. She came back tossed my food on the counter and said $17.33 and I asked for extra dressing ...she then said in spanish "this bitch wants extra dressing" I said what did you say ...she said nothing and I gave her $20 and without waiting for change as i figure she can keep the change...she just looked and said something in spanish. I asked to speak with a manager but they let me wait for so long that I had to go and figured I will just call and speak to the manager.

When I came back to my office, I called the restaurant and asked to speak with a manager. Whoever answered the phone hung up on me. I called again only to experience the same thing.


I'm not sure what's going on in this restaurant and why they feel entitled and think they can just treat people like that but as I know - restaurants generate revenue from customers who comes to enjoy the experience and enjoy the food.


I am very disappointed with this place and will go on every social media and news and feedback posting just to let everyone know the bad experienced i;ve had including the other people I know who went through the same thing too.



Extremely disappointed!
author: Liz J.

description: Been here many times, so ready to write an overdue review! Max's has been consistently a great place for lunch. Interesting layout, as you enter next to "take-out" counter - just continue forward past "salad prep area" to host/ess stand to be seated. The service is always attentive, with many servers becoming familiar faces. The place can get noisy, but such are people today! Good for small groups as well, as we often see. The seating side closest to McAllister seems a little more relaxed, perhaps the setting calms people. Many good items on the menu, including salads, French dip, Matzoh Ball soup and my one and only love, the Ultimate Grill Cheese (no tomatoes, please - they get too soggy!) and sub a side chopped salad. Plenty for lunch. Hot rolls available on request as well, but they tend to favor the raisin rolls over sourdough, so if you prefer sourdough just ask for those instead of both. Anyways . . . if you're in the civic center area you should stop by and try this place. Gets busy around lunch because of the office bees, so if possible come at opening or after 1pm . . . gets quieter. One great piece of news!!! I have been to several Max's throughout the greater Bay Area for many decades, and they always had "ice tea" that was brought to your table while it was brewing! This and a large cup of ice, with a lemon wedge, is the way I was accustomed to receiving Max's ice tea. Sadly, somewhere in the past few years they switched to bring you the glass pre-filled with tea and ice, as do most places today. Most uncivilized for those of us who like a strong (long brewed) tea. However, this visit I almost fainted as the server brought us our ice teas - in a tea pot, with 2 large glasses of ice each (you really need the second glass as it is VERY hot and melts the first glass of ice quickly!). I was shocked, and mentioned this, to which the server replied that the new manager, a nephew (?) of the owners wanted a return to the old ways, and this was one face of the new and improved Max's. I approve strongly, and appreciate the extra effort. Maybe it does "taste" the same as the premixed teas, but I think if presentation is the key to a great meal, this is the way to start it off right!! Thanks for the happy memories - again!!
author: Mark K.

description: Max's Opera Cafe is a pathetic excuse of a restaurant.  We had a reservation for 5:30pm on a Saturday night in Dec 2017 and could not be sat because of a back log of reservations still waiting to be sat.  Reservation 30-45 minutes before us were still waiting for a table.  You cannot count on them to honor reservations so never book, but especially not if you are planning to attend the opera, theatre, ballet, or any other scheduled show afterwards.  We ended up going to Home Alone at the Symphony hungry.
author: Katie D.

description:
Feels like home... With that old world American charm hanging over it at all times.. I feel transcended everytime am there. Piano playing in the background its so easy to be serenaded and feel lost in the time and space.
Also the portion size makes sure you're well fed just like a granny would take care of you. Oh good ol' Max!
author: Auroshikha R.

description:
I've been here multiple times without checking in.... came here with 2 coworkers. We wanted to eat at that sushi place nearby, but it's not there anymore. 

We were seated in a booth near the back. Our server was really nice and accommodated us. One coworker wanted the special without bread and extra mashed potatoes... and I got Joe's special for lunch and another coworker got the special too. I also got soup which I thought was delicious. Chicken sausage gumbo or something.

We got dessert, but the dessert kinda took forever, that's why minus one star, but other than that they helped us cut the cake in half and in a to go box for us. 

I would definitely come back since I always enjoy their food. There is a lot of business people that go there and eat.
author: Eugenia W.

description:
this is Randy fave resto in San Francisco.
Beautiful live jazz music and singing. 

Brian is an excellent singer/ waiter who sang la vi en rose sooo beautiful it really touched me.

Ribeye creamed spinach and baked potato for mommy

Mac and cheese for Skye

Pastrami on rye with french fries for Randy

Apple pie a la mode for mommy

Garage parking 

Wonderful end to Father's Day weekend
author: Charlene C.

description:
Max's has new owners but I did not know that when we went to celebrate my birthday.

What a huge disappointment. I was told the singers were not working so I didn't get my singing but someone else did!

They were out of many items on the menu which has been changed. Many favorites are gone.

The service was terrible. 

The end of an era for Max's ; not my go to pre-performance or birthday anymore.
author: maybelline e.

description: Yes, Max's Opera is overpriced by $5-7 dollars on every dish I'd say. Someone I met told me about this restaurant near the Opera and Symphony. I thought I'd try it. The dishes that really got a hold of my attention were Jewish deli classics like potato pancakes and matzo ball soup. I ended up getting the Reuben and as they say, juice will drip down the sides of your hands. The Reuben had sauerkraut and I got cole slaw on the side. My friend had a vegetable pasta and he finished it. I tried some and it did not stand out, but it was edible. It's a cozy restaurant with a lot of space. To top it off, there's a piano player playing classics.
author: Denise C.

description:
Never order takeout from here! They use those cheap compostable boxes that crumble up within a few minutes. Take a look at my photos. They might as well not have given me any boxes and just tossed all the food in the bag. I ordered 3 meals for pickup ($75) and all the food spilled out of the box and into the bag. They were defensive and said the boxes were intact when I picked them up. They only offered me a bs 10% discount. It's not that great dining there either. 

The food is expensive and not that great tasting. They only get business from all the patrons that are attending shows in the area. 

The Max's Laws on the back of the menu is bs. #3-They don't make the iced tea fresh at your table. 
#5- They don't keep your table clear of dirty plates. Look at my pics. My plates were sitting there more than 30 mins while the staff were just chatting with each other. 
#10- big portions? Not! Check out everyone's photos.

What's up with the 5.9% SF benefits offset fee?

I WILL NEVER RETURN TO THIS RESTAURANT AGAIN!!! My family and I came here to celebrate my brothers birthday and honestly the entire time I was there I was pissed off. We got to the restaurant around 720. We were seated right away (first star) while we waited our waiter came and took drink orders. The rest of my family joined us and we placed our food order. We ordered a good amount of food. Unfortunately, we sat until 845 when they brought us our food. My children (who are 5) had to sit and wait until the food was prepared to eat so they got irritable and wouldn't sit still. When the food finally came I couldn't believe what they put in front of me.  We ordered 3 things of nachos, the chips were stale, it was like they took some ingredients and just dropped them on top of the chips. The chicken they put on mine was cold, my boyfriend ordered steak nachos the steak was burnt and my cousin who order chicken with extra jalapeños. They gave her cold chicken, a little bit of jalapeños and to top it off. The amount of meat was very small for them to be $20 each! All of the other food was mediocre. My sons burger was undercooked, we asked for well done the burger came out medium. My daughter ordered a grilled cheese with fries which could've came out quickly. I wouldn't be so upset if I didn't know the restaurant was basically empty aside from 4 people in another part. I ended up speaking to the manager regarding my disappointment with the food. He didn't seem to care much that the kitchen was so slow children had to wait over a hour to be served their meal. I do not recommend this restaurant to anyone. Especially if you have small children. Oh the second star is for the waiter being so polite and welcoming! I would never fault him for a mess up in the kitchen! One last thing. Did I mention they microwave the 3 plates of nachos??? Ha... this place is a joke, and way too expensive to be falling short in their kitchen!


Ps. While we sat there waiting for our food for all that time someone was breaking into our car. They stole my purse and my son new winter coat!
author: Racquell C.

description:
Don't get sticker shocked looking at their menus online. Their lunch prices are usually a few dollars less and the portions are very filling... even for my XXL appetite! 

Had the sweet & sour spinach salad today. It has bacon, candied almonds, mandarin orange slices, cubed pears, avocado, and spinach, with a creamy lemon vinegarette. Yummy!!!

They have a wide variety of salads and other diner fares (burgers, plates, etc) Will try their kale salad next!
author: Stephen Y.

description: The food here is actually quite good. I ordered Max's Famous Reubin Sandwich with pastrami and fries. The fries are ok. The sandwich was good. Be prepared for a very noisy environment. They could use some sound deadening panels on the ceiling. Our party of seven were going to the Nutcracker ballet. Even though we were ten minutes late, they were able to get us seated in time to complete our meal and make it in time. Be prepared to pay the San Francisco employee health tax in addition to the sales tax.
author: Bob C.

description: I used to go to Max's (Stanford location) for years, just for Guy's Chinese Chicken salad. Ate there again last week after a year hiatus.  I was very disappointed with GCCS this time.  Chicken was half the size, tough and seemed undercooked.  The chicken used to be encrusted with peanuts.  There may have been 2 pieces of peanut, in all, on the chicken. The peanuts are what made it for me.  The service was very good.  However, GCCS has gone "down hill", and the price has gone up.  Max's has moved to the bottom of my list of eatery's.
author: Louise H.

description: The portions are huge here. Don't come for the ambiance unless you are specifically looking for a schizophrenic retro (not in a good way retro) diner/delicatessen/cheesy 70s piano lounge twilight zone feel. The booth table had a weird coating that was sticky and had newspaper (or menu) print permanently on it from something transferring. This space is huge with a lot of Windows and would be amazing with an overhaul. But food was diner style and tasty, and fresh. But definitely not refined by any means. Service was quick and efficient. Come hungry or share an item.
author: Piper W.

description:
food was good
service excellent
classic 1980's feel restaurant
Enjoyed the experience
author: Steven M.

description: Super disappointing. It's been years since I went here. I don't know what's gone on in the interim but it ain't what it used to be. Cranky maître d', sticky table, poor heat, desultory matzoh ball soup and really sad heap of nachos. Take a pass and go to Mels
author: cece b.

description:
This place has been around since I was in college.  I picked up lunch to go today.  I ordered a grilled chicken sandwich.  Sandwich and chicken were huge!  However the sandwich was bone dry.  This was even after I smeared mayonnaise and ketchup on it.  

$11 for sandwich, drink and chips.  Ok.  Not mind blowing.
author: Wendy H.

description: This place continuously has great food, great service, and a great atmosphere. My husband and I came here as a mom & dad only getaway and have been craving Max's for awhile. We both ordered sandwiches and my husband got a chocolate martini. All were excellent. Good portions as well. We will continue to return each time we come to the bay!
author: PaulSandra K.

description: The food was good, as was the atmosphere.    But the happy hour service at the bar was extremely slow and not courteous.
author: Ed W.

description:
A very nice and festive atmosphere, the food is reasonably priced.
There was a piano player and one of the employees sang as did the piano player.  I took my 80 year old mother there with my kids after seeing the ballet.  My mother loved it.  Our waiter Brian was the best...my mom described him as being like an old friend. Thanks to the restaurant for being a perfect ending to our day in San Francisco.
author: Paula T.

description:
I've been coming to Max's at this location since about '98. I made a regular appearence each week for lunch with my coworkers when I was working in the area. Now that I am back in the area, I have been back a few times and it's still a crowd pleaser.

I brought the whole crew in recently for lunch. We were limited on time, but was able to book a reservation via Opentable ahead of time and were seated immediately. Everyone was pleased with thier order and I got to introduce them to a new spot. 

I have my usual items, I go with the pastrami or corned been reuben or chinese chicken salad. Sometimes a nice chop salad, sometime a iceberg wedge. 

I love the soups, but the chicken matzo ball soup has always been a comfort when sick or on a cold day. The broth is soothing and the matzo is huge and filling, yet fluffy. Ask for the bread, the rolls are delcious and each is different. 

The portions are big, but I like to eat half and take the rest to go. Even then there is never any room for dessert and they make some amazing desserts! 

I ordered a tuna melt the other day and had half, took the rest home and made it into a tuna salad. Very good. At $13 for the plate, I would say that was an excellent deal. 

This is my favorite Max's location and I'm glad it is within walking distance of my work place. Makes it really convienant to have work lunches and meetings with good food at a decent price.
author: Rebekah T.

description: Rather surprised at Max's last night. Although my corned beef and my SO's pastrami were quite acceptable, the rye bread they were served on was just terrible. No other way to say it. I have never had worse rye bread on a corned beef sandwich before. Not dense, not crusty, not really rye bread. Max's, you should check out Miller's or Wise Sons to up your rye bread style. Until you do, I'm afraid you've lost my business.
author: Diane K.

description: This place is just so expensive for what it offers. Nothing on the menu is outstanding for the price you pay. I once paid $22 for a beet salad with chicken and it was just okay. I work in the building and Max's is my last resort on days when I don't bring lunch and I don't feel like walking an extra block for better food.
author: Chan P.

description:
The warning is etched on the door. This is a bad place for a diet! No kidding! We went in anyway and decided to let it all hang out being New Year eve! We were hopeful that we can get a good meal and be entertained by their talented servers, as after all, we haven't been into Max's for well over 15 years. But alas! I now remember why we stayed away. Their glory days seemed over as we ended up getting neither.
 
The evening started pleasantly enough with live piano playing in the background. The dining room was nicely decorated for the holiday season and appeared cozy and swanky. The Christmas lights stylishly lit up the bar area and the glass windows.  Even with a full house, the muted conversation and soft piano music added some class and sophistication to the ambiance. Being a fan of the opera, I was somewhat disappointed that none of the servers sing anymore. This used to be a unique draw for Max's during their heydays. 

The server could have been a little more attentive but overall pleasant and friendly. Soups, salads, burgers, sandwiches, pastas, desserts etc. ...You name it; Max's have them all!  One can say Max's is like a glorified diner. We shared a hearty bowl of Russian Cabbage Soup ($8.00) sans beets. I assume this was the non-beets version of borscht. It was instead tomato-y and the other ingredients were cabbage with chock-full of beef giving the soup a savory, beefy flavor. With a subtle sweet and sour taste, the soup was great though not over-the-top great. (4 stars)

In the mood to play "Finding a needle in a haystack"? Try Max's Famous Crab Cakes ($17.00). Two good-sized crab cakes were served but where was the crabmeat? Bland! Bland! Bland! They looked like frozen patties with tartar sauce on top, which by the way was good but cannot save the underwhelming crab cakes. The saving grace for this dish was the red cabbage and jicama slaw that came with a mustard caper aioli. (2 stars). Skip!

Tri-Mushroom Fettuccine ($17.00) wasn't bad but needed help.  Even without any culinary background, I still know it was time to add Parmesan for better flavor; to spice the pasta with a little chili crushed peppers and to add a cautious touch of salt. I am not a huge fan of rosemary and thyme bunches and had to toss them. I wish Max's were more generous with the tri-mushrooms (portabella, shitake and button). The mushrooms were delicious though, and were sautéed with fresh herbs, evoo and toasted garlic. The fettuccine was a toothsome morsel, had a good bite or al dente. (3 stars)

We thought we needed to order at least one sandwich since Max's is known for their deli meats. Since no one cared for a Reuben or Corned Beef, we settled on a Patty Melt ($15.00) that came highly recommended from a young friend who had no qualms with fat and cholesterol! I bit my tongue and reluctantly agreed.  Why not... today was NYE? We ordered the works and it came loaded with cheese, caramelized onions and 1000 Island on grilled rye. It was sinfully rich alright and sinfully tasty as well while you chomp into the cheese, the onions, the medium rare meat and only to sober up with the down-to-earth taste of rye. Yay! There was no guilt feeling at least today...it only starts the next day or the New Year! (4 stars)

The tart and aromatic Key Lime pie ($8.00) was just the way I remembered it from 15 years ago and provided a happy ending.... for the year 2014, I mean. The sweet and flaky crust was filled with a creamy smooth lime flavored filling and topped with a dollop of whipped cream. It was very refreshing to your palate. (4 stars)
author: Geoff G.

description:
This is a place I eat at. I have been here probably a dozen times. I am certain to go back. It is competent at what it does. It also serves generous portions. Nothing is great; nothing is terrible. It is what is is. And it's honest about that. No pretense. 

A big plus for efficiency. They will get you in and out before the symphony or opera.
author: Frank W.

description:
I stumbled upon this cafe on my way to Peets. It's a nice location. It's nearby Peets Coffee, Books Inc., and the Landmark Theaters Opera Plaza Cinema. I came for breakfast and it was pretty empty but for a few tables. I optimistically assumed that this was a hidden gem I accidentally discovered. This was not the case. Unfortunately, this will be my first and last visit. 

I ordered coffee, and Max's Famous Diner Hash. It came topped with three eggs over easy. The coffee was bitter and the hash was bland. The hash lacked any flavor and the corned beef tasted like it had recently been warmed up by a microwave. I had to add a ludicrous amount of hot sauce to finish the meal. 

Bland food is unforgivable, but the food was also expensive! The bitter coffee was $3.00 and the Hash was $17.00. Overall, I was disappointed and Max's will go down in my book as a one and done.
author: David M.

description: Had a great brunch here today before the Sunday afternoon ballet. Max's has a lot of selections and takes reservations for Sunday brunch! Here's a shout out to Lindsay who took great care of our party.
author: Lou S.

description:
No. 
Had a very overpriced and underwhelming lunch here. Everything on the menu is about 20% too expensive for the quality (basically diner food). I ordered the greek meze plate which came with lamb patties, hummus, pita, and tzatziki. The lamb tasted a little "off" (I had a stomach ache a few hours after eating it) and there was not enough pita for the plate. I asked for extra pita to finish my meal and was surprised to find they charged $3 for it. Seriously? $3?!?!? You can get an entire package of pita for $3 and they charged $3 for six slivers. Boo. 

Two stars for our very kind server but the food was less than mediocre. So many better options for lunch in this area.
author: Semuteh F.

description: Great atmosphere and a lovely man playing a piano complete the setting. The food and service were average at best. I ordered the honey chicken which was so over cooked I had to send it back. The 2nd time was way better but took too long to come out and by that time I wasn't interested anymore. The potatoes were a little bland too. It's a good place if you are going to the Symphony and want a little mood setting but the food needs a little work.
author: Angela H.

description: The fries were pretty fire and the food was alright,not the best but it was pretty high up there.The live performance had me thinking of suicidal thoughts  and I noticed that everyone else that was dining here tonight had black napkins but me a my three Mexican friends did not receive any black napkins ,we only got white napkins. That is all I have to say bout these white supremacist.
author: Max W.

description: Hadn't been here in some time but decided to come early before an event at Herbst and use a gift certificate. 5:30 pm the place was literally half empty, but they had no tables because we had no reservation. Really? After reading the recent reviews, it looks like they're under new management, so they probably wouldn't have taken the gift certificate anyway. Also the reviews don't look too appetizing of late. We went elsewhere and had a nice dinner.
author: Wendy R.

description:
I've been coming here for 15 years... Why haven't I written a review? 

Simply the best food in the city. They have figured out the formula for a perfect "easy" dining experience. 

P.S. Blanca at the bar is fantastic. She's so attentive and friendly. Her drinks are on point too!
author: Dave H.

description: Horrible service. Bad food. Our food was super late, we were never told that our appetizer was not abailable, and the alfredo pasta we ordered did not actually have the alfredo sauce. Old favorite gone bad. Sad but true.
author: Yelena K.

description: I have been going to Max's Opera Cafe for 20 years. It used to be a great place to go before the opera or symphony. I have to say that in the last year the menu has lost items that I loved like chopped liver sandwich. The last two times they seemed to be very understaffed and the wait for service was extraordinarily long, 30-45 minutes and the food just is not what it used to be. My fish and chips was cold and soggy!! I talked to about 6 friends who have also foundthe same thing....poor service and bad food. We are all deciding NOT to choose Max's again.
author: David B.

description: We had a great chicken pot pie. Very attentive waiter. Lovely piano music. Clean and nice.
author: Shelly R.

description:
I dined here for lunch for a coworker's retirement celebration.  The service was great.  But I can't even remember what I ordered because it just wasn't memorable.  Which means that it wasn't bad, but it wasn't great either.

I've heard good things about the matzo ball soup.  I'll have to try it one day.
author: Vira P.

description: Arrived for a dinner reservation for 10 that we had confirmed the prior day and the restaurant was pandemonium. I have never seen so many people in a reservation line WHO HAD RESERVATIONS.  There were parties of 4,6, and 8 waiting for tables for reservations that were at least 1/2 hour earlier than ours. The reservation people had overbooked are working for computer and paper lists and had a fully packed restaurant with no hope of accommodating most of the people in line. What a train wreck when you are taking small hungry children to dinner before the Nutcracker. DON'T RELY ON THEIR RESERVATIONS TO BE ANYTHING OTHER THAN A WISH.
author: mary jane w.

description:
I ordered a chicken sandwich that came on toasted sourdough, with cheddar, avocado and grilled onions. The toasted bread was probably the best tasting thing from my plate, next to the French fries. The avocado wasn't ripe enough and was hard and had no flavor. The chicken breast in the sandwich was horrible and I'm pretty sure it was a frozen piece of meat. I took a few bites of the first half, with the thinner part of the breast, and my boyfriend asked how it was and I mentioned something was off. I bit into the thicker part of the chicken breast in the sandwich...and spit it out because it felt like I was biting into raw meat. It looked cooked through, but was was to tough to be fresh and turned me off from the rest of the sandwich, didn't even bother to pack up the other half.

My boyfriend had a corned beef and swiss...it was decent, your average corned beef sandwich...nothing spectacular though. 

Our son had the kids macaroni and cheese. It looked like macaroni and cheese, but tasted like macaroni and butter. I know butter is used to make Mac and cheese normally...but this was more butter flavor than I've tasted on anything...even buttered toast for breakfast.

We were seated fast, customer service was fine, but the food was nothing that would make me return. I feel the food is over priced but they can get away with it because of their location.
author: Danielle R.

description:
This updated review is a few months past due, as it should have been done on September 25, 2013.

First of all, there aren't too many restaurants that have excellent food and ambiance in the Civic Center area and/or close by the SF State Building.  Maestro's is long gone and I do miss their chicken crepes.  The choices of restaurants are limited.  O3 Bistro changed up their menu...nice ambiance but the luncheon menu selection ain't what it used to be.

After 40+ years of working for the state government, it was time for me to start a second journey (heading out the door and toward retirement).  My colleagues gave me a farewell luncheon on September 24 at Max's Opera Cafe, and they were kind enough to do so.  I didn't have the heart to tell two of my colleagues (organizers of the luncheon) that I was not (and still not) a big fan of Max's.  The menu selections were okay; and all I could hope for was improvement in customer service.  

Last year I attended a farewell luncheon, and the service was slow, especially for people who ordered the Asian chicken wrap.  Most of us had already eaten over half of our lunch when the waitstaff brought out the wrap.  They claimed they were not fully staffed that day.  Even my Arnie Palmer was sour.  

The customer service improved and the waitstaff was more attentive and accommodating.  My turkey sandwich was okay.  At least there was more gravy on the mashed potatoes.  My Arnie Palmer tasted better.  Overall rating:  no more and/or less than a 3.25.
author: Carol C.

description: I generally like Max's but this one can't handle reservations.  When we arrived the desk lady made a face and we watched the waiting area fill up and bailed after 30 minutes.  A sit down place next to venues like the symphony or opera has to run a certain way.  Max's doesn't anymore.  Avoid for reservations.
author: Steve G.

description: This place is good for a big group, especially before the theater or symphony. My dishes have been just ok. My friend ordered the Chinese chicken salad and said it was not good at all, she didn't want to complain so ordered some fries as a supplement. I didn't bother to try the salad, it was very big but did not look appetizing. I tried some fries and liked them. I think you would be safe with a burger and fries here. The pastrami is supposed to be good too. I would not go out of my way to dine here but would give it another chance if I am in the area. The servers have always been quite nice.
author: Sam M.

description:
I'm giving this place the maximum stars because it has parking lot around the corner, comfy booth seats, you never need reservations except for during SF Symphony/Opera/Ballet dinner times, the staff is friendly and the food is good.  How many SF restaurants can claim all these things?

A caveat about the food, don't order anything that isn't originally American, (like pasta, etc).  Things like their Reuben, which is my favorite, they are right on.  Their portions are HUGE.  When I get the reuben, I always say afterwards, "the next time we come here, we have to share one." But I never do, why is that?  I love this place and would be crushed if it ever left.
author: Johnnie N.

description: I remember coming here as a kid with my parents, still looks and tastes the same, as in excellent. Yeah, area questionable, so what, it's worth the visit to Max's!
author: Rady A.

description:
Max's is a great place to get a bite before or after performances just down the street at the Opera or the Symphony.

Also, Google has been incorrectly showing it as closed on the weekends. This is *NOT* true.

Its hours are Monday - Thursday 10 am - 10 pm Friday 10 am - 11 pm, Bar open until 11:30 pm; Saturday 10 am - 11 pm, Bar until 11:30 pm; Sunday 10 am - 10 pm
author: John L.

description:
Fabulous food and wonderful ambiance. We enjoyed a wonderfully prepared Chicken Picatta and Shrimp Louis that was out of this world! All while listening to a wonderful live piano musician in the back ground. 

Wonderful place to go. I loved all the mirrors, they are reasonably priced and I will definitely come here again!
author: John P.

description: We went here because it was close to the War Memorial Opera House and it looked full. It was surprisingly bad. The pastrami was thinly-sliced, dry and flavorless, and was missing the Swiss cheese. The matzah ball soup was average at best, certainly no better than what you can get at any Jewish deli on the corner. The beef dip was likewise dry and flavorless. The au jus was more like gravy and had no flavor. We are super surprised that there is a wait for this place as a crowd usually signals good food. We will need to search for other eats around the area next time.
author: Philip C.

description:
We went there Sunday.
The food for the price was very mediocre. The reason I am writing this review is they charged my card twice two different amounts.I drove back the next day and the waiter did not even apolgiese and I am have just noticed a third charge from them. I am trying to work this out with the manger but they seem dishonest I would never go back again.
author: Shane O.

description: Four of us went to Max's today at 4:00. The restaurant wreaked of rancid oil that others smelled all over our clothes even after we left, and which gave us a headache while we were there. We had to wait for 10 minutes to be seated even though the place was almost empty. We then waited for 15 minutes to be greeted by the waiter.  Then 2 out of 3 of our orders were prepared completely wrong, after waiting for 30 minutes to get it. I'd suggest eating ANYWHERE else unless you just want cheesecake to go.
author: Millie G.

description: Had the signature pastrami, nothing special and it SHOULD have been for the price. Inattentive service to boot.
author: Alex B.

description:
Max's was a popular place to go 20 years ago. The crowds may have died, but the food remains the same,  jumbo sandwiches, a chicken pot pie that could feed a small village, good Jewish deli.

Still a great place to take care if your sweet tooth cravings. The Chocolate cake, and macaroon are awesome, try the rich tasty carrot cake.

If you miss the 80's stop by for a slice.
author: Brad C.

description:
I still love you Max's and always will BUT this location...the service BLOWS. Or maybe it is the management, or staff in the back  Bartender/waitress girl was really gruff and short with us, like she needed another hit of blow in the back.  Our waitress was nice but my date's steak was too rare and my salad had dressing after I asked for no dressing.  The man dining next to us also sent his steak back for being rare. 
I hope they get it together and can deliver more consistent service.
author: Chelsey G.

description: Convenient location close to the Theater, good food, fast and courageous service. I like this place and visit often.
author: Lynn F.

description: Max's has descended to dreadful. Used to love Max's, now itsa joint to avoid. Much better off at Tommy's Joynt: https://www.yelp.com/biz/tommys-joynt-san-francisco . "Something has changed" (quoting another review). I am sure they capture the symphony/opera/ballet pre-show crowd, however their convenience just would not compensate for the poor quality meals and high prices. Lunch during the week, had a superlative waiter and sub-par food. Sad to say the best thing on the table was the french fries, which I could say about McDonald's --- not Max's pastrami sandwich nor Max's open faced turkey sandwich. When paying $ 17 for a sandwich, I would hope and expect to say "that was great" ... NOT. Now pushing a varied menu of Poke /Nachos/BBQ pork sliders/"Wraps"/steaks/sandwiches/  etc. etc. etc. Max's has lost its way, adrift in the sea of dishes popular in the moment, unfocused and unsatisfying. While they have managed to open 5 locations in the vaunted Bay Area;  the quantity of locations does not seem to translate into a good meal @ Max's 601 Van Ness Ave. Deli style deliciousness & tradition seem to be LONG gone. Oi Vey.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
What has happened to this place?! 

My family and I used to always eat here pre-theater, so we came here on Saturday night before seeing a show at the Orpheum. Our reservation was at 5:30 but it was already super busy. Most of my family had already been sat but I had to stand in a 5-10 minute line to speak with the hostess. She couldn't find our last name but said there was one large party in the back and motioned towards the right side of the restaurant. Thanks? 

Once we were all sat, our server came by and took our drink order. She was unaware of half of the drinks that we ordered (which were all in the drink menu) and kept asking us to point to the drink name in the menu. The drinks came in two's throughout a 10-15 minute period; during that time we attempted to order food and she would quickly rush away before we could say anything. When it finally came time to order, she took our starter orders and then walked away, saying that she had to put in those orders before she could take down our entrees. Really?

We ordered the crab cakes and the friend calamari. Both dishes were pretty tasty. Once we were finished the dirty dishes sat on our table even after our entrees were delivered. Finally we asked another server to remove the dishes from our table. Our water glasses were not refilled once, and it was only until we were mostly done with our entrees that our server asked if we wanted any more drinks. For the entree, I ordered the bowl of matzo ball soup, expecting it to be a super large serving that the restaurant is known for. Sadly, it was not an entree sized dish, but I was able to take bites from everyone else's meal. My husband ordered the Rueben and greatly enjoyed it, although he said that potato salad tasted too much like vinegar. My brother ordered the fish and chips; he said the fish was good but the fries were way too soggy.  My parents ordered the grilled salmon and soba salad, and there were no complaints. 

Halfway through our entree we told our server that we needed to leave by a certain time in order to make our show, and asked for our bill in advanced. 5 minutes until we're supposed to leave, and we're still waiting for the bill. She seemed uninterested that we were in a rush, which greatly frustrated the entire table. We ended up having to run to the theater in order to make it in time. 

The food was good enough to earn 2 stars, but otherwise a definite 1 star, disappointing experience.
author: Regina L.

description: We were looking for a place to have lunch.walked into Max's opera cafe and waited at the host podium waited for a while while five people walked by me did not say a word did not say hello did not say I'll be right with you did not say anything. Finally I asked one of the people that passed by me what does it take to get a seat she gave me a smirk no hello no I'm sorry and said Walk This Way. While I was waiting for my order to be taken I noticed a couple dressed very nicely walking in and before the door was able to shut they were seated immediately. When my order arrived I ordered a chicken salad sandwich it was horrible it had big chunks of frozen chicken pieces inside. For an establishment at this location calling themselves the Opera Cafe and with prices like these, one would think the food would be top notch I would not recommend this place to people who love to eat food especially good food please go elsewhere. The service was lousy the food was lousy.
author: ed z.

description: Needed a loan for a chicken salad sandwich that falls apart and is made with old bread. Disaster.
author: John ..

description:
Why is your hostess so mad at everyone who walks in the door? We sat next to her station and watched her greet each customer with a snarl. Very disturbing!

Ordered chicken soup and Caesar salad. Only got the salad. Waiter could NOT have cared less. The waiter took our order and the next time we saw him was when he brought the check without bothering to ask if we cared for anything more (like the other half of my dinner)or dessert.

This place has gone downhill fast in the past few years.  Might as well be at Mel's Diner across the street.

STAY AWAY!!!!
author: Les T.

description:
Max's has changed...
I've eaten there for perhaps 25 years, sure it was always a bit pricey, but the food was very good.

Last night before going the the Symphony, my wife and I stopped in for dinner. We hadn't been there in about 2 years.

The restaurant was busy, but not full as there was plenty of tables. The hostess sat us at a table placed between the kitchen and the bathrooms. We asked to be moved and she begrudgingly complied. We than waited 20 minutes for a waiter. (The hostess apparently never assigned the table to a waiter). In the meantime, a busboy dropped a bunch of napkins on the table (while we sat) as well as silverware.  It was up to us to set the table.

I should note that at this point I went to use the men's room. Honestly, it was filthy and smelled, There were paper towels on the floor which was also wet. Obviously, there was nobody checking the cleanliness.

Back at the table, I noticed that the menu had changed, from a rather large selection to only a few pages. Being a cold night, my wife and I were in the mood for a large bowl of Chicken Matzoh ball soup. They don't serve it anymore, only a small cup for $9.00. We, therefore decided on a corned beef sandwich for me and pastrami for my wife. Note that each sandwich was now $19.00 dollars. For that type of money you'd expect a nice full sandwich (ex NY'ers would know what I mean) however the size was average. The corned beef had no flavor and it appeared to have been sitting in boiling water for hours. Just awful! Similar for the Pastrami. The potato salad did have flavor...of a huge amount of mayonnaise. Again...awful! 
We left most of the food on the plate, paid the bill and left. My wife wanted to use the ladies room but I advised her to wait till we walked over to Davies.

Now, I realize San Francisco is an expensive city and I understand that prices need to rise to keep up, however there is no excuse for the quality of the food to have taken such a nosedive.
Furthermore, the attitude of the hostess was inexcusable.

Max's was an institution, a place to quench my occasional NY cravings as well as a pleasant place to have a good meal. No more. That is sadly the last time we'll eat at Max's. Hopefully other long time SF residents will speak up!
author: Gene M.

description: Well all I had was coffee and a brownie. But the server treated us as if we were special anyway. He was very nice and recommended the brownie over the eclaire which was an excellent choice! The brownie is a pillow of chocolaty goodness,tender and melts in your mouth. The coffee was fresh and strong, full of flavor.  I asked if I could get a tomato and the guy gave me a couple extra! I plan to go back after I saw the amazing looking sandwiches!
author: Orleana P.

description: We ordered take out from this place while visiting friends... BIG MISTAKE. We all got sick shortly after eating. It was a long uncomfortable night for everyone (I'll spare you the details). We couldn't go out that evening to enjoy the city because we need to be near the bathroom.
author: Lanie L.

description:
Just around the corner from the Symphony is a New York-style deli where the pastrami comes in the fistful and the cheesecake could serve as ballast on a windy day.  To add to the throwback charm, the waiters are well-dressed and a musician tends a piano in the corner. 

To say the place has charm undersells it's greatest feature.  Sure, you can go anywhere in the area for a nice dinner before the show.  But a night at the symphony is all about doing something classic and vintage, and I can't think of a better pairing.
author: Seth E.

description: Wish u could be as excited about Max's As I was last year. But not so. Noisy, frantic staff, food that was not up to what i remember. Too bad for a place that is not what it used to be.
author: Willliam O.

description:
What a disapointment. I have been going to Max's over 25 years. The matzo ball soup is the exception. Still great. The corned beef and pastami sandwich is terrible. The nitrate free meat is dry and flavorless. The rye bread has no rye flavor. The cole slaw has no meaning. They removed the chopped chicken liver which was to die for.
Max's is a sandwich joint with opera singers. You better like the music or a salad because it is not a deli anymore.
author: Winston L.

description:
Short story:  My family has enjoyed many meals at Max's Opera Cafe and we were all looking forward to their Thanksgiving lunch.  This year, our experience was so terrible I wrote to the owner and manager - no reply.  From the service to the food, it could not have been worse.  
 
Long story:  We made a reservation more than one month in advance for a table of six, but when we arrived, though the restaurant was fairly empty, the hostess suggested we should "push a few tables together" in the bar area.  No problem - we did.  Our server, busy clearing plates off of neighboring tables assured us he'd be right with us.  Okay - no problem.  We cheerfully greeted him when he came to take our drink order.  Fifteen minutes later, we still didn't have our drinks.  Or water.  Or bread.  I was finally able to flag down a man who appeared to be delivering such items to other tables and asked if we could please have some water and bread.  He returned with water and a basket of four burned cinnamon rolls.  They were not a little brown, they were black on all sides.  I stopped our server, and showing him the burned rolls asked him if we could please have some fresh bread.  He said "Oh, we don't have any.  It's in the oven.  I'll bring some when it comes out."  He said he could go ahead and take our lunch order.  Sure - that would be great.  Drinks were delivered.  Starter salads were delivered.  Entrees arrived, but since the salad plates were never cleared, there was no place to set the entrees.  We had to stack them to make room for the server to set the entrée plates on the table, and there they remained.  Then the bread basket was delivered.  This time, it had three rolls.  We asked if we could please have three more rolls so that everyone at our table could have one.  "Oh, sure."  

Now, for the thanksgiving lunch we had all looked forward to.  Let's just say the broccoli was great and the French fries off of my 4 year-old's plate were good.  Everything else was so bad, we should have sent it back and left.  The mashed potatoes were cold and undercooked to the point that they were crunchy.  The "sausage stuffing" wasn't even stuffing - it was a gelatinous unidentifiable pile of goo.  Inedible.  The turkey, ham and salmon were barely edible.  We would have been better off eating the meal served at my grandfather's nursing home.  No one ever asked how were doing, how our meal was, or if we needed anything.  No one cleared our plates.  We got the check and were very sorry to see that an 18% tip was included.  We usually over-tip, but this was the one occasion where we could easily agree that any tip was too much.  
 
We were so disappointed in this experience that we've talked about it for days and no one can think of a more terrible meal.  We should have walked out.
author: Courtney D.

description:
I've been here a few times and the food has always been really good. I decided to try the shrimp filled baked potato as it was their special. I also ordered a cheesesteak figuring a baked potato wouldn't be that much but my waiter, Miguel, said it was pretty big and maybe I should order that one first and if I was still hungry order the second. 

He was on the money. It was a big portion and easily filled me up along with the side salad it came with. And it was packed with shrimp and cheesy goodness. An incredible dish and more than enough as a complete meal.

But I don't write this review based on the food (I had the 7 layer dessert which was also tremendous) but because of the service. I've been to Max's a few times and the service has always been great. I have watched other servers with customers and always going out of their way (the one a few tables down was working on his Spanish with some South American tourists and going out of his way to help them). 

Miguel was an incredible waiter. He could have just let me order the two plates and this possibly guaranteeing him a bigger tip due to a bigger sale, but instead looked out for my best interest. He was attentive and always there to make sure everything was alright and went above and beyond what most servers I have seen do. His service was better than most high end Vegas eateries I've been to. And I'm not saying Max's isn't up to those standards, but you wouldn't expect it and so it's a nice surprise. 

Kudos to Max's for their food, but special high praise for their service, especially Miguel!
author: Roger M.

description:
We used to eat here a lot before going to the opera. Used to be a very nice place to eat.  We went back last night after not having gone for about a year or more, and things have really changed there.

I could tell immediately when we walked in.  They have a display where they used to showcase their delicious desserts, but this time it was nearly empty...a few plates with pie slices on them but otherwise bare. Our hostess seated us by running to our table, slamming down the menus and running back to her post (honestly the place wasn't even busy so I didn't understand the rush). 

Someone else noted in their review that their table was sticky.  Ours too.  It felt pretty gross, actually.  Did not want to put my hands on that table...our glasses kept sticking to the table each time we took a sip of our water or wine. 

As for the food, I had the crab cake entree which I thought was fine.  My wife ordered the Mojito Skirt Steak. This is usually her go-to dish but this one was terrible. It was more like a pot roast than a skirt steak, it wasn't cooked right (we sent it back only to get a very slightly improved one), and it was covered in a gelatinous sweet sauce.  Gross. We did split the key lime pie for dessert and it was fine.  

Two stars for the decent service, the crab cake entree and dessert.  Probably not going here again, though.  Standards really took a dive at this place.  If you want Max's food, go to Burlingame or Stanford. Much nicer places. 

Oh, and I just saw the "poor health safety rating" notice that Yelp is currently displaying for this place. No wonder...
author: Steve C.

description: I like Max's as much as the next guy.they have a wide variety menu and I always love that. However, it's not fine dining. I got a cold turkey sandwich and a salad and it was good. The service was good and the place was very clean. However it's not a place I don't want to date, and it's a little bit too far from my work. I'd really need a good reason to return to Max's.
author: Sandra P.

description: The traditional thanksgiving burger. ;-) easy, good, friendly. Just fine for Thanksgiving orphans.
author: Richard A.

description:
A friend and I ate there at noon on 11/8 before the opera which is only 2 blocks away.  This was the last time I'll eat there.  Though the restaurant wasn't crowded at that time, the waiter was slow to acknowledge us, let alone visit our table, until I called him over.  My friend ordered her lunch but I said I was going to have a drink first -- he was perturbed.  I ordered a hot pastrami with Swiss cheese and a side of Russian dressing (a signature offering of Max's).
