We ordered mimosas ($3.75 each!) and they were promptly brought out, with the perfect amount of orange juice to champagne. Each of us ordered a 'build your own' omelette that came with potatoes and a delicious biscuit.
We thoroughly enjoyed the food, and the mimosas. We also thoroughly enjoyed our server, Mauricio, who was funny, fast, and nice, if not also super cute. 
Bottom line, the food, environment, and prices at Max's are superb and we are happy we came upon it in our travels to San Francisco. Oh, and Mauricio, you can find me on Yelp! ;)
author: Abbie H.

description:
It's obvious to us now that not all Max's are the same when it comes to food quality and quantity, even though they are franchise restaurants.  This is our third and definitely last time dining here.  

On the first visit, we ordered their signature chicken pot pie.  It arrived with 25% of the crust obviously burnt, yet the waiter served the dish anyway.  Needless to say, we asked for a replacement and, after some time, the waiter returned with what was obviously the old pie reassembled and this time with a smaller crust covering and less filling.  That was a major disappointment, but we decided to give them another chance.  

On our second visit, they were again not very good, as the pie lacked enough gravy to keep the chicken moist, so let's say it was like chicken pot "cookie."  We therefore decided against ordering the chicken pot pie on our third and final visit.    

I first have to say that we would not have ordinarily chosen Max (Van Ness) after the two dissatisfying dinners, but we had a show to attend that was close by and timing was essential.  This time however, we decided to order something different, as we figured the chicken pot pie would be another disappointment.  In its place, we ordered the overpriced (half slab for $19) ribs and tri-mushroom pasta.  

The pasta was tasty and similar to other Max restaurants, except the quantity appeared less.  As for the ribs, they were cooler than room temperature and the BBQ sauce was a last minute spread that was also not heated.  Worse yet, the meat did not fall off the bone as they should, so obviously undercooked.  There's something about having to use fork and knife to eat ribs that really did not sit well with good old BBQ food.

We won't be patronizing this place unless everything else close by is closed or too busy, and we do not have time to wait; otherwise, we'll continue to patronize Max's on GEARY BLVD instead where their chicken pot pie is consistently excellent, as well as there many other dishes that we tried.

One would think that the restaurant manager here at Van Ness would have concerns about the overall (under 3 stars) reviews, but guess he believes his is irreplaceable.
author: Anson D.

description: It was a fine meal for Max's.  Delicious pastrami, salmon not so good. But wonderful sides and  service that was great.
author: Virginia P.

description:
I haven't been to Max's Opera Café for many years. I decided to go there on a Saturday night with my husband and two other people.

I ordered the roasted turkey dinner ($16.99). Mydining companions ordered the "Special" Prime rib (12 oz.) - $26.99. I have to say we were very disappointed with the quality of the food. The turkey looks like the pre-packaged "sandwich" meat you can purchase at Safeway. It didn't taste very good. Also, the stuffing was in a "muffin" form and it was hard. 

The prime ribs were cooked to our "specifics". However, it was not USDA prime quality. The cut of meat had much tendons.

Perhaps, we just ordered the wrong items on the menu. But definitely, we will not return to Max's Opera Café for dining. I think the atmosphere of the restaurant is good. It is in a good location, walking proximity for people who is attending the Opera, Symphony, or other performances in the area. The food is not very good though.
author: P F.

description:
Unfortunate that they've got a great location.  The food is mediocre at best, but it's the bad management that's most amazing.

Waiters joking with each other while tables needed busing. The bus staff didn't seem to have bins and used small trays.  Many empty tables while customers waited 30+ minutes before evening performances.  

I've eaten at the other Max's and been mostly satisfied, but I may not bother with any again after this last experience.  A walk across the street to MacD would certainly have been quicker and probably tastier too.
author: T T.

description:
redundant

Been here too many times after the opera with old dates for their apple pie a la mode, served warm.

They are open late and the portions huge in the event the teeny boppers at Mels scares you away.

A good friend and I hit this late one evening when she came out to visit me and we ordered french fries, cake and numerous refills of coffee.  Our waiter was courteous in that he figured we were out gossiping about men, so he left us with our space.

I'd come back for a hamburger.  And french fries.
author: Miika M.

description:
"Eek! Methinks not." is correct! 

Let's just be honest here. I've eaten here a few times before and just good enough to come back. However, quality and service it keeps taking a downward plunge.

Me and my guest wanted lunch and in the Civic Center area so decided to go there. 
We were quickly seated and the waitress took our order. After that, we never saw here again, It took forever to get our lunch )brought by a food runner). The food came out incorrect and cold. It took so long to get our food, my egg yolks was over hard.

We flagged down another server to fetch our check. I think she went on vacation. 

I even wrote to the corporate office with my complaints and to this date, received no response. 

See ya, taking my dollars else where.
author: Geoff F.

description:
I have liked Max's in the past. I was excited to go there again and  we went on Sunday the 30th at 9:10pm. 
The doors were locked but there were clearly people who had just started looking at the menu, In addition to that the sign on the door said they were open until 10. A server finally came to the door and told us they were closed because "their systems were down" Ridiculous excuse! I have worked in the industry for over 10 years and there is no reason a restaurant should ever shut down based on the computers being down. You can take CC #'s and enter them in later. Write down orders for the kitchen, etc. I have done it, I know it is not hard to run a restaurant if the systems are down. Needless to say, that is horrible customer service. I will not be going there again.
author: Amy H.

description: Had a great dinner here after the symphony. We got there half an hour before our reservation and they were able to seat us right away. They have an extensive menu with something for everyone. We ordered the fish and chips, the hamburger Max, and the roasted vegetable and artichoke sandwich. All were delicious (and a LOT of food!). Most notable however was the service. Our waiter, Tony, was one of the nicest waiters I've had in a long time. He was so attentive and sweet and constantly made sure we had everything we needed. He truly made dining out fun as he appeared to really enjoy providing great service. We will definitely be back soon!
author: Jaime M.

description: I've been eating at Max's Opera Cafe for years especially before our Sunday SF Ballet matinee.  I usually order the Soup and Salad Combo----Russian Cabbage Soup with the Bistro Salad.  Today's lunch was a big disappointment.  The Russian Cabbage Soup was tasty as usual.  But the Bistro Salad was very skimpy----smaller in size, NO BACON, and bland.  It wasn't worth $15.00.  On the plus side---our server was very attentive.  There are quite a few good restaurants on Hayes Street.  It's time to give them a try.
author: Andrea P.

description:
II tried their Corned Beef Sandwich for the 1st time today since it's suppose to be their specialty.  I was NOT IMPRESSED AT ALL. 

For $12, I got a few thin slices of dry corned beef on stale, old rye bread. The sandwich was so dry, that with every bite, I had to wash it down with Diet Coke. They didn't even give me horseradish with it!  

WTF was I thinking coming here?!?!?!

To make matters worse, I thought I would be able to "grab and go" since I tried their online take-out order option. I really don't understand the purpose of this, as you still have to wait in line with other people placing/waiting for their orders. So, expect a 10-15 minute wait if you do this. A separate window should be created for "pick-up" orders only. 

I never noticed this before, but why do they place their sides and condiments (e.g. potato salad, coleslaw, pickles, etc) in the open in their hallway?  As people walk-by, they can sneeze and cough into it. YUCK!

Anyhoo, while I was waiting to pick-up my order, one of the servers was carrying a plastic bag, and the tip of the bag was touching the potato salad. And, as she moved a long, it touched the other sides/condiments.  Who knows where that plastic bag has been!

I should have taken my lazy butt to Tommy's...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Had a Reuben sandwich with pastrami. Two thumbs up!

Next day had a Pastrami sandwich. Two thumbs up!

The rye bread is fresh (must be baked on site).

Portions were generous and service good.
author: Harry S.

description: I used to go here for deserts afterdinner somewhere else, but finally went here for a sandwich and a salad.  Both were good and fresh.  My favorite is still going here for desert and really love the Macaroons.  They're huge and I always end up taking at least half home with me.  Service here has always been a bit of a mixed bag.  Great one time and slow the next.
author: Scott L.

description:
Absolutely terrible!!! 
We had the worst service. Our food took almost an hour for a really over priced ruben and then they forgot my side. My waiter was so bad I had to get up myself and serve our table.  When I asked for the manager to alleviate the situation she blamed me! And the food was not all that great. NEVER RETURNING!
author: M M.

description:
Went there after the Giant's World Series Parade and we were lucky to be one of the first ones there before the crowd hit. 

The service:
They were attentive at the beginning when taking our orders, but we had to repeatedly ask for refills on water and even asking them, it took them forever to get back to us.  I understand crowds were getting bigger and the place was getting packed, but don't neglect those who are sitting down! 

The food: 
I had the Crab Cake sandwich.  Bland!  The Crab Cake itself tasted like it was some frozen patty and it was thin.  It just tasted greasy.  The kids had mac n cheese and the all beef hotdog.  My niece said the hotdog was "thin" and it was very much so.  My brother had a sandwich which seemed alright.  Their potato salad had a funny taste to it and I wasn't so sure if it's the relish or it just went bad.

Overall: 
Meh, I can pass since the place can be pricey for diner food.
author: Meshell C.

description: OMG, this place is just horrible. We came here for a weekend brunch because we do not want to stand in line for amazing places. But hindsight, we should have!! The food is horrible. I ordered a ruben, the toast stinks! It's like it is about to go bad if not already. And they put this gross sause all over it, it just doens't go with it. Anyways, I felt like it's a dish that came from the trash. Don't go here.
author: Fung S. O.

description: Fanciful diner food. It's busiest if there happens to be a venue at the SF Symphony or Opera house. I really love their Jambalaya pasta and NY pastrami sandwich. They have some of the best fries here too - love that there are tons of different mustards at your disposal at each table. Love the large portions - there's always enough leftovers to take home.
author: Elaine W.

description:
One of my favorite meals in the cold and windy town of SF.  

It's comfort food in a comfort setting.  The menu is huge.  Excellent sandwiches.  Great crab cakes.   Large portions.  Good beer selection.  Not pretentious in a town where that is a very big problem. 

Great menu, good service, excellent location.  Five stars.
author: Paul C.

description: dont know why this place doesnt get at least 4 stars. find a better ruben anywhere. prices.not that bad for the size and ambience. Great clasic piano this night.. it may no longer be trendy but hell.w that. thewe places are rare these days. enjoy while u can
author: Burt K.

description:
The server and bartender need either retraining or to be replaced. Both guys either did not care to be there or are just plain lazy. Convenient location to lots of places we are visiting. Big menu to choose from but our waiter didn't check on us, we waited so long for the check - finally had to ask another waiter for it. (bad for business -- you could have had another table much faster. Our guy was just yaking about his tattoo.

Faster and nicer service needed. Checks delivered as soon as possible (don't clear the table when we just asked to pay -- can't you clear the plates after you get the check - that would help us the customer and it would ALSO help you get more tips and the restaurant get more hunger customers in.
author: John G.

description: What in the world happened to Max's ?  I will never go there again.  The service was hideous, some of the food had to be sent back to the kitchen - and I can get a better hamburger for half the price almost anywhere in the city.  No one waited on us, we had to get up ourselves and finally find a waiter, any waiter, after almost 20 minutes.  We had to ask numerous times for our water to be refilled, and he didn't collect the check until we asked twice.  It was like we were invisible.  Perhaps they're under new management ?  Don't waste your time or money, and certainly do not take out-of-town visitors there.  Seriously.  Go anywhere else.
author: Mary N.

description:
HORRIBLE!!! YOU WILL CRY!!!
Horrible service. We got ignored for most of the time. 
Menu prices are outrageous. And the menu choices...? A bunch of dishes that don't strike the fancy. 
The nachos were nothing like nachos. I guess you shouldn't order nachos at a diner by the SF Opera. 
Never going back!! EVER!
author: joanna r.

description:
Okay so Max's has great food I can admit that but the service is kinda terrible. I go there to get desert every time I have a dance recital. The deserts are crazy good and so is the chicken matzo ball soup. The service is the worst part. Once my sister left her video camera there and we hadn't relized it until we were at home. We called and they kept putting us on hold. The food takes like thirty minutes to get to you. Once we asked for a container and they totally forgot so we had to go to the counter. They also forget every thing and you have to ask at least three times.







                                             -Nikki
author: Nikki Y.

description: I've been going to Max's for over 20 years and it's my neighborhood comfort restaurant. You have to know what to order though, and I'm glad that I do. Big flavorful salads, wraps and tasty burgers. I also like the potato pancakes, sliders and three mushroom fettuccine. One of my favorites was the roasted chicken with a big heap of mashed potatoes, but their entrees are now limited, which is disappointing. Large portions and good service (when they're not busy) and there's a take-out counter. Don't care for their potato salad, but I like their coleslaw. Quality of cocktails can be a bit inconsistent.
author: Larry K.

description:
Sorry Max. but your place is just going downhill.
First, at the end of the meal, there was no card asking for suggestions or critiques. If there had been, I would have made some suggestions privately. But now I'll do it in this forum

1. Servers really need more training. Go to Houston's to see how great the service is because of the training. After my meal, the waiter did not clean up any of the mess on the table and just removed the main plate and set down the desert. Very unappetizing. And what ever happened to the singing waiters?

2. Food quality is going down. I know that deli was the best food to order at Max's but I ordered ginger chicken. Plum sauce was strong and nearly uneditable. Chicken dish was not as good as any chinese or thai restaurant.
But the worst was the pumpkin pie with whipped cream. The crust was soggy and about 3/8 inch thick! And the pie filling was only about 1/2" thick. It was like soggy crust with a little pumpkin smear. Fake whipped cream.
author: James H.

description:
Love love love Max's. Great atmosphere, delicious food,  drinks well mixed, and UNBELIEVABLE live performance. Seriously, I don't understand why all these hot men are waiting on the tables, when they clearly should be singing  Figaro at Bolshoi. 

Make sure to try their pear salad while you there. Like an orgasm in your mouth
author: Yuliya G.

description: I haven't been this disappointed in a meal in a very long time. This restaurant would be right at home in rural Pennsylvania if the prices were cheaper. Yuck.  I had the luis salad. Nothing about it was redeemable. The shrimp was like the cheapest you could find, brocoli reminded me of the snacks in elementary school, lettuce wasn't crisp. Really just gross for 18 dollars!? The soup of the day is $8 and also very basic, diner style stuff. You're going to pay the same prices at Max's as you would at a very nice restaurant, like 03 down the street, but get Mel's quality food. The menu is huge (always a red flag), not as huge as cheesecake factory - which by the way is much better, if that says anything. The piano player was not very good either - very average show-tunes on a blown out speaker.  You know, I hate to disparage my fellow yelpers ,but if you look at the profiles of the folks giving this place 4 stars, you'll see they mostly review diners and places like home depot. This place is just sad.
author: Mark S.

description:
I have been here several times. The food is not really worth the price--$16-$23 for an okay-sized, okay-tasting entree. I kind of want to bump it up a star because we had our first date at the bar here, but this place is a solid 3. However, this is the place to be if you want to hear your waiter sing opera.

Try the blood orange martini! (Also pricey but damn delicious.)
author: Dante and Alleliah G.

description: Went here last night at 6:00 p.m. The place was not crowded but by the time we left it was packed. Service was very good. I had the sweet and sour spinach salad with chicken that was really good, although the chicken was fairly dry. My husband had the pork chop. It was ok, but nothing great. He also had the hot fudge sundae that tasted more like chocolate sauce than hot fudge. The best thing about Max's is that it is so close to Davies Hall. We gave up quality of food for convenience of distance. Next time we go to the Hall we will probably allow more time and go to a better restaurant.
author: Carole L.

description:
I like the location.  

I love their lemonade.

A fan of their specialty sandwiches, whether it's the pastrami, grilled three-cheeses or crabcake...drool!   And I love how their specials are always so different, and sometimes seasonal.   It's very American fare, but better than Mel's, and they get points for having the specialty items!  Hey, they try!

You've been warned: Service can be pretty bad, when they slammed!  Otherwise, they are friendly and helpful!  Absolute diner feel.  

I have a preference for having lunch there...just like that kind of food for lunch moreso than dinner.  And I always have leftovers. 

I actually would not recommend this place for desserts--very disappointing, and too sweet for me.  Just go to Safeway and buy the white sheet cake, m'kay?
author: Fannie S.

description: Ginormous portions! Geez, you don't need to order an appetizer because the amount of food they give you with an entree can feed two people. I got a skirt steak sandwich with a cucumber salad. The cucumber salad wasn't that great but the skirt steak was delicious. Also, the other food choices were delicious as well. I had a sample of my friend's matzo ball soup. Let me tell you, if I were feeling ill, it would have cured me because it is quite tasty. This place is somewhat on the pricier side, but the prices do match the portions that they give you so if you don't finish, you should box it up and take it home as an additional meal.
author: Alan K.

description:
We went here before the opera on Sunday noon. Had a very nice table in the bar area. Max's has influences of a Kosher Deli with lots of great sandwiches. I had the Russian cabbage soup which was excellent. Then a Greek salad--I've had better, but it wasn't bad. Service was delightful, as was the atmosphere. I've eaten here once before on pride day. We had a good size party and we were no longer sober. Had a great meal and the great wait staff but us with our boisterous style.

One interesting note: the restaurant has to provide any staff working 10h or more some type of health insurance or subsidy. For that they add a 5+% surcharge to your tab. I don't mind. I think everyone should have healthcare.  (I'll be losing mine at the end of the month because of my gender. But that's another story.)
author: Nobbi L.

description: I've had many good meals from Max's, but we just had a truly dreadful brisket plate and was really disappointed.
author: Sanford S.

description:
I like the ambiance and the service is good. But the prices are a bit high. Whenever I go to a place like this I try to find the item or specialty that is worth the price. Or something on the menu that I do not see often anywhere else. 

I did discover that Max's has a happy hour. And, if you want to save a bit of money and get some value, go at happy hour and order from the appetizer menu. That I think is the better deal. That is what I will do next time.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
Although I discovered Max's serves decent sliders and a pretty good clam chowder, the service was subpar today.  At Max's establishments, there is a list of Laws the staff is not supposed to break.  At least three of them were broken today.  

It started with the burger sliders which were described on the menu as coming with crispy onion strings.  When the sliders arrived, they were draped with RAW dehydrated wilty red onion strings.  My friend and I were confused because the red onions sure as heck didn't look fried.  This was when Law #16 was broken, because the server is supposed to check-in with us within four minutes of serving the entrees.  So... the one time something is wrong, I couldn't locate anyone on the staff to tell.  I decided to ask the girl serving water if the red onions were the crispy onion strings and she stared at me like I was speaking Martian and said "I don't know" and walked away without a look back.  A few minutes later, I managed to flag down our waitress to ask the same question.  Apparently, she didn't know either, because she ended up taking our dish away to the kitchen and mumbled something about the kitchen possibly having run out of crispy onion strings.  Huh?  If that was the case, shouldn't she have told us in the first place so we could have ordered something else? Who knowingly serves an incorrect dish?  (Now I am channeling Kitchen Nightmares.)  When she brought our plate of sliders back, she told us that they had been served the "old way" (whatever that means) and that a plate of crispy onion strings was on the way.  "I just work here" should be Max's new motto. 

The manager finally delivered the onion strings and explained that the cook had plated our sliders incorrectly since the menu has changed.  I eat out A LOT and have never had this happen to me before.  It is just plain sloppy workmanship.  By now the sliders were cold.  Around this time, Law #13 was broken.  The ketchup was supposed to come before the sliders, but no one thought to bring it until the missing crispy onion strings arrived.  

To add insult to injury, we left $40 for a check totaling $20.66.  The waitress asked if we wanted change.  DUH!   She broke Law #17 by merely asking if we wanted change.  For each of the broken laws we were supposed to get a slice of Niagara Falls cake for the table.  Without the laws in front of us, we didn't know to bring it up. We confirmed these laws on the website when researching a promotion we previously saw online at their site called "10-15-20".  The restaurant told us the promotion was posted on the webpage by the "old owner" so I guess that means they weren't honoring it?  The experience was so odd, it warrants a letter to the manager because I like Max's and I want to help them improve.
author: Jeannette W.

description:
This place is really strange. I've been coming for lunch for years because my 70-something boss has a frequent diner club card.  Even though he has absolutely no idea what it gets him or how it works.  I think the real reason is that its the only place he feels comfortable, with other 70-somethings.  Which is precisely why I feel UNcomfortable here.  

The menu is really extensive but strange.  Sometime in the past few months they put a vegetarian baked potato with vegetables on the menu, but it comes with a Cesar salad, and YES there are anchovies in the dressing.  Tell me on what planet does that make sense?!  The baked potato itself is one of those "twice baked" dealies where they bake it, scoop out all the potato, mix it with some strange combination of steamed and most likely previously frozen vegetables, whip it real good, then put it back into the skin.  Apparently there's no cheese in it, but there must be some source of creaminess.  I think my waitress just didn't care to ask the kitchen. 

 I can always find something here to eat, but its usually something pretty lame.  Like hearts of iceberg which is the wonder bread of the vegetable world.   If I had a choice, I wouldn't go here and when I do go here, its because I have no choice.
author: Molly B.

description:
3 stars for closing at 11pm on a Saturday night when they are located 2 blocks from the Opera. 

I wanted my 3 layer chocolate cake. 

I am not sure why they don't stay open until 12:30 am for everyone leaving the Opera AND Symphony tonight. 

bad bad bad bad. Other than that, I enjoy Max's.
author: Katherine B.

description:
It was peak time when we went and the host was less than welcoming...not off to a great start. A 30 min seating wait did allow for me to drool over the desserts...more on that later. 

Shrimp cocktail had a decent amount of succulent morsels, but anyone can open a bag of cooked shrimp and throw out come cocktail sauce. Bistro salad was ok. Steak was good---topped with VILE fried onions--and I'm NEVER one to turn my nose up at fried foods. EVER. They were stale, cold, and I'm wondering if they left out the onions? Cold, thick creamed spinach. 

Ok, so why 3 stars? The Reuben!! The sauce really does run down your hands! That won me over...a bit fatty though.

There's 5.4% "benefits" charge added to your bill in addition to sales tax (almost 10% these days) and then a 15-20% tip ? Well...you do the math. 

I did have another Reuben at Mel's Diner for $5 less (not including Max's added charges!!) and dare I say it--it was comparable. 

The desserts however looked quite delicious, but I wasn't wearing my elasticized pants at the time so I reluctantly passed on that round.
author: Maggie C.

description:
We went here to eat before going to the symphony on Saturday night. My Mom and Dad both had the prime rib special which was average. 

One thing at Max's is that you can actually get a baked potato!  In San Francisco? Unheard of!

The sour dough rolls are good, but a little tough on the outside. The pianist is a very nice, classy touch!
author: Finnegan M.

description:
I've had their food twice now, still deserves only one star. 

The first time I ordered, it was a veggie 'burger'.  Ummm I was better off eating red meat. It was disgustingly greasy and the ciabatta bread for a burger? that was uncalled for! that was hard to swallow.......no really it was hard to chew and swallow. I like Ciabatta bread, but it was simply too much bread, to hard, too doughy, and hard to hold while eating. Everything was sliding out, I felt like a 3 year old eating a massive size burger mess and all. 
I'll all for BIG stuff and large servings, but this just didn't taste good or go well. Who would have thought ordering a burger would come on ciabatta bread; that was upsetting. 


Today, I'm suffering from stomach cramps and I have the trash can next to me. I'm seriously considering going home sick. 
 I'm sure it was a complete misunderstanding, I was given enough oil to keep a high volume KFC in business for 2 days. 

I ordered a veggie sandwich this time and again it came in another ciabatta (this one was specified in the menu but I overlooked it), and wtf why another ciabbatta?! ugh, not happy but I still hate my food. 

Every bite I took, had an ocean of oil gush into my mouth. I dismissed it, and said it was probably the fried onion onion strings in it. Then another gush of oil, I opened my sandwich up and noticed there was cheese, ok another reason for it to be oily...... so much for trying to stay away from fatty foods like red meat.  I'm beginning to get a little grossed out so I open my sandwich up again and start dissecting it. I find Spinach drenched in you guessed it oil, the ciabatta is falling apart because its a complete mush drenched in oil. Artichoke hearts bathed in oil, sauteed onions floating in oil, I couldn't take another bite. My gag reflex had had enough and it wasn't going to warn me anymore. I gave up after realizing I had to wipe my face and chin after every bite. Warm oil dripping down your chin looks cute! 

Funny/ disgusting part: 
remember those HOT summer days as a kid eating watermelon and the juice would drip down your arms to your elbow? yeah picture warm OIL dripping down to your elbows from this disgusting oil drenched ciabatta. 

french fries are large steak fries.........they're forgettable.
author: Anna P.

description:
I usually order my Salmon Pasta from this place.
Pretty pricey ($19.00)  for their ok-quality food
Service is okay~good

I would rather go to the nearby CPK for pasta dish  :)
author: Anna N.

description: My husband and I always go to Max's Opera Cafe before the Symphony on Friday nights. It's consistently good, the service is friendly and attentive, and the extensive menu covers everything from salads to sandwiches to entrees of beef, chicken, fresh fish, and vegetarian choices. Although it's not a negative, the servings are more than ample, so two people can share a salad or entree if a lighter meal is in order.
author: kathleen f.

description: We were at the San Francisco symphony recently and some of our friends invited us to Max's. The location was great as it is pretty close to symphony hall. We ordered roast beef sandwitch, pastas and jambalaya. The food was O.K. We also ordered vanilla ice cream for desert. The service was fast. The dishes were priced reasonably low for San Francisco. I would go back to this place if I was around in the neighborhood.
author: Raman S.

description: Sunday Brunch in a corner street Dinner. Very amazing desserts! and the portions are large. Matzo ball soup and half pastrami sandwich is really good. Service is on auto pilot but I don't mind that as long as it gets done. You want to leave satisfied? With these plates it's guaranteed.
author: Charlene K.

description:
After spending 4 months on jury duty service, the jurors wanted to get together for one last luncheon. We had to find a location that could seat 25 comfortably.  To my surprise the restaurant was fairly empty for noon, but then it has been awhile since I've eaten here.  The menu is extensive and their portions are huge.  It took me about 5 min to go through everything.  Prices could be lowered and portions reduced. The majority of the dishes range from $10-$15. I was hoping to see half size salads.  

-Scrambled Eggs with Corned Beef.  3 potato pancakes ($11.99)
-Pink Lemonade
author: Stacey L.

description:
Much improved service.  W0W woW Wow weeee!!
The waitestaff actually care!!!!! Was there with out of towners  originally from Brazil who sang "The Girl From Ipanema" Food was excellent. After a night of Zumba-ing, it was fantastic!!!!!! Really happy now!!! Gastro-orgasmic experience. Nap time!!!  I've concluded that it can be hit or miss depending on the # of customers. 
I'm convinced they have redeemed themselves!!
author: Jboogie X.

description:
Very reliable. 
Big servings of good food at a good price.
Great place to dine - lunch or dinner - with visiting family.
Very good service.
Open late.
author: Jono H.

description: This is my 3rd time eating at Max's. but this time I was disappointed.  The host who gave us a table wanted us to seat in a booth or the other option she gave was a lonely corner table at the corner that was separated by the rest of the restaurant. I refused her suggestions and asked her more comfortable one because I am in a wheelchair.  She seemed to not know how to seat a customer that happens in a wheelchair. Then when we ordered our food and the waiter who took the order and gave my guess the wrong order, so my guest waited for his correct to come out while we had our plates in front us.
author: N. L.

description: Went here recently for my mom's 80th birthday and didn't have a good experience.  There were 9 of us and we were put in a corner in the back and received very poor and somewhat rude service.  We had to ask for things twice and some things never came so we just made sure they didn't bill us for the missing things.  Food was average but not especially fresh and tasty.  I have been coming here with smaller parties for over 20 years with much better service and food so I'm wondering what happened.  I might give them one more chance and then skip them in the future.  We gave them the standard required tip but probably should have asked them to take that off the tab.  We didn't because we just wanted to get out of there.
author: Mark L.

description:
Delicious! I highly recommend Max's because the food is heavenly. Here are my ratings/reviews for all the food that I have eaten here. 

Prime Rib and Creamed Spinach - 5/5 Stars!

The prime rib was extremely tender, just the way I like it. It was accompanied excellently with the creamed spinach which had a nice tang of cream.  


Dungeness Crab Cakes - 5/5 Stars!

Exquisite! Hands down my favorite food on the menu. The inside of the crab cakes are superb. The combination of the juicy crab with the crunchy crab shell is just sensational. The crab cakes are hard to beat..


Caesar Salad - 4/5 Stars

4/5 stars is not bad for one of my favorite salads. I am a caesar salad lover and its hard to impress me. The dressing and croutons were decent although the dressing could be a tad bit richer with a bit more dijon mustard or worcestershire sauce. That combined with maybe a bit fresher romaine lettuce leaves and it would certainly bring it up to 5 stars. 


Chicken Caesar Wrap - 3/5 Stars

Not bad. It's a convenient food that you can take on the run and its pretty tasty. The only thing is that it's a little heavy on the sauce. If they just put a little less sauce on it, it would be perfect!


Chicken Liver - 3/5 Stars

Tasted just the way I thought. Some people love it and can eat it by the spoon. Me personally, I am not a huge fan but its typical of chicken liver anywhere else. It's just not my cup of tea.


Omelette - 4/5 Stars

I came here for breakfast once and I got the omelette with mushrooms, spinach, tomatoes, and a side of chicken sausage. It was decent and I would definitely recommend coming here for breakfast. It's also perfect for hangovers :)


Matzah Ball Soup - 3/5 Stars

I know people that go crazy over this and love it to death. Nothing too special about it except its great on a cold day. 


Lamb Burger - 5/5 Stars!

Lamb... so yummy. Enough said..


Ahi Tuna - 4/5 Stars

Ahi Tuna, I almost forgot! It was crusted and seasoned with sesame which had a nice tangy spike to it. I personally thought the ahi tuna was very tender which is great.


Grandma's Honey Chicken - 5/5 Stars!

One of my top 3 favorites. This meal was perfect. The glazed honey sauce contrasting with the tender seasoned chicken was divine.. I would highly recommend this!



Overall, I've had great experiences with Max's. Dungenes crab cakes takes the cake for being top-notch. The crispness of the crab cake is potent and unmatched. The servers are extremely friendly and the vibe is nice. Can't wait to come again!
author: Brian W.

description: I have been a customer of Max's for a number of years both t their California Street location and their Opera Plaza location. I moved out of the City a few years ago but just picked up a job working in the City a couple of days a week. A few weeks ago I went into Max's and asked for a brisket sandwich on a French roll. When I got back to work, the girl had made my sandwich on wheat bread and it fell apart on the floor as I was unwrapping it. That was a waste of $10. I went back the following week and asked for a matzo ball soup which I love. I got the soup but with cinnamon bread instead of sour dough bread. Today, I went in for a brisket sandwich. I placed my order with the girl behind the counter. She took my order then went back to doing inventory or something on the computer. I am on my lunch hour and do not have a lot of time to wait. A waiters on wheels person came to pick up an order and she was ignored as well. I said to the waiters on wheels person (loud enough for the employee to hear) that I was pressed on time. The employee continued to ignore me and do whatever she was doing. I turned around and left. She never tried to call me or to apologize or to even ask why I was leaving. Never again. You lost a customer of at least 20 years. Their prices are high and their service certainly went down. I do not need to be giving them any more of my money. There are a lot of restaurants in this area that appreciates my business more.
author: Khalil K.

description:
I have lived in the Bay Area for 17 years.  I know better than to eat at Max's Opera Cafe - BUT in a pinch on the way to the ballet, I and my partner and daughter stopped in for lunch.  Oh my - what a mistake.  Server was absolutely checked out.  I think she must have had a sore throat because she barely spoke a few words.  

When we asked if our food was forthcoming, she said "oh yeah, it's been up in the window for awhile."  Really???  

When it was delivered by the manager, it was cold.  And when we asked "why are the wings coming with the entrees when they should be an appetizer" he said "nope - all together".  

I really don't think that I have had a meal or service that bad in many, many years. Of course living in the Wine Country and the Bay Area for years we are spoiled, but it all begs the question "How in the world has this place stayed in business for so long????"
author: Ursula Z.

description:
I used to go to Max's ALL the time...I brought friends frequently whenever we had something to celebrate (every night of the week there were long lines until just before closing:not any more) EVERYTHING IN THE PAST WAS GOOD to excellent ..not in recent history
Every place goes through changes....however this evening had to be amongst the MOST DISAPPOINTING NON-MEALS OUT I EVER HAD.
THE waitstaff was attentive.  But honestly I went into the restaurant to eat a hot comfort meal.
There are large signs above the kitchen  extolling their way of doing things.  One thing I noticed was that in foot high letters "bragged" about how crusty the bread was.  IT WAS NOT (first disappointment) That sign said: it was soft on the  INSIDE and eat the inside if you want it soft.  The bread (which I ate because I was/and ;eft same) soft on the outside and inside..not crusty of which I recall in the near past ... (it may have been warmed for 30 seconds in the microwave as well=nasty!
The honey roasted chicken and mashed potatoes arrived...one degree above refrigerator.  Potatoes and chicken same under warmed temperature...so it was obvious that it was put in microwave......nasty...When the waiter asked ""Is everything all right?", I said no and explained a good 15 minutes went by before the waiter came back to tell me they were out of chicken!  This is the only protein I eat and I needed protein...I did not want a meal only of cars...He offered it for free if I didn't mind it being warmed again in the microwave.  THIS DID NOT APPEAL TO ME.  I was thinking of the makings of a salad that was sitting in my refrigerator.  I KNEW ALL THE INGREDIENTS were carefully curated (unlike MAX.s who forgot that people eat out because it's prepared BETTER than at home (DON"T COUNT ON IT.
I DECLINED THE OFFER realizig there was nothing else on the menu that I would eat.
IT APPEARS THE COOKS MUST BE ON DRUGS AND DRINKING HARD....anyone who  takes any pride in their cooking would not allow the microwave to be used as anything more than an accessory.
BTW, the man at the next table also had a problem with his food AND HE claimed that he has had to send food back for being cold before.  HUH?
There are plenty of corporate restaurants in the city that cater to customer....MAX's ambiance it nice...but the food is just plain disgusting.....
NOT A PLACE TO GO IF YOU ARE INTERESTED IN GETTING A GOOD MEAL.  AND DON't BRING FOODIE FRIENDS (THEY will never forgive you!!!)
author: Minnie M.

description: I love their food so yummy!
author: Nola P.

description:
A popular spot to go to prior to seeing the opera or the symphony, Max is traditional pretentious romantic San Franciscan charm at its finest and it will win over your heart to a certain extent.

With a pianist playing jazzy versions of Billy Joel's "Don't Go Changin (to try and please me....)" you are served by the waiters and waitresses who actually perform and sing.  That's an interesting perk.  But as you all know, singers are often primadonnas which means that there is a risk of emotionally unstable service.  Although I can report that this wasn't the case, the service was very slow even after we warned them we had an 8pm opera to see.  Could our server have been more concerned about hitting a certain note for a song than the status of our order?

The food was not bad.  The prime rib was excellent, and the desserts are gigantic.  One order is enough for three people.

The seating for the most part is too tight unless you get lucky and get a booth, which there are a few.

The menu selection is extensive.  Be warned that most servings are large enough for two people.   Also be warned not to commit to a favorite dish.  I loved a certain lasagna dish and it is no longer on the menu.

If you have a show at 8pm, do not go to Max's Opera Cafe unless you can get there at 6pm.  Otherwise, you will not be able to enjoy its relaxing, slick ambience.
author: Tony U.

description:
One heck of a pastrami sandwich....!

My grandmother used to rave about this place.  I can see why.  The food is good--portions generous and quality very good.

Good lunch spot.
author: L C.

description:
A friend and I visited Max's on a super cold, rainy night for a cocktail while we waited for some of our friend's to come around.  I was very pleased with my experience and would definitely come back.

The drinks: Stiff, cold, well-mixed.. one of the only well-made "Old Fashioned"s I've had in the city.  

The service: WONDERFUL.  The very red-headed server was really fantastic, made some great suggestions and made sure we were always taken care of.  Highly recommended. 

The atmosphere: Dated, but charming.  Loved the live music!
author: Clair B.

description: We stopped in for a quick meal before the opera.  I went the non-deli way with a meal of roast chicken, roast zucchini and lentils.  The food was okay.  For a real treat try Max's deli fare.  It's one of the few places in the Bay Area to get anything approaching deli food.  In that department I would rate it 4 stars.
author: Stuart B.

description: A good place for dessert and a drink.  The weekends feature live music to enjoy in this newly remodeled bar area.  I had a great late harvest zin an dthe desserts were great.
author: Veda F.

description: Great place to grab a bite to eat before the Symphony or Opera, complete with their own piano and singers (that may double as your waiter/waitress). If you haven't been here and can't decide what sandwich to get you MUST try their Max's Famour Reuben Sandwich. Their corned beef and pastrami is packed with flavor and you can get a mix of both if you really can't decide. It's a big sandwich, so come with an appetite and comes complete with warm swiss cheese and sauerkraut. And their fries trumps their potato salad hands down, so order your sandwich with fries!
author: Andrew S.

description:
*Haven't even eaten here yet, BUT... 
FOUR STARS FOR A HILARIOUSLY AWFUL WEBSITE!

I was going to share additional hilarious website details, but all the animations were making me ill.

http://www.maxsworld.com/maxs/locations.php?Id=11
author: Nathan C.

description: There's a lot to like about maxs and some left to be desired. I'm always happy with the Rueben sandwich and the deserts are pretty awesome.  Service can be good or really bad. I suppose it just depends on who you get.  The interior of pretty much all of their restaurants needs help. But that doesn't keep me from going back.
author: Troy H.

description: Had a recommendation from a friend to go here. We decided last minute to try it. Came in, got seated , ordered, and the food cam out very quickly. I had the mojito skirt steak. WOW. Very good flavor, and the veggies and potatoes also were good. However my girlfriend Ordered the ground sirloin with Brie. That was not real good.
author: Chris L.

description: The carpet is falling apart, the chairs are worn, the table was sticky, the food is just ok, but the service was excellent. Chopped green onions are NOT chives. Mediocre dinner for two w one appetizer, 2 glasses of wine, 2entrees and dessert=$92 plus tip. Not worth it when SF is full of excellent restaurants.
author: Kate M.

description: Drinks after the opera, Sunday brunch, or gigantic sandwiches.  Nothing special for food but the waiter/singers make it enjoyable.. FYI the mini sandwiches are large enough for almost anyone.
author: David J.

description: I took an important client to dinner, and things started out shaky when the server could not answer simple questions about our drink options. The food was mixed; delicious chop with inedible mashed potatoes, for example. The issue of incompetence came when paying the bill. The server returned to the table and announced loudly, "your credit card was declined". Not only was this without class and courtesy, it was embarrassing to my company in front of my client...as well as in front of the tables around us who obviously heard him. The same thing happened with the second and THIRD credit cards, and the server was even more rude saying, "your cards are no good," with a manner clearly expressing frustration with ME. I phoned the card issuer from the table and was told that no charges had been attempted. After asking to see the terminal printout, I saw it clearly stated "modem error, unable to connect". The server, or cashier, or whoever...was incompetent, and the server was not trained in proper etiquette for handling such situations -- making the customer and his guest feel embarrassed, insulted, and mistreated. I will not return.
author: Aaron B.

description: OK, the cheesecakes are pretty good, but my question to this business is: do you want business at all? Why don't you keep your doors open for your listed business hours? What's the point of business hours if you close early? I was there at 9:45pm the other night, a full 15 minutes before the supposed closing time. The place was quite full otherwise. Locked. What's up with that?
author: Bruce C.

description:
2 stars for the convenience. It would've been 1, but the OTT singing from the servers boosted it up to 2. It was LOL worthy and entertaining.

I got a salad here...and the lettuce is what would've made this a 1 star review. Lettuce was old - like slimy and starting to turn colors. I know from experience that when that happens, the lettuce has been sitting for at least 5 days. Either that or their supplier doesn't give them the freshest of produce. Either way, as I was eating through my second salad (first one I sent back) that was fractionally better than the first, I had a perfect view of McDonald's and Chevy's. I should've gone to either of those instead of paying $18 for a chicken caesar salad.

Why do they have to douse everything liberally with celery salt?!
author: Carina M.

description: I have been coming here for years (earliest I can remember was when I was 8). Most recently was for dessert after seeing The Nutcracker. The dessert was amazing as per usual, but the service was horrible. They definitely did not have enough staff on for a Friday night. I will still go there for the wonderful desserts, but maybe just not as late as this last time.
author: Eva M.

description:
i haven't been to Max"s for a long time but used to love it... not anymore.  i ordered a cornedbeef with swiss to go.
no dark or marlbed rye available - this is a Tuesday not Monday before deliveries.
got home - no swiss
the cole slaw side was the size of extra mayo container
the to go menu includes a drink - i got to the door and realized no drink was in the bag.
author: anne k.

description: I ordered crab cakes with warm slaw and mushrooms. My date ordered chicken piccata. We shared a beet salad, which was swimming in oil and so salty I gave up on it. If my crab cakes ever saw a crab, it was because one walked by the kitchen. They were mealy and tasteless, so I left two out of three on the plate. Like the beet salad, the warm slaw was drenched in oil. I had to ask for the mushrooms because they were omitted. When they arrived it was obvious they were straight from a can. Terrible. My date liked his chicken piccata, so that's why I gave it two stars. If I based this on my meal alone, they'd get no stars at all. The service was attentive and prompt, and the coffee afterwards was first-rate. This meal was an expensive disaster. We're not coming back.
author: Annie M.

description: The service was very good and the food is always consistent. I have never had the best meal of my life here, but I have never had a bad meal either. The piano playing added just the right ambiance to our Valentine Dinner.
author: Rick L.

description: Happy hour supposedly goes until 6.  Went in around 5:30 the other night with 3 co-workers just for drinks.  Wasn't an opera or symphony or theater night because the place was empty.  We sat in one of the tables off the bar (2 of maybe 15 tables were occupied)--after being told it was fine for us to sit at a table just for drinks.  Waiter came to take our orders and I asked what the happy hour specials were.  He said we could only avail ourselves of happy hour if we were sitting at the bar, in one of maybe 12 bar stools (there weren't 4 stools together even had we been willing to sit there).  So they have a happy hour, but basically only about 12 people can take advantage of it.  That's bullshit.
author: Chuck P.

description:
Came here prior to attending "Wicked" at Orpheum Theatre despite the distance, as no decent restaurants were nearby there.  It turned out to be a good choice.  The place was busy, but we got seated within 15 minutes.  There is a full liquor bar where you can sit and wait for your table.

The interior is a bit of retro, but not that horrendous.  As most of diners are attending performing art events nearby, you see many who are dressed up nicely, who appear to be in their 50's & 60's.  It's a casual restaurant, but catering to a higher end.

We weren't that hungry, so we shared; Herb Roasted Turkey Breast & Stuffing, and Niagara cake.  There were many items that I'd like to try next.  I'll definitely come back when I'm attending performing art events nearby.
author: Kioko O.

description: What a huge disappointment. I ate here fairly often 15-20 years ago but hadn't been back until tonight. Everything over cooked, greasy and bland. Denny's is better. The calamari used to be so good. The $27 Dungeness crab cakes were worse than Stouffer's frozen brand. Red snapper grossly over cooked. They should close out of embarrassment. This is San Francisco AND you had a reputation. Not any more - never going back.
author: Tim K. M.

description: No home fries available with breakfast? Why not? They used to be. This restaurant seems to be pursuing mediocrity.
author: Richard M.

description:
Yah it's a tourist trap. So what? You're probably from Iowa too; you just lost the denim shorts and the United We Stand shirt. 

I love getting a glass of bubbly at the bar and making conversation with all the regulars before the ballet or opera. The suave older gentlemen really know how to compliment a lady and they always make my night.

Food's not bad but that's not why I go. They do have this side salad with fresh shucked white corn and dill potatoes over field greens. Pretty good for a diner with a chandelier and grand piano. 

The servers are hit or miss so I ALWAYS sit at the bar which I've already mentioned. It's best to go to places like Max's and hang out with hokey older people. Life lessons should come from people who have lived if you know what i mean.
author: dr S.

description: Yay for the new happy hour deals! You can only eat the happy hour food at the bar so be sure to get there early and secure your seat. The drinks are alright. They did the job. I ordered a peach margarita ($6) and it was pleasantly strong. We also ordered some food, all of which were $6. We got the angus sliders (2), portabello mushroom fries (loved this!), and potato skins (pretty average). My coworkers also got the clams (pretty good), the quesadilla (small-ish portion but comes with salsa/guac/sour cream), and the veggie & spinach dip platter (skimpy portions). The food is pretty decent and it's so close to work that I'd probably come back again for the happy hour. Otherwise it's just OK.
author: Sannie L.

description: Quite possibly the most foul tasting Reuben sandwich I've ever tried. The meat was just awful. Same applies to the fettuccini pasta with chicken. One of the more disappointing meals I've had in recent memory. I will say that the thousand island sauce and fries were good.
author: Daniel P.

description: I always feel super disgusting after I eat here.  I eat a lot of fried, buttered, and fatty food.  Every time I eat here I feel like I ate all of those things in one dish.  The quality of the food has been getting worse since I first tried this place back in 2004.  Its like an upscale Dennys.
author: Fatty A.

description:
Max's Opera Café
San Francisco, few blocks from the Opera House
Great for pre-performance meals or post-performance desserts
Love the house bread
Great salads e.g., beet
Nice pasta dishes.
Too many choices!
Good wine by the glass
Good food service
Decadent desserts
author: Rosquete B.

description: Wonderful piano player. Ok food. Horrible waiter named Monte who did not want to split the bill and rushed us through the meal. Sorry you had things to do, Monte, but we were paying for a decent meal....
author: Desiree C.

description: Took my mom here for lunch. I lived in the city when the place opened and it seemed good then, not so much anymore.  The food was just Okay if not a bit disappointing (We believe that the burgers were precooked and then reheated), our server seemed harried although the place was not full.
author: John M.

description: I'm sad to say that I can only give Max's Opera Cafe two stars right now. We hadn't been to this location for awhile so we were in the neighborhood and thought it would be a good choice.  It was about 10p by the time we walked in and we were surprised to see the place was pretty empty--not a good sign on a Saturday night.  The host didn't acknowledge us because she was too busy talking with her co-workers. Strike one. Once we were seated, we were given menus that were dirty. Strike two. The server was very nice, however, and attentive. We ordered our food and it came out relatively fast but it was disappointing. Strike three.  What it looks like is this location has deteriorated, unfortunately, which is a shame. Hopefully, the Geary Street location is still good because we've always liked Max's.  Right now, I don't see us returning to this location.  Sorry.
author: Rabbit B.

description:
My family and I came to Max's on 12/23 for lunch prior to a show at the opera. We called the week before for a reservation for 10 and were given a noon time: great, our show is at 2 that gives us an hour and a half. 
We arrived at 5 to noon and were dismayed to have to stand in a line to check in. Why accept reservations if you need to stand in a line 30 deep just to check in? I tried to explain to the hostess we had a reservation and she ignored me. So we stood in line and were seated at 1210. Table was nice, at the corner of Van Ness.
We were greeted by our server about 5 minutes later. He took our drink orders, and 10 minutes later they arrived. We then place out lunch order.
At 1:20 the plates began to arrive. 2 at a time. Unacceptable wait time, the salads had been obviously ready for awhile as the lettuce was limp and wilted. Burger veggies same, and burgers lukewarm. One arrived tartare style, when we told the hostess it was raw and needed to go back she asked "what am I supposed to do with this?" Really you have never had a dish returned to the kitchen? At this point now 1:30 and pressed for time. We asked for a manager twice and finally had to seek him out. To his credit he cut the bill in half, but we will never return here. They obviously have no idea how to staff for seasonal times - and in such proximity to the opera house and symphony one would expect they would know how to anticipate this. On the positive side, I had the salmon sandwich and it was great. The grilled cheese for the 6 year old passed muster. The rest, well not so great. Stay away! Extremely poor service.
author: Keith C.

description: After calling in to make sure they had the Fantasy Torte in stock, we headed to Max's from our dinner location.  There used to be a Max's down here in San Jose where I could get my fix of the Fantasy Torte, but that is no longer the case, so I was thrilled to find out I could have a piece last night.  We arrived at the Van Ness location about 9:00.  There was only a scattering of tables with customers finishing up their meals, but it took over five minutes before a server acknowledged that we sat down.  After giving us eye contact, the server again disappeared for a few minutes before coming over to greet us.  All of that waiting time was dangerous, because I actually looked at the dessert menu.  It was a done deal that I would have the fantasy torte, but the B52 sundae was calling out to me as well.  The wheels in my brain were turning, so I asked the server to check if they had a whole Fantasy Torte in the kitchen somewhere.  They did, so I knew exactly what to order.  I had the simplistic B52 sundae, which was just vanilla ice cream, whip cream, and a shot of Kahlua, amaretto, and Bailey's. In addition, I bought a whole fantasy torte to take home.  We cut off one slice to devour the perfect combination of cheesecake, chocolate mousse, and chocolate cake covered in chocolate.  AHHH!  We also ordered a piece of New York cheesecake with blueberries and some drinks.  Service left a lot to be desired, but Max's was able to fill my craving for the Fantasy Torte.  I sliced, wrapped, and froze the rest at home.  Now I won't have to drive to San Francisco the next time I want to dive into my favorite rich, creamy, decadent dessert.  Thanks Max!
author: Lorianne L.

description: I used to go here a lot with my kids after going to the SF Ballet but haven't in recent years. We decided today to go again after today's performance. For reservations, I made a reservation for 5:45 which was the earliest I could after the performance ended.  It ended a little earlier so we walked over and the place was pretty empty. I told her I had a 5:45 reservation but would like a table if possible. She barely acknowledged me but seated us in one of the many tables.  I should have known the service was going to be bad since it took the server at least 10 minutes to merely acknowledge our existence. By the time she came back we ordered everything (drinks, appetizers, entree).  It took at least 30 minutes to get our food. Then she dropped it off and practically ran away without saying anything but I stopped her and asked about the appetizer. She said, "You didn't order any."  I said I did and you wrote it down. She looked at her slip of paper and said, "oh, do you still want it?"  I said no and she turned around and left. The entire meal she never came back to check on our drinks or see how we were doing. She was very attentive to tables around us. I hate to mention this, but we are an Asian family and all the other tables where white families and couples.  We ordered dessert and it took over 15 minutes to get a piece of cheesecake.  When she was walking by I asked for the check and she didn't turn but yelled "yea". At this point I think she's pissed at me about something. Anyway, we finally paid and left without talking to her. Horrible and rude, I'll never go back there. And if you do and you are not white and your waitress' name is Meriem, take my advice and leave immediately.
author: John C.

description: This place was just alright. Nothing special or out of the ordinary. The piano Player and the waitress's that sing were nice. I split the turkey sandwich and a salad with my mom. I have had better for cheaper. I don't know if the waitress was having a bad day or what, but she wasn't very friendly. The pepper grinder at our table wasn't working and when I told her she seemed annoyed. Hey, it's not my fault you have pepper grinders that malfunctioned. Sorry Max's, but next trip to S.F. I'll be skipping you!
author: Sarah R.

description:
First off the service is pretty bad. I missed out on a free slice of cake cause they broke their service rules and my dining companion begged me not to point it out, but the Pastrami is to die for as is the fresh baked rye bread and potato salad. 

Even at the price I'll come back for the pastrami.
author: Kelly O.

description:
So, I had a sick child at home this week. OK, so he's 38, but really, aren't we all children who want to be taken care of when we have the flu?

I thought that some matzo-ball soup was in order and this was the closest place to my office to get some on my way home. I remembered having their latkes at a holiday party that were delish, so I got some of those, too. Then I figured that with the soup I should get a sandwich to share. Here's where a problem lay. My standard for Jewish deli food is the fabulous, amazing "Famous 4th Street Deli" in Philly, where the sandwiches are big enough to feed a family of 6 and the matzo-ball soup, which is the best I've ever had, could feed Somalia. So at Max's, I was expecting huge portions of yummy food. 

The large soup was just enough for the 2 of us, but it wasn't spectacular. I was happy that it wasn't too salty, a problem that many soups have, and that the chicken was white meat. It was OK, but it didn't leave me anticipating my next visit. Same with the roast beef sandwich. It was a decent sandwich; nothing to complain about. But nothing to really remember, either. The latkes, however, were just as tasty as I remembered them. 

So, next time I have a sick child at home, I'll try one of the Russian places on Geary that always seem to have a good supply of fresh matzo-ball soup.
author: Amy B.

description: Just picked up a Reuben sandwich from here. It was a wet, sloppy mess with no flavor. Seems that didn't drain the sauerkraut at all and the bread was soaked. The pastrami was dry and over heated. Disgusting sandwich. Best Reubens are at Manhattan Hub in the financial district!
author: Kevin-louis B.

description: Stopped in here with a friend last Wednesday and ordered a cup of soup with matzo ball. Just want to say that the matzo ball was tasteless and just a heavy lump when it should be delicious and light. The corned beef sandwich was okay, but I had to go to Saul's in Berkeley the next day to get the bad memory of Max's matzo ball soup out of my mind. This kind of matzo ball is inexcusable!!!!
author: Yoka V.

description: I've eaten here many times and its become a staple of my SF experience. The sandwiches are to die for and the salads are mountainous piles of flavor. I recommend this establishment to anyone in the area or for anyone out of town coming for a visit. Try the matzoh ball soup!!!!!!
author: Marcus R.

description:
It's a restaurant by the opera house... How cool could it possibly be???

At dinner time we found a place to park, right across the street on Van Ness. Could happen. Right before me n wifey walk in, some bum proclaims how awesome we look, and asks "Are we locals?"  Too bad I didn't have any spare change.

It's a nice place, nice bar, even live piano lounge music. Good, friendly service. Waiters are a lil tongue in cheek (at least).

Great sandwiches. My Philly Cheese-Pastrami with fries was pretty good. And all the dishes are really generous. You will not leave there hungry. They have a chocolate cake slice that was huge, moist and sweet. It's the sh!t.

The prices aren't bad. I'd go again.
author: Rick V.

description: Walking in, I immediately noticed the great environment. Holiday lights were strung throughout the restaurant, adding an up-beat vibe.  A pianist also added to the cheery ambiance by playing some great tunes! We were seated quickly, even though we got there at 7 PM. Our waiter was able to take our orders quickly, and impressed us with his hospitable attitude. I ordered the corn beef, pastrami, 1000 island dressing, and swiss cheese sandwich with french fries. When my meal came, I took one bite, and wow, it was probably the best sandwich I've ever had. The crisp, well seasoned fries were also amazing. For dessert, I ordered the raspberry sorbet, something I also recommend. Despite the three star average of this restaurant, I would highly recommend it to anyone; the friendly atmosphere and the delicious food make this restaurant a perfect choice for a night out.
author: Josh R.

description: My husband and I were there for an early pre-opera dinner, and were almost done when a woman near us appeared to collapse.  My husband and I helped, holding her and trying to get her help, until the paramedics arrived.  The lovely manager at Max's comped our food, which was such a lovely gesture!  Thank you, Max's!
author: Kelcey P.

description: This place just isn't what it used to be. Unless you're stopping in for a huge slice of cake it just isn't worth it anymore.
author: Donna J.

description:
I'm a fan, but it's just not what it used to be.
I still love the sweet potato fries... and all the portions are HUGE... but these days the katchup shows up after the fries and the prices have crept up too.
I'm a semi-regular and I'm rarely dissappointed... but it aint what it used to be.
author: Alex S.

description: Slightly above average American food with huge portions. The menu covers a pretty wide spectrum, I opted for the chicken pot pie. I was warned that the portions were big, but that was an understatement. Talk about bang for you buck, my pot pie would have satisfied Kristie Alley. The piano player was a nice touch, and the servers were very helpful even though we came in right before closing time. The decor kind of made me feel like an 80's crack party was going to break out at any moment, but I'm a fan anyways.
author: Jordan S.

description: Don't know what all the whining is about. Same great food and service for the 25 plus years I have been dining here. We made a reservation for 6:00 and as always we were late. Not to worry I explained to my friend "it's Max's they will take care of us. As a nasty older (old) women and her husband were reprimanding, in a condescending tone, the host and hostess, because as she/he stated they "didn't know Max's took reservations" and for that reason they should be seated. Another manager approached us asked if we had a reservation, I said yes "we are Late" gave him my name and we were promptly seated. No fuss no muss. Food was great as was our server. We actually came back after the show and had wonderful dessert. Thank you Max's.
author: tom f.

description: Consistently good, very reasonably priced, and the service is just right.  Great location to meet with business partners and those that you need to catch-up with minus the fan fare.
author: Craig A.

description:
I love this place!!!! They have wonderful food and well the waiters break out in song for you from time to time. I am sure it sounds cheesy but I love it!!!!

I always tell people to go eat here when they are asking me where to eat in SF!
author: Samantha B.

description:
I always have and always will love Max's. 

The bread they bring to the table is awesome.  It's always warm with a good crust and tender interior.  Both the sourdough and wheat-raisin rolls are completely yummy!

I must admit that for me, the main attraction is the Matzo Ball Soup; Max's makes the best I've ever had.  A giant matzo ball, flavorful chicken broth, tender chunks of chicken, noodles, carrots, celery, and onions.  I'm drooling just thinking about it.  It's total comfort food for me as whenever I was sick when I was little my Mom would bring some home for me on her way back from work.  It always makes me feel better!

I also really like their sandwiches (yum Max's club) and, of course, their desserts!  Portions are huge here so you should probably share.  Even the "smaller" pieces of cake are huge.  Definitely check out the eclaires - they are massive and filled with half vanilla and half chocolate custard (not whipped cream.)  Yum! Oh and the giant chocolate-covered macaroons!  

Fantastic, delicious, comforting, wonderful.  Perfect for lunch (though parking is sort of a pain at this location.)
author: Katharine H.

description:
It's sad to say that everything here is going downhill: first their chicken now their matzo ball soup =( I was feeling like sh!t and wanted some good soup but was so disappointed when I got it. There was no ball in it and hardly any noodles- the soup was also super oily and had small pecks of fat in it..yuck. The roll that it came with was super hard and not fresh like it use to be.

Wow what's happening to this place?? Food downhill, prices sky high...no good!
author: M W.

description:
This place was decent and shiny.
It had yummy matzoh ball soup.
Terrible singer.
Okay piano player.
IT WAS FULL OF OLD PEOPLE.
author: Lauren S.

description: "Such a nice little Jewish deli" my grandmother would say. Get your matzo balls and pastrami here. The food's gone a little downhill lately, but still big, satisfying portions with a hell of a lot of hutzpah (sp?).
author: Jenny M.

description: This is my favorite place to have a nice filling meal prior to the ballet or Broadway shows. The crab cakes are just that: crab cakes, not cake with a little crab.I order the same thing every time,but I've tried most of their dishes by stealing bites off friends' plates.Reservations are necessary on show nights because this place fills up quickly. I love the live piano/singing while you dine and this place is fun for groups
author: Nicky E.

description:
I am rating them for their ice cream sundaes/desserts. 

It you're on a date and would like a cute atmosphere with singing or music in the background with cute comfy booths to sit at and gawk at each other, this is a nice spot.

Sweets with your sweet? Max's has HUGE ice cream sundaes, real thick hot fudge and a delicious assortment of desserts ranging from an eclair the size of my forearm to astounding creamy cheesecakes...

drool...
author: Theresa B.

description: Four adults and two 10 year olds - dinner before the Nutcracker...4 out of 6 bread dishes were greasy and 3 still had large blobs of melted cheddar cheese? on them. I quickly ask the waiter to replace the plates ....hurry before the other adults show up! (I'm thinking precursor of what's to come?). As water glasses were being REFILLED she over filled one glass and poured the entire contents BACK into the pitcher! (Please have washed it out before filling other tables!) 2 Stella's & 1 wine, Prime rib dinner (2), Turkey dinner (1), ribs (1) and kids chicken tenders (1). All the meat was luke warm to cold, broccoli was cold, baked potatoes were COLD. Cheese cake was excellent and the ice cream good.... after tip almost 200$ Yikes ...! Woke up next day with upset digestive tract....It use to be a great place....Not anymore...left wondering... What happened?
author: Robbie A.

description:
Myself and my mom had a cup of matzah ball soup and split a reuben sandwich with corn beef. The reuben itself wasn't that impressive, but tasty enough. On the other hand, the matzah ball soup was delightful. But just  a warning- the portions are HUGE.

This is the bottom line- if your downtown San Francisco, there are a million other places to eat better than Max's. However, if you are going to see a show at the opera house, grabbing a bite here before the show can be fun.

Come to Max's, have a bite to eat, down a few martinis, and enjoy your show.
author: David D.

description:
Two sandwiches and two soft beverages.  That'll be a week's salary and an advance from your retirement account.  This place is WAY overpriced.  What was intended as a nice, informal lunch outing turned into a $35 boondoggle.  For sandwiches!!

The Philly Cheese Steak was mundane, something you could throw together at home.  The wife's pulled pork sandwich was not very good.  The pork was dried out, the sauce was overly sweet, and it was served on an onion roll, which is just wrong, wrong, wrong.

The fries were good.  I'll give them that.  And the service was extremely fast during a relatively busy holiday lunch rush.  

Beyond that, though, you will leave here feeling poor and doubful about your judgment.
author: Daryl E.

description: very nice place with good food and a little bit of that charm that makes it interesting. Be aware that if going to the theater you might want to show up early so that you get a table. Otherwise the portions are great. The food was good and the atmosphere reflected that old San Francisco older but charming look. The waiters sing and just like anything else some are much better than others but overall it is a good experience. It is a cross of old California, Jewish deli and mini Hollywood. Very charming.
author: Carlos V.

description:
There really are only a few places in this nape of the woods... neck of the wape.... vicinity that are still open at 11.  And that I would enter unarmed.  Max's is one of them.

Things I like: option for double-sized pour of wine (9 oz.) for only 1.5 times the price; giant brownie sundae; they don't care that you're just here for wine and dessert.

Dessert sizes are truly heroic.  Thankfully, I can be a hero when the occasion really calls for it.  Or when brownies are involved.  Either way.  Note: I said brownies, not Brownies.  Screw Brownies; they knew what they were getting into when they signed up, and I need this trail mix.  I bet your parents will send their next daughter to something safer, like Kiwannis, huh Suzy?

Where was I?  So, the service was just fine (maybe a bit slowish, but it was freaking o-dark-thirty when we left, so I don't blame the guy), the food was awesome, the wine selection was decentish, and the prices were quite reasonable.
author: Ben P.

description:
Almost decent diner food, what more can I say? The strawberry lemonade with raspberry flavor was damn good. I had some linguine that was so-so. My friend had a crab sandwich that was not good. 

Almost funny signs.

I will almost go there again.
author: Ken L.

description: Food was plentiful and well prepared. Service however left a lot to be desired. We waited 15 min before we got up to ask for someone to wait on us. We waited another 10 min before anyone showed up. We also waited 20 min after asking for the check.
author: AJ H.

description: Great location. Huge portions but the food is n othing special. If you are in the mood for something plain and American, it's a great place.  I had lunch here with a big group and it was a perfect place for that.
author: sofiya f.

description: I went in for "the famous matzo ball soup" again the other day. Lukewarm water, canned celery and carrots, tiny slivers of chicken, and a matzo ball so tasteless and hard it could knock out a prize fighter. Oy vey!
author: Irina T.

description:
This place is a shell of its former self.  We ate here on Monday evening May 4th after finishing an event at the nearby War Memorial Opera House.  It was raining and we didn't feel like going far.  It's been awhile since we ate here and remembered that the food was good.  Boy were we disappointed.

We ordered a Cobb Salad and a pastrami sandwich.  The salad had a vinegar type dressing and was not prepared like a traditional Cobb salad. It just  had a poor taste.  The pastrami sandwich consisted of soggy bread and pastrami that had been sitting on the steam table all day.   It seems the kitchen did not care about presentation or quality. The service was marginal and we sat awhile after finishing and had to summon the waitress for the bill.   It wasn't very busy there and we can see why.

I think we would either eat at nearby Chevy's or even McDonald's before coming back here.
author: Robert J.

description: Always a nice meal, generous helpings and tasty food. Fun place to go.
author: Brendan H.

description: Let's be honest, the food and drinks are only average at best, but a pre-opera/ballet/symphony stop here for one of their colossal deserts and a cocktail is such a guilty pleasure! The live piano music is pleasant and the staff are accommodating when you've only scheduled 30 minutes for dinner before dashing to the show.
author: Anna J.

description:
Max's and I go way back.  Back to the original diner on 3rd, which was marvelous, a real diner w/ good diner food.  We've eaten at Max's in Corte Madera, the late and unlamented Max's Opera Cafe in Walnut Creek, whose singing wait staff were probably part of the farm team for this one, the excellent but short lived one across from the ballpark and the execrable one in San Ramon.  We've had good meals at this one, but this wasn't one and I doubt we'll bother w/ Max's again.  Dennis Berkowitz is famous for his dislike of critics and still has a handwritten diatribe against one of Michael Bauer's reviews framed on the wall.  When Max's food was good that was cute.  As the quality of the food has deteriorated over the years it's lost its charm.  

We were told there would be a 45 minute wait and it was about that.  I ordered a lemon drop.  The best thing about it was the service (Alan brought it).  If the lemon drop at 2nd Street Bistro in Williamsburg was a 5, this was a 1.  It was thin, pale and tart.  The only sweetness was provided by the sugar on the rim.
