Not a particularly appealing drink.  When we were seated our waitress immediately started to try to upsell us.  We told her we weren't interested in another drink and she pushed more than I thought was OK.  We told her we had an 8:00 concert.  By this time it was 7:00.  She brought us a basket of lovely warm rolls and butter.  Two of the rolls had raisins in them and one was plain sourdough.  They were tasty.  She took our order.  I had been debating between the mojito skirt steak, marinated in mint and lime and the traditional brisket.  Alan decided on the skirt steak, so I ordered the brisket.  Bad move.  We told the waitress we wanted to split a chopped vegetable salad.  The salad arrived unsplit, no extra plate.  Shortly after, she brought the entrees.  Alan's was cooked medium rare, as ordered.  It was good.  He gave me plenty bites.  The brisket, not so good.  It was sliced thin and wasn't especially moist or tasty.  Tam's is better, Bo's is better, mine is better, almost everyone's is better.  The best part was the roasted carrots that came w/ it.  I gave Alan lots of bites.  Of the brisket, not the carrots.  I got the better deal.  Our waitress was scarcely in attendance.  She checked by twice, Alan requested more water and the second time she brought it.  It didn't help the experience any that the tables were so close together that our "table mates" on one side were a singularly unpleasant pair about our age, of uncertain relationship, who gossiped about others' illnesses and deaths and sniped at each other throughout, bickered over sharing a desert, then figured out to the penny what each owed.
author: Toni M.

description:
Max's used to be fun.  Now it's more like a cranky old man.  An expensive, cranky old man.  

There's not anything special.  

Servings are huge, but not the kind where you think, "Ok this is so delicious, and I have enough for lunch tomorrow."  It's "Do I want to even bother taking this stuff home?  Will I ever eat it, or will I just end up tossing it in a week?"  (I ask for take-out, then leave it outside on the bench for one of the many street folk who always seem hungry.) 

I wish that Gordon Ramsay would give Max's a makeover.
author: Sebastian S.

description:
When I was contemplating moving to San Francisco (after grad school), and made many 12 hour flights (lay overs, you know) from New England, I always visited Max's, just for their smoked salmon sandwich.  

You need only to eat once the entire day after such an amazingly huge sandwich.   It has or shall I say HAD, all of the major food groups; protein from the eggs and salmon, veggies from the largely cut tomatoes, red onions and whole olives, grains of course from the onion bagel, dairy from the wedges of swiss and muenster cheeses, and fruit from the garnishes of orange slices.  

Perfection, no worries Mom, I have a "balanced" diet. 

 So, I move to San Francisco, and on my 2nd day here, I jump on the bus and head to Max's.  I graciously wait, and wait and get to the counter to order, and am told matter of factly; we don't sell smoked salmon anymore.  WHAT? Wait, what?  "we-do-not-sell-smoked-salmon" No more smoked salmon?!  At a New York style cafe/deli?  Blasphemy!
author: Mai G.

description: I had pretty good service and the pastrami sandwich was really good.  There's always an interesting crowd when I go here- great place to bring my 80 year old dad- he fits right in
author: Jackie H.

description:
Many Jews will tell you, "Oh, my (grand)mother makes THE best matzoh ball soup."  However, when I say it, I am telling the truth.   My mom's soup is extraordinary.  Her broth is sublime and her matzoh balls (or bumbahs as we call them) are nothing short of ethereal.  Often when she makes it, she'll exclaim "I've outdone myself!"  The funny thing is she doesn't even like matzoh ball soup.  And, she'll share her recipe with no one, only my sister.  She'll gladly tell you, however, that the number one ingredient in a matzoh ball is "love."  "You have to want to make a good matzoh ball otherwise you won't," she'd tell you.

This evening I was feeling a little under the weather.  Often when I do, I crave good ole Jewish chicken soup.  So, I dragged my goyish boyfriend here tonight so I could get my matzoh ball on.  Granted my standards are high but the bumbahs here were pretty bad.  They were kinda sweet as if they had added sugar.  Even the bf knew they were bad and he's from Iowa.  The broth & noodles were decent though.

All, however, was not lost.  I did get to indulge in a really good corned beef & pastrami sandwich.  The meat was moist and flavorful and not too fatty.  He got the pork chop which while a bit overdone came in really good, tangy sauce.

They had a piano player playing this evening which was a nice touch.  And, when she went on break the played Ella & Billie tunes which was cool.

So, all in all, this ain't my mom's house but it did in a pinch.
author: Jeff P.

description:
Max's is some kind of New York import, but I'm not sure what kind.  The restaurant rules on the back of the menu guarantee a good customer experience.  

My first Max's Opera Cafe experience was down by the airport, around 1997.  The waitstaff really did sing opera, and I hear they still do it at the Opera Plaza location.   

I don't have to look at the menu when I go to Max's.  I want the Reuben sandwich.  These things are HUGE.  The longer they stand on your plate, the more the dressing soaks into the rye bread, but the crust stays crispy all the way through.  About 1/2 lb. of corned beef is the centerpiece of this sandwich, and the sauerkraut is just a little sour.  The last couple of times I have visited, I couldn't finish the sandwich.  Three sides came with it this time, but for me it is all about the sandwich.  I ordered a diet Coke to go along with it, and the waiter made sure there was always a glass on the table for me.  

My Lady, who is more sensible than I, ordered a small Cobb salad and tea.  All four items cost us $31.71 + tip.  The waiter was surprisingly gracious, and earned a big tip.  

There's a small deli counter at the front door, but I've never tried it.  There is only one Max's experience for me.
author: David D.

description: Typical Max's food.  Good pastrami sandwich.  Others liked their meals as well.  Kitchen got order wrong.  Waiter made it right quickly with no questions asked.
author: TQMon E.

description: It breeds greed and gluttony.  MUST the portions be so big??  Only in America - and we wonder why Parisian women are so petite.  Sigh.
author: Kristen S.

description:
I'm not sure if it was too much 4th of July fun or the ever changing weather but I've felt like crap all week.  Who the hell gets sick in July?
Tonight I ordered takeout from Max's--chicken matzo ball soup and a cesar salad.  The soup helped soothe my savage beast of a cold and the cesar was fantastic-in addition to the normal cesar ingredients it also featured black olives.  Yum.
Next time you're feeling lousy or are just looking for a good cesar, give Max's a shot.
author: phil h.

description:
I used to work here in 2005, so I think I should write a review. I can keep it real, yo.

First of all I have to mention that the chicken pot pie is amazing. ORDER IT NOW. Megan and I used to order it all the time and nosh on it in between serving customers. It's SO good. 

Secondly, the desserts are incredible as well. I'd recommend stopping in for dessert and drinks in the late evening. I LOVE the Niagara Falls cake-- chocolate cake with loads of white butter-cream frosting. So worth the sugar coma it induces! Also, the brownie sundae is heaven as well. Mmmmmm I think my blood sugar is spiking just thinking about it!

Thirdly, as said in other reviews, yes, most of the portions are HUGE. I can only eat half of that chicken pot pie. It's good to come here and split an appetizer and an entree with someone (unless you're one of those who enjoys having a muffin-top, of course). 

They have a lot of different kinds of salads, which are, again, huge, and they are popular too. Their burgers are mediocre-- I wouldn't waste your money on one from here. Their pastrami sandwiches seem to be popular too, but that's not my cup of tea, so I couldn't tell ya!

Also, to be noted-- it gets super crowded here when there is an opera/performance, especially in December with the Nutcracker going on. There are loads of children running around. If you're like me, you'll avoid those times like the plague. :D

Last thing to say-- they don't take reservations, so if you come here on a weekend night, especially on a "performance" night, you should probably be prepared to wait a while.
author: Tiffany R.

description:
My review is based on Max's service. 

I went to Max's for the first time with a co-worker for a post-noon lunch during the week. About half of all the tables were taken but the restaurant did not give off a busy vibe. From what I could see, most of Max's patrons go here for a leisurely lunch. Since both my co-worker and I have an one hour lunch break, we did not feel pressed for time. With that said, we would've never gotten our waiter's attention without deliberately waving our hand in the air. 

Once we got his attention, he sauntered over as if we were taking his precious time. When he found out that we wanted to order he gave us that "oh, is that what you wanted? I'm too busy for you right now" look and said "I'll be back." Then walked away without another word. I've received better attention at CPK's. 

When he finally did return to take our order, his service was just as curt and inattentive. After he took our order, we never saw him again. Not to bring us our food. Not to refresh our drinks. Not to give us the bill. Not to tell us that he would be leaving. 

In regards to the food, my co-worker and I shared a Lamb Burger on an Onion Roll served with french ries and crispy onions and a California Chicken Melt. I would say that the food was 3 1/2-star worthy. And the portions mirrored the price. But the waiter's service far overshadowed the food. 

I would not come back here.
author: Cynthia P.

description: Had the chicken pot pie - tasted ok - but oddly it was salty..   now i've never had a salty pot pie before - and i've eaten a fair share of Swanson's home cooking (sodium overload) in my youth.   Now i'm wondering if they were using salt to conceal old expired chicken?   I dunno, a $15.99 "famous" pot pie shouldn't be salty period - I suspect this Max's location is going down the drain - tragic.
author: Ryan Y.

description:
I like going here for dessert. The waiters/waitresses sing with the piano every now and then. They must be aspiring actor/tresses or singers. The food is good, the service more/less substantial and the atmosphere professional. 

Parking is pretty unpredictable. It's nice for a once in a while outing or for a date. Don't be cheap and make your date walk: just pay for the parking lot on the side of the block (:
author: Kimiko Q.

description:
Went there after attending a performance at the Symphony Friday night. Blomstedt did a brilliant job conducting. 

I find it a little disconcerting to have to walk through what feels like a pickup area to get to the Host. The restaurant feels a little run down but I do like the lighting fixtures. 

I had a nice glass of the house Chardonnay. Hubby drank his usual water, which was brought to the table promptly as was the bread and butter. Nice thing about the butter was that it wasn't rock hard as most butter in restaurants is. I had a small order of nachos which were quite good with lots of different items on them like black beans, guacamole, tomatoes, cheese, lettuce and sour cream. Hubby had the roasted vegetable pasta and that was quite tasty too though it would be nice if the canned Roma tomatoes were broken up a bit. 

The restrooms were a little gnarly but not bad. I would definitely go back there if I can't find anything else in the area.
author: Anne C.

description: Great service and the sandwhiches were really good. Funny theme, really enjoyed going the experience. the waitstaff makes it worth returning
author: Tiff W.

description:
Went here before going to the SF Ballet. They have a decent menu and selection. I ordered a chesse burger with fries. I chesseburger was nice, but the fries were a bit soggy in my opinion. 

The service was okay, but we had to wait a while to get our food. 

This is a nice selection for lunch in San Francisco and I may return in the future.
author: Olga A.

description:
I've gone here for lunch. The food is pretty good, a little greasy. The restaurant itself is like a fancy burger joint. I tried the veggie stuff potato with the Cesar salad. They both were tasty and very filling. Service is slow during the lunch rush. 

I'd go back.
author: Terri L.

description: Good spot to drop in after watching the ballet since it is walking distance. You have to be quick because everyone else has the same idea and there is a long wait ;) Ordered a grilled salmon sandwich and lemonade. Portions are huge.
author: May B.

description: The Caesar salad with house-made dressing and parmigiano-reggiano cheese is delicious! Matzo ball soup was also good. I haven't eaten in at this location but have been pleased with take-out.
author: Miriam W.

description: Truth be told, it's kind of a great brunch place. Cheap drinks & good food. I even braved the nutcracker crowds for it and still I waited less time than I ever had at Boogaloos.
author: nicole l.

description:
Ok... keep in mind that these 5 stars are for their desserts. Namely, their oh-so-amazing and delicious, Fantasy Torte.

Fantasy Torte will be the cake served at my wedding. No doubt about it. I'm a girl so that's supposed to mean something right? Cause all girls do is fantasize about their wedding day right? Well the only reason I fantasize about it is because I get to do anything I want and no one can argue with me. Like eat Fantasy Torte. A whole cake worth of it. 

When I've had a really bad day, people bring me Fantasy Torte. When my mom comes and visits, we eat Fantasy Torte for dinner. And order more to take home. 

What is Fantasy Torte you say? It is heaven. Heaven is a 3 layer cake of cheesecake, chocolate cake, and chocolate mousse, covered in semi-sweet chocolate. If you hate being happy you can order a half order. 

Ok... enough about Fantasy Torte...  I also like their calamari, ribs, and asparagus. Those are the only things I ever order, so I can't comment on much else. This is a diner/cafe although it pretends to be a fancy pants place. It's not. So take it for what it is. Oh... and order the Fantasy Torte!

Oh and in case you didn't know... all the wait staff are singers so they take turn singing Opera and other stuff.
author: Ali R.

description:
Chicken Maztoh ball soup....need I say more?

It's all about a big piping hot bowl of starchy goodness on a windy Saturday Summer afternoon.

Another beatiful thing about this place it their bloody mary's which I wouldn't think that they would make a bloody mary half as well as they do here, but it's such a pleasant surprise! It has all the right stuff...including celery salt, regular tomato juice and enough worchester/hot sauce to give it that final smooth kick. Overall, I great bloody mary....even with crisp celery.
author: Laura G.

description:
You will be able to eat for three days if you get a dish here. That is for certain.

Good food, old fashioned soda joint feel with a piano? I don't know what Max's is trying to do but it confuses me. Maybe I am the only one...

But the food IS solid.
author: Alexis B.

description: Not sure what happened to Max's.  Max's was a staple for me and my friends since moving to SF in 2002.  I've been to five of the locations: San Bruno, Oakland, Opera, Union square, and 3rd Street SOMA.  However, over the past three years the prices have increased and the quality of the food has declined.  Service has always been spotty depending on time of day.  About 6 months ago I finally swore this place off for good.
author: Lola D.

description:
Overall, a disappointing experience. We can after seeing Juno, had a great salad and sandwich... but sadly, there was no service.

By no service I mean I had to track down our waiter to ask for the bill and the location of the bathroom. Basically the experience was like this:

Seated begrudgingly by a woman with pigtails.
Waiter comes to get drink order, we weren't ready to order drinks, so we ordered food. I then told him we'd have a drink order in a couple minutes. The waiter takes all the menus (including the drink menu sitting open in front of me.) and leaves to put in the order.
I waved down the woman with pigtails to get a new drink menu.
Time goes by. I wave to the waiter a couple times, he nods, but never comes.
He shows up to drop off mustard, and whisks away to talk to a 4 top seated right next to us. A minute later he comes back with our food.
No water refills, no checking on us to see if our food is right, no adherence to the Max's rules found on the back of the menu. That was it, it was disappointing.

After we ate and sat and talked for a while  we decided that it was time to get some drinks, somewhere where we would get SERVICE. 

I tracked down the waiter, and walked up to him while he was at a order terminal. Asked for the bill, and that was the end of our Max's experience.

Truly disappointing, lackluster, and apathetic service. The food was great, but I doubt I'll be back. Good food offset by bad service is not a great experience.
In case you are wondering, it was about 5pm on Tuesday, the place was maybe half full. However, we did get wonderful service when we relocated to Home for drinks. Max's lost out on an extra $50 in drinks.
author: Dave M.

description:
My take-out crabcake appetizer came with six teeny-bite crabcakes, all breaded so much that you can't even tell that they are crabcakes.   And why even bother to decorate them on top of wilted lettuce?  

Whatever happened to Max's?
author: Shirley F.

description:
My friend had his birthday party here. The manager agreed to charge only two corkage fees for however many bottles of wine we'd bring (and we brought several cases for this large party). When our large party showed up, the staff had heard nothing of the deal, and the manger, on the phone, reneged. Unbelievably, they argued with us for 45 minutes as we waited to start our party, kind of spoiling it for us. 

The food was good, nothing to rave about, and the wait staff was pretty good. But, the management really burned us. I'll avoid this place!
author: ken w.

description:
Max's is one of my g/f's favorite places to eat in the city.  It definitely did not disappoint.  I had the meatloaf w/mashed potatoes, gravy and roasted carrots.   Since I was a kid, I haven't been much of a meatloaf eater.  Even more rare, I actually ordered it at a resturaunt.  It didn't disappoint, tho.  If fact I filled up on too much raisin bread rolls and salad, so I just made sure I ate as much of the meatloaf as possible.  1st:  Raisin bread rolls-F*ck Yeah!  2nd: Heart of Romaine Salad-  This is really basic.  Just the heart of a Romaine head with red onions and halfed cherry tomatoes.  I got my salad with the lemon vinagrette.  Really tasty!  3rd:  The meatloaf tasted like an original meatloaf.  This isn't your mom's meatloaf...    Cooked well and still juicy and tender.  Had to eat it all cause you know it wouldn't be the same cold or reheated.  If I wasn't staying in a hotel, I definitely would have taken some home to make a meatloaf sandwich.

The only thing I wasn't thrilled with was the opera singing.  I would like to give props to the Host and the Waiters for performing, even though I didn't really enjoy it.  Aside from the singing (which wasn't bad, I'm just not into it) I thought it was great that the waiters doubled as performers.
author: Zofeone D.

description:
There is probably a lot to say about Max's, not only the Opera Plaza location but its other locations, past and present.  The thing is that the menu is enormous, widely scaled, which they proudly brag about in their menu-ese-y declarations.

To put it simply, I've found a number of things on their menu that I enjoy  and find to be largely consistent in their presentation and quality.  The place gets mobbed at certain times and service can vary a bit.  There is a huge staff, none of whom I can recall seeing twice.

But, let me get to the point.  The thing that has been bringing me back time and time again lately is their kiwi lemon drop.  Made with a freshly-squeezed and mashed kiwi, it's both green and delightful.  I could drink 'em by the thermosful.  They do good cocktails as well as large-plated meals.

So, I gotta say, I like it.  And there is a Peet's Coffee right nearby to cleanse the pallate and encourage digestion and caffeine jitters.
author: Kennelco C.

description: This is a total ripoff!!!  one waiter taking care of 10 tables ..with a 50 minute wait to get our food.  the pastrami sandwich was $14 with more fat than meat.  the matzo soup was good however ovetall this was not a max's that i will return to any time soon!!!  We asked for a box which never materialized...don't know how they stay in business!!!  service is one of the worst i've ever experienced!!!
author: Rosalie B.

description:
Ok...Miguel, tell the restaurant manager that the WHEAT bread is STALE (hard, and too horrible, dryed out turkey meat) for the sandwiches!!! Why do people go here? To get a drink and feed their fat faces with DULL food flavors and big slices of cake with seven layers...can I now give it minus three stars?

Now, black and white stripes, white tiny weird lamps, black floral carpeting....GREEN just seemed a bit less cold than black and whiteIMHO.

Getting a " FACE-LIFT"-Aug. 8-Aug 30, 2007

Open late and has large portions. The kind of place to get an enormous dessert and share it with at least four women if you're with someone, or have it for one big muthawidabigbuttafucoappetite, that has a need for VOLUME in this super-sized portions. Plus you can order a drink from the bar. I generally like most of the servers and bartenders. NO RESERVATIONS taken; they will seat you. 
:-(
Update: July 2006

Went again last week for the Chinese Peanut breaded chicken salad and was disappointed in the lack of flavor. It was just thrown together and was lackluster , just bland without any excitement... and have to downgrade it minus four stars (learned from the Opera House bartender that this place got  a citation from the Health Dept. for cockroach and rat droppings...)also because the dinner rolls were so tough it was definitely made for shark mandibles. Too bad. Oh well, what do south of the border workers know about Pastrami..niente, adios Maxi-millianous rodent droppings, por favor.
author: miriam b.

description:
wow this is a hard review/rant 
I love this place. The prices are great and the portions are huge the waiters are usually awesome! I even cracked my tooth on the Reuben and they paid for the dental bill after a short investigation with my dentist! OK all yay!

I was there after the Ballet last week and have in the past dined there when it was much more crowded and our server didn't even ask us for a beverage until we were there nearly 15 mins. Then when we ordered he sped off and another 20 mins passed without him asking us if we wanted bread-Another Waiter doll) from the opposite section took pity on us and gave us bread-after another 10 mins he without apology or even much of a greeting took our orders that took nearly 20 mins to come without checking in on us at all...

When we were done he didn't come back for ages to give us our dessert menu and take t he order's you see a pattern? HE got the lowest 15% tip

now in between all of this the ladies room was a mess! I mentioned it to the Host and when I went again (we were there a long time) it hadn't been fixed but worsened with the stall trash bins exposing used pads mentioned that to the Host -on my subsequent visit only the "tops' of the trash had been removed the end of the night lipstick touch up lets say I saw BART bathrooms smell and look better. am shocked and wished the health dept saw that mess...and the thing is I had been there on much busier nights...since I love the food so much I will return but after the memory of that eve has faded
author: Kitty L.

description:
Great place...you just have to be in the mood for a LOT of food.  

- I heart grilled cheese and theirs is soooooo tasty...maybe a little overpriced though at $12 or so.  
- Their chicken salad wrap is excellent and not overly huge.  
- Reuben is De-lic-ious.  
- Love the live piano player and occasional singer in the evenings.  

- The pot pie was just way tooo big and nothing special.  I had to drench it with hot sauce.  
- Really good overall but there are better places.
author: John B.

description:
When living in San Rafael from 1991 - 1994, I used to view a trip to Max's Opera Cafe as a major treat.  The food was amazing, the entertainment was fantastic, and the atmosphere was very cool.  After I moved out of state, the Peppermill in Corte Madera became a Max's.  D'oh!!

At that time, I would have given it 5 Stars.

After relocating to the Bay Area in 2000, I looked forward to returning to Max's Opera Cafe, but it seemed that the quality of the desserts had changed (possibly a different vendor) and the ingredients used were not the same.

Unfortunately, over time, their other locations near Moscone and the sandwich shop near the Embarcadero shut down.  Nowadays, I can enjoy it, but I have to lower my expectations and not compare it to Max's Opera Cafe, circa 1994.

Great place to go if you are near City Hall...  I would advise going right after the curtain goes up at the Ballet or they dim the lights at the Symphony.  That is best time to get a table, as the theatre crowd disappears and you can really realax.

Not sure what is going on with the quality...  they really seemed to take pride in the authenticity of their New York Deli style food in the 1990's.  Now, I can only give it 2 Stars and say "Meh.  I've experienced better." but, that better experience was from the SAME RESTAURANT.
author: Ross H.

description:
I'm sick and craving Max's matzo ball soup, but regardless, I can't imagine how this place only has a three star average?!?! Max's Opera Cafe is a tradition; if the service ain't great, it's because, chances are, your waitstaff is trying to break into show biz. Hence the random outbreaks of singing and why it's next to the OPERA HOUSE.

There's a Max's in Corte Madera and one in Stanford - I think the chain was bought out awhile ago - but the recipes have stayed the same. Again, the matzo ball soup is EPIC, as is the turkey burger, the pear salad, the nachos...crap, now I'm hungry and bed ridden.

Bonus: they deliver through Waiters On Wheels, which isn't as expensive as you would think, and so worth it for their fries (AND SOUP! I CANNOT STRESS THE SOUP ENOUGH!)
author: Hilary L.

description:
Usually, I love Max's.  I love their fries and sandwiches.  However, this location nearly ruined decades of love for me.

My usual at Max's is the Reuben sandwich.  I'd definitely consider it one of the best in the bay area.  A couple friends and I got lunch takeout and all ordered Reubens.  Keep in mind, the $9.99 price tag comes with the sandwich, coleslaw OR potato salad, and a pickle.  $9.99 was fine with me, because we were expecting huge portions, based on experiences at other Max's.

We got our food and went home.  When we opened the sandwiches, I was kind of grossed out.  The corned beef was an unpleasant purple color and full of hard-to-chew connective tissue and fat.  I was almost glad there wasn't that much of it on the sandwich.

I think the worst part is the complete lack of value.  $9.99 for a crap sandwich and no fries or salad?

This Max's should, by nature of its location, strive to set the bar for the rest of the Max's in the bay area, yet it is a complete failure.  Another thing, they don't have all of the famous Max's desserts I love so much.  They have a few, but not all!

Tip to Max's: Replace your terrible kitchen staff (any chef will tell you it's 110% clear they don't care about the food they're serving or are simply inexperienced) and you will profit.

Tip to those who are going to visit Max's on Van Ness: Go to a different Max's.
author: Gavin S.

description:
This place was magical for me as a kid.  I have this distinct memory of sitting in our Toyota celica, driving to Max's and I was playing with this puzzle thing (extraneous information thus far) and, anyways, when we got there and we always went there, especially for my birthday with the parents---I got to pick out my birthday slice.  Which means, I got to go up to the big glassed case of desserts gleaming up in front of my 5 year old self.  I always picked the Niagara falls slice.  With a name like that, how could you not???  I remember the fan fare, the singing, the sparkling, the city lights and again: the magic.

I went back recently for the first time since I was 5 or so.  I had gone to the palo one since many times.  I was sorely disappointed.  Kind of like going back to the swing set you saw as golden and delightful and perhaps new on retrospect going back no longer fits your behind, is graffitied or grown old, grass growing through the wood planks below, I no longer saw the magic. In fact it looked so, well---dated.  It looked like it needed a good remodel.  And that is when I realized that this may be due to the fact that it was pretty old and it was pretty new when I first went there as a child.  In any case, it just wasn't the same.  And I even ordered the same cake again for old times sake.
author: Lauren S.

description:
I think that any place that shares the name of my orange tabby can't be too bad...

I've been to Max's at the Opera in the past and it is pretty predictable.  Yet, this time, it wasn't so predictable.  I hadn't realized that it changed ownership, but the menu has also taken a drastic turn.  

So, this is what I have to say:

$40.00 for lunch for 2 is ludicrous.

The price is the same for lunch or dinner.   Bah humbug.

The skirt steak sandwich ($14.99) = edible, but WHERE IS THE BEEF (really).  The seasoned steak fries would have been better if they were CRISPY and hot, not soggy and luke-warm.

The coffee ($2.75) = decent 

The 1/2 slice of ultimate chocolate cake ($3.99)...RIDICULOUS...the cake was good, but the 1/2 slice was paper thin.

The lamb burger ($12.99) = good and different offering

Yet, in the end, I left feeling that the experience would not be memorable in a very good way.  The food is overpriced, the service was good, but the clientele is much more the "older" crowd. There just isn't a youthful, creative vibe to the surroundings or the food.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
Max's has gone seriously downhill over the years. They don't even have good pickles anymore! A group of us met on New Years Eve at 4pm for a pre-show meal...  the service could not have been much worse. I liked my Cobb Salad, so I can't complain about the food on this occasion, but my friend's beet salad had the most boring beets ever. There weren't enough condiments on the table and the waitress never asked how the food was. 

This could be an annual tradition for us... in fact, we have gone there pre-show in the past... but they've lost our business.
author: Mara K.

description:
I always end up at Max's because of the convenient location or because someone else really wants to there.  Everyone I know thinks Max's food is great.  I've always thought the food is mediocre.  

But last Friday night, Max's dinner just won the award for the *worst* meal I've had in San Francisco.  

For some reason, it took over 45 mins for our food to arrive.  Fine, no big deal.    For some reason I ordered a cheeseburger.  Why not?  For some reason, it was rancid. Yup.  I had my friend inspect and taste it, just to verify; he had to spit it out.  How awful is that?  That is just a big no-no!   

I ended up sharing my friend's tuna melt sandwich, which was decent, though my taste buds were still reeling from the bad meat.  The french fries,  mushy. 

Oh but the Arnold Palmer was yummy.  And note, they will charge you $1.00 for a refill, though no one tells you that.

You've been warned......
author: Nancy X.

description:
for vegetarians there are very few selections and the prices are very high. I go there fairly regularly but resent paying $12 for a salad, plus tix, health tax and sales tax. Especially since i go there late at night and the music is already done... there should be an automatic discount when the live music/singing is done...
I am being tough with my review hoping to see a change...
author: Lea P.

description:
Dear Max, 

I will never darken your door again. All I wanted was a big, juicy lamb burger and free-flowing champagne. How was I to know that I would only get a side of meat with all my french fried potatoes? ...And worse yet, I had to practically tackle my waiter to get another glass of your $9.00 champagne. I was sad, I cried myself to sleep...a little. 

Vaya con dios Max, until we meet again...
author: Kate B.

description: Dined here prior to Colors of Christmas concert. I ordered a sandwich and the hubby ordered a burger.  I agree with the other reviews about the bread being stale. I dont mind paying $12.00 for sandwiches if the bread is good; the bread used for the burger was practically falling apart! Never coming back to this place.
author: Elle A.

description:
Here's the thing: I ate at Max's before a show at Davies Symphony Hall, and you can't beat it for the proximity. I probably would have given it three stars then: Our sliders were a bit greasy, but the sweet potato fries were good and, even with a drink each we got out for under $30 in less than 45 minutes.

But I went recently for a friend's birthday and felt like I got scammed. For a glass of wine and a dessert, I ended up paying $25. After spending the equivalent on two stiff drinks and appetizers down the street at Olive, this seemed way overpriced. 

Verdict: If you need a pre-theater bite to eat, go for it and literally stomach the prices. If not, check out the local eateries in nearby Hayes Valley -- or toddle on up to some cheaper eats with the fast food venues and Naan-N-Curry on Van Ness.
author: Nob H.

description:
Big portions and over priced would best sum up this eatery. 

Key to the Max's experience in the singing waiters and piano. I've only seen this done in the evening, and I suspect the staff does it out of boredom since there are about twelve people in the restaurant. 

The food is some kind of cross between a Jewish deli and Denny's, but I wouldn't describe any of it as stand out. The sandwiches are ok, as are the hamburgesr, as are salads. 

Its not worth the trip.
author: Geoffrey P.

description:
I came here the other night after the opera with my family. We come here pretty ofteen to both this location and the one around union square. They have the best rueben sandwiches, my favorite being the pastrami and corn beef with swiss cheese and thousand island dressing. WIth every every sandwich you get  to choose from three side dishes: coleslaw, potato salad or cucumber salad. 

  If you are into show tunes, some of the staff sing a few tunes during dinner time.
author: Adam D.

description:
The 4 stars are for the desserts alone, which are really decadent and served in rather large portions.  I had a slice of Max's cake, and also got bites of their chocolate cake and their brownie.  The chocolate cake was delicious and very moist, while my cake was almost too rich to eat.  The brownie was okay, though it initially came out with the wrong toppings.  The hot fudge was delicious though.

Service was not bad, but I couldn't understand their rather strange service "rules."  I want to be asked if "how everything is" because that's usually when I get the chance to let the server know whether I need something or not.  

In any case, all the desserts were really good- I'd come back for those desserts and possibly some of their main courses.  The singing is a little distracting, especially when you're trying to have a conversation, but it was neat to listen to the servers belt their hearts out.
author: Angela H.

description:
Forget the other chains (OK, Palo Alto is all right), this is what Max's is all about.  Great food, nice servers, pleasant music (for the most part).

I highly recommend the reuben with pastrami - amazing!  The pear salad is also a great option for vegetarians, or those who'd like something a bit healthier (umm, huge chunk of blue cheese aside of course!).

You can't go wrong with the desserts.  The eclairs are the biggest I've ever seen, and the Fantasy Torte is the only version of cheesecake that I'll eat - sooo tasty!
author: Corey C.

description: I had a terrible "never should happen" experience today at Max's near the Civic Center.  They lost my credit card!  How does that happen?  The waiter brought us our check and I put our credit card in the small pocket intended for it.  No one came by for quite a while but when they finally did, they said the card was lost.  We had ballet tickets so we agreed they would still look for it while we were at the ballet.  When we  returned 2 1/2 hours later, they had not found the card.  They were nice enough to pick up our lunch (the least I would expect) but did not even offer a gift card for all the hassle we now face with canceling our card, calling numerous businesses that have our credit card on file, etc.  Nor did they offer to pay for our parking...but they were kind enough to let us know where there was an ATM.  I was shocked as was my 12 year old daughter. I  plan to call the manager tomorrow, and the owner and Seven on Your side unless they offer me more than a free lunch that i was trying to pay for until they lost my form of payment.  To top it off, my husband is leaving town on Tuesday and now has to get cash since we will not have the replacement card...and we are out airline miles now too as a result.  Max's......you owe us more than a free lunch for all the hassle we now face due to your mistake, not mine.
author: Mona S.

description:
I remember their food to be rather tasty but nothing exceptional.  Kind of like Cheesecake Factory in terms of what they offer and the portions are indeed ginormous.  Their chicken wings are really really saucy.  Chicken marsala was good...al dente pasta and tasty chicken and plenty left over for lunch the next day.  Friend got the crab cake sandwich and she said it was rather tasty as well.  The superstar of the night however was their chocolate brownie sundae with marshmallow sauce...dude... that thing can be shared between four people. and it's really, really, really good.  

Prices are pretty standard for the amount of food they give you...around $15-$25 per person depending on what you get.  Parking can be hard so don't even bother on Van Ness and head into one of the alleys instead.
author: Peggy W.

description:
I used to love this place. But, I've been up for two hours now, experiencing horrible tummy reactions due to their questionable food safety.

Bad. Bad. Bad.

no fun at all.
author: Franciscan M.

description:
So the water was good... so was the raisin bread. Two stars for that! Oh, and for parking too! Lots of street parking!

Service was bad, food was ehhh.... I ordered the chicken melt and it was DRY. Save yourself money and go to the Chevy's or MacDonald's across the street.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
Max's is one of my favorite places to eat in the city. I almost always get the grilled cheese sandwich and fries. Breaking from the simple origins of the grilled cheese, Max's allows you to combine some fairly exotic (or at the very least, "non-traditional") cheeses for a fairly unique take on an ultra simple dish. Their fries are probably my favorite french fries in the world, and good God do they give you a lot of them.

Bottom line - when you come to Max's, expect to stuff yourself silly.

Four stars - only because I greatly prefer their Union Square location.
author: Alex C.

description:
The menu proclaims, "This is a bad place for a diet!" 

But what an extraordinary place it is to bond, especially on a Friday or Saturday night!   Max's is a highly popular post-performance destination, and we always seem to fit right in.   When I visit, I am usually in the company of performers from the venues around Van Ness, and it's just as easy to mingle with other figures which frequent this place. 

The desserts are divinity on Earth.  There isn't a single one that I don't recommend!   Max's uses singing waiters/waitresses, which adds an interesting touch to the whole experience.  Be sure to clap, even if they shattered a few wine glasses. 

I hesitate to take a few of the other reviews of this place seriously, like the dork who can't even seem to remember what he ordered. Uh huh, just the way he likey.

That being said, there are a few items to avoid, such as the lip-peeling buffalo wing salad.  Just don't do it.   Also, the pasta isn't necessarily gourmet quality, but with so much else to order, why the hell are you eating pasta? Nearly everything else is deeply satisfying.  

Just as Max's relies on the Civic Center's jewels (the symphony, the ballet, and the opera), these events just wouldn't be the same without Max's.
author: Daniel C.

description: Went for lunch, had a group of 13.  Was seated immediately at a very busy noon time on a weekday.  Great service.  The waiter was calm and answered all our questions. Last time, we came the food was uneven.  This time the food was surprisingly good.  I wish they bring back small pieces of bread.  They had chunks of raisin bread and sourdough.  I had the special:  Pastrami with three different salads (potato, cucumber, and cole slaw).  Just much food for $10.95 including a drink (either soda, tea, or coffee), can't beat that price.  They are having artichoke specials.  My friend had that and finished the whole plate of artichoke, asparagus, with salmon.
author: Helen L.

description:
Excellent food, huge portions and some tasty food.  That's why this place is so popular.  It's as if you've walked into a New York City deli which also doubles as a lounge.

I had the Reuben, and enjoyed it thoroughly.  The service is great and the ambience is very condusive to a good dining experience.  Try one of their deserts too if you still have the room, their banana cream pie is quite good.

Just be sure to ask to be seated away from the front door if it's a cold night, the wind comes gushing in everytime that door opens.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
Max's used to be one of my favorite places. I took everyone there. I live in Burlingame, so I frequented that one more than the others, but I've been to most of the Bay Area locations and the quality was consistent.
In the last few years, I've been disappointed by each experience. The Niagara Falls cake which was my reason for living, just isn't the same. The meal I had on Max's on the Square was flavorless.
And yesterday I went to the one on Van Ness to get a 7 layer bar. I saw them in the display case and they were huge! I greedily thought I'd be getting more of something I've always loved. But no, it's dry, hardly any flavor, and so big I couldn't get it in my mouth. Way too many butterscotch chips and not enough coconut milk and chocolate chips. I was so disappointed. It definitely wasn't made that day. (This was at about 3pm on a Monday.)
Anyway, this experience just reaffirmed my decision to stay away from Max's now. Such a disappointment.
author: Adrienne C.

description:
OK, the skinny to sum up quick:
Sit at the bar and eat, or you will wait a while.No Reservations.
But....The food was good. All I had was the ' Guy's Chinese Chicken Salad" at a half order, and the $#!+ was still big.

And a couple lookers ( lady workers) at that place.I would go again. Perhaps....
author: Lou Z.

description:
I was REALLY craving a Reuben and I got it here.  It was thicker than it was wide due to the inordinate amounts of pastrami... a must for any good Reuben on rye.  

     Even though I got a water with it, I ended up paying $20 with tax and tip ($12.99 sandwich price).  This place is kind of expensive for a lunch because I'm a baller on a budget . But, it was worth it because of occasion that I went for.

     I also heard that some of the staff are trained musicians and can put on a good show.  They also gave good service as well!

Great food, but about $3-4 more expensive than any other diner type place for most items.
author: Joey S.

description:
I can only give this place one half of a star for the only time I have had a wholly satisfying meal here. It was take-out, for lunch, and only a half a wrap, so there for a half star is only appropriate.  If it had been a whole wrap, perhaps a whole star...
Anyway, it doesn't matter.  After several attempts over the last four years of working at City Hall and having desperate deli cravings absolutely dashed to pieces upon one crappy Max experience after another, I have sworn off for good. 

Recap of my last experience: 

(Scene) It is raining absolutely sideways, we run from City Hall to the safety of Opera Plaza.  Throw open the doors to Max's and slosh through the nearly empty restaurant to the hostess stand. 
Hostess: Yeah? 
Us: Um, yeah.  We would like to get lunch. 
Hostess: Well...you can sit at the bar.

We walk in the direction of her thumb, which she has just casually thrown over her shoulder, and sit down at the bar. 

Mind you, Max's has just renovated from one horrific interior to something equally horrific, which is good because we have something to talk about as we wait for interminably long periods of time between any waitstaff attention throughout our meal. Honestly, it looks like a monster with a penchant for green and pink Smooth & Melty's lost his lunch inside a slick chinese restaurant.  I do like the chandeliers, though. On to the rest of our lunch....
 
The waiter brings us menus, does not ask if we would like drinks, and leaves.  Another waiter comes, gives us water, leaves.  A third waitress comes. We order. 
 
10 minutes later, we get our appetizer "Baked Giant Mushrooms with Pecorino Cheese and Pesto".  Now, wouldn't you think that they would be warm? Yes? Well, you would be wrong. Wouldn't you think the mushrooms would at least be large, if not giant? Wrong again.  We got 4 cold, not-so-big mushrooms in a tepid (at best) marinara sauce.  Generally, my lunch partner and I are not complainers--we are too afraid of spit.  In this case, however, we had to say something.  At two dollars a pop, we were not going to eat lukewarm mushrooms.  So we did.  The waitress STUCK HER THUMB in one of the mushrooms and said, "yep, you're right" and whisked them away.  She returned 10 MINUTES later with our plate maybe two degrees warmer than the last time, and made a huge deal about the fact that she gave us an extra, "free" mushroom, on her....Well thanks a ton, lady. 
 
Our lunch continues in this downhill trajectory...my buddy's Rueben comes with no 1000 dressing, and he has to ask for ketchup for his french-fries too (I know, bizarre request, but still...) The cheese on his sandwich is, yes, melted, which would imply that it was once warm, but in fact it too is chilly to the touch.  So okay, maybe warm food is not their thing? On to my salad...which I never found under the huge glob of sour cream that they put on top of it. 
 
Oh, and the desserts, which used to be the restaurants only saving grace, have been downsized. This is not my imagination, we asked and it was confirmed. And don't even get me started about the time I got a half a salad for the bargain price of $17 dollars....
author: Alexis T.

description: I like Max's because it has such a huge diverse menu.  It's not the A #1 best food I have ever had but that's not to say it's bad.  Their sandwiches are really good.  I used to go there with my mom and meet her when she got off work.  It's fast and convenient.  I prefer to go there for lunch as opposed to dinner just fyi because I feel the menu is better suited to (at least my own personal) lunch tastes.
author: Jon T.

description:
If you're craving American food, definitely go to Max's. I've been here a couple of times for prom and casual get together's. All of my experiences there have been fabulous. The atmosphere is very classy and jazz rhythms trickle throughout the whole restaurant. Occasionally during the hour, someone will play the piano or sing very beautifully. This place is decent enough to bring your significant other onto a dinner date. The entrees here come in large large portions for a decent price. 

Try these:

[[ Fresh Pear Salad ]] Danish Bleu Cheese, Cranberries, Candied Walnuts, Scallions, Raspberry Vinaigrette

[[ Sourdough Tuna Melt ]] Avocado, Tomato, Dill Harvati

[[ Barbecue  Chicken ]] Sweet Texas BBQ Sauce, French Fries, Coleslaw

[[ Brownie Mud Pie ]] Fudge brownie, coffee ice cream, bitter sweet hot fudge, caramel sauce, candied peanuts.

[[ Niagra Falls Cake Slice ]]
author: Janice M.

description:
Disappointment. For me, one word is enough but for you I'll explain the situation. 

First of all the ambiance is lacking, a diner at best. 

Second of all, I came into Max's under the impression (as stated on their website) that  "opera" was going to be a part of my night, I was wrong. Opera singing only begins at 6pm and is only located at the piano. According to my very drab waitress, "some waiters sing, sorta". It was 5pm and I was attending the ballet at 6pm so no singing for me. 

Next the food was below par. When a 5 year old is disappointed with their hamburger you know there is a problem. Besides the fact that they got 2 of the orders wrong, which I noticed was also the case at the table next to us. 

Finally I ordered what I believe was called Flank Steak Mojito, described as being an infusion of mint and lime juice with broccolini and potato's. When I got my order the potato's were missing, the only thing about the steak that resembled "mojito" was the slice of lime and leaf of mint sitting on my plate, the broccolini was unseasoned as were the potato's when they came, not so much as a bit of butter was on them. 

Like I said before....disappointment.
author: Nikki W.

description:
Yes I was sick and no I couldn't even swallow (food people!!!....nasty).  Nonetheless I went to Max's Opera Cafe to kill one hour of my time and ordered the yummiest concoction that I have had the pleasure of having for dessert.

Chocolate Decadence Brownie Dessert!!!!  It is a big warm thick brownie (no nuts-I'm allergic to nuts) with a super scoop of vanilla bean icecream with fudge and marshmallow topping.  It stood at least six inches tall and tasted damn good.   

Do you need an insane sugar fix?  This is the place to do it....just ignore the tourists gawking at the waiters/broadway showtune singers.
author: Jay H.

description:
I can't speak too generally for the epicurean experience that is Max's, but whenever I get the first inklings of a cold, I come a runnin' for their Matzoh Ball Soup.  Well, they say that there's no satisfied customer like the one who has a problem that is well addressed by the establishment...so it is here.

I went in today to salve my unhappy throat with a couple of quarts of MBS...unfortunately, they were out of the sturdy plastic quart containers and gave me four of the more flimsy styrofoam pint containers with paper-thin plastic tops.  By the time I got home, the upper containers cracked through the lower containers in the little stacks in the bag, leaving a nice puddle of soup in the bottom of the bag.

I called  the manager and told them what happened and they were very apologetic and offered replacement when I next came in.  More surprisingly (for a $4 item), they called me again later to apologize again and to assure me that they would take care of me.  

THAT is the way it's supposed to happen.  Bravo, Max...Bravo.

--- FOLLOW UP on JAN 18th ---

Went back in to Max's for lunch with a friend and spoke with Mary, the manager who had called methe day before - again she was apologetic and said she'd take care of it.  At the end of our meal, with no need for a reminder, the waiter brought a quart of the soup to the table - even though all I'd lost was a pint.  They're keeping me as a customer, fo sho.
author: Josh M.

description:
I have never been so upset at service in a resturant like I was this past Sunday. 

My husband and I arrived at the place and waited at the check in desk for about 5 minutes before anyone even acknowledged us. 

We were then seated and was given glasses of water that looked as if the glasses were taken out of the dish washer during the wash cycle.

We sat there as the waiter continued to pass by us not even asking if we were ready to place our drink orders. Another family of the same race of the waiter walked in and received the royal treatment.

My husband and I decided to speak to the manager whose attitude about the situation was very "and, so what", which prompted us to leave.

I must say, the food at Max's is delicious but the service at this location sucked!!!!!!! We really enjoy the service at the Stanford Mall location and will continue to visit there instead.
author: La Toya B.

description: I like this place for its convenience for dinners after attending the Opera or Symphony. The food is good. I feel like the quality has decreased in recent years, and at one time I would have given it 4 stars. In addition to a decrease in quality, the portions seemed to have gotten smaller. But, don't get me wrong.  The food is still good here. What they do especially well is the deli sandwiches. Even for dinner, I much prefer the sandwiches over any of the dinner entrees. The other thing they do especially well here are the sundaes. I'd give them 5 stars if all they had were the sundaes.
author: Gregory S.

description:
I came online to give this place a 4 star rating. I thought about it and maybe the service could still be improved. However, the food and service was better than last time - so I'd give it a 3.5 instead of a 3.0 stars.

I had the Thursday lunch box special. For $10.99 I got the turkey sandwich) warm and it came with mash potatoes and a free fountain soda/coffee/or iced tea. I chose the iced tea - actually they gave me warm tea and a glass of ice and I put it in myself- unsweetened style my favorite. They have lunch box specials for everyday of the weekday. I was impressed because the sandwich was pretty good. I also asked for extra gravy and it was just perfect- not too salty and included mushrooms in the mix. I thought the mushrooms could have been more cooked, but other than that the lunch was really good.

I felt a bit cramped in the booth seat I was in, and our table was a bit close to the others. 

The service was fine. I think the waitress could have been more attentive to us, but I didn't think she wasn't either. It was somewhere in the middle.
author: Tina C.

description: I love this place.always great food.  The dessert is out of this world.  Last time we were there the was a guy singing some opera.  Awesome!
author: Jeff L.

description: This place is okay. The setting is really nice and does have that historical feel. The food and the portions are good-sized. There is a LOT to pick from. I just wish it wasn't so crowded all the time - which is typical of the Civic/Van Ness area. Sometimes it is a hit a miss. Sometimes you are seated right away and sometimes if you just want to buy some cake you just stand there hoping someone would acknowledge you so you can go on your way.
author: Cathy B.

description:
So I went to the sandwich line here to grab a quick take-out lunch and I got a 'corned-beef' sandwich, plus a small potato salad which came with it - for $10

The sandwich had NOTHING in it except corned beef and some bread of the type you can just buy in Safeway. No cheese, veggies, butter..nothing!

The potato salad I didn't get to try because they didn't include any utensils in my bag

I could have made this myself in about two minutes. 1 star
author: Yan S.

description:
I came here with a couple of friends, one being Mr. Billy S, and had high expectations. After quickly being seated, it took a bit to get a waiter to help us- he was playing the piano and singing. The food was decent, but definitely not worth the price. In fact, the price was a bit absurd. I understand I'm not paying just for the food, but for the atmosphere, but when I'm dropping quite a few dollars on a meal, I want my food to be enjoyable, and it wasn't to say the least.

Another huge problem is the parking. You can't find parking anywhere around here unless its late at night and you find an empty spot on the street, otherwise you're paying $20 for the standard Opera House/Theatre parking garages.
author: Mace M.

description:
When I'm in the mood for large portions of above average American diner food, I think of Max's. I love the Patti Melt here, but I've enjoyed all the dishes I've tried at Max's over the years.

And Max's has my favorite desert, a chocolate macaroon crumble, which is basically vanilla ice cream, covered with a coconut macaroon that's been covered in dark chocolate sauce, and tons of it. I've tried the other deserts, and they've all been good, but this one remains my favorite.

Portions are so large here that I can't imagine eating both dinner and desert in one sitting, so I usually go for either one or the other, otherwise it's a waste of food.

I've eaten at the Max's Opera Cafe in SF, Max's Cafe in Redwood City, Max's Cafe in Palo Alto and Max's Restaurant and Bar in Burlingame, and they've all been pretty much the same.
author: Alexander O.

description:
1. They sing (opera) to you.
2. There is a live piano player.
3. The plates of food are enormous.
4. Fake alligator skin apoulstry.
5. Delicious.
author: K. C.

description:
Max's is way overpriced (what is the bagel with lox, $9? $13? who are they kidding) with only decent food. The reuben bites were on the low side of decent.

I didn't care for the music either.

Don't go here if you want a cheap, quick snack.
author: Paul S.

description:
Max's is a staple of the Civic Center area. For a late night dessert, it's a popular place.  For lunch, it's a popular place. Heck, for dinner it's a popular place. This particular location has gone through a recent remodel. It's a bit more "diner" feel now with blacks and whites being a central color theme. Menu hasn't changed much though prices have gone up slightly.

The food is pretty consistent and usually fairly large in portion though you'll find newer items on the menu will usually start off with larger portions and then are pared down the longer they stay on the menu.  I'm particularly partial to the meat loaf, enchilada pie (which is usually a special), chicken pot pie (which has gotten smaller over time), and the turkey burger max.  For salads, give a try to Guy's Chinese Chicken salad though go for a half unless you are really hungry.

In the evenings the waitpeople also double as entertainment and will go up and sing with the pianst.  They started charging an extra surcharge for the evenings so expect a somewhat pricier dinner than you might be used to from a Max's.

For lunch, which is primarily when I go there (since I work in the area), I definitely recommend getting there at least 10 minutes before noon to beat the lunch crowd, especially during the holidays when afternoon performances of "The Nutcracker" are going on nearby and the restaurant is filled with families eating lunch prior to the show.

Overall, it's one of the better places around the Civic Center area and worth a visit or two.  Remember to save room for dessert!
author: Nelson W.

description:
Great location, can't argue that.  And the crowd, is pretty funky, Ballet, Symphony, concert goers, that's fun.  There's a vibe about the place.  

It's a little too casual, like a deli.  But without the great deli food.  I'm a walker arounder.  Before I eat somewhere, I'm peering between kissing couples to see what they ordered.  And after all the walking, studying, thorough research, I went with a salad.  What's that telling you? 

I snacked a little before coming here, big mistake.  I should have ordered a burger or something straight forward.  The salad blew!

If I read some reviews before going, I should have ordered a phatty dessert.  I agree with the rules, sayings painted up in the restaurant.  Give me some paint, I'll get some shit up there.  But, it was neither funny, witty, or even purposeful.  I wanted to shoot that placard with a shotgun.  

And the waitstaff singing opera?  How stoned were you Max designing that concept?  Have a seal and a beachball - that would be fun.
author: Michael R.

description:
How the mighty have fallen. Max's was once the uber place to eat. And the old Max's Dinner on 3rd was just as fab.  Boy...do times change.

Max's Opera Cafe is now sad. A sad shell of what it use to be. This was the place to go and get great food and great portions.  My visit last week was hands down one of the worst food experiences.

First, let's talk staff. Or better yet, the lack of any caring staff. There was a wait (hmmm..wait till word gets out). We were then rushed..yes rushed..to a table by an older host gentleman who threw our menus on the table and then left. Such a homey feel!

It took about 10 minutes for our server to come over and say she would be right with us. How kind of her to stop by.  When she came back, her greeting was "And what do you want to eat?" That should have been the sign to get out.  The burger I ordered was bland and not cooked to what I asked. The Matzo Ball soup was watered down.  What happened to the great bread basket they use to serve? We just got some generic French bread.

I remember going to Max's in the 1990's when it was great. Sorry to see what's happened.

Dan Shelton
Don't Call It Frisco blog
http://dontcallitfriscoblog.blogspot.com/
author: Dont Call It Frisco D.

description:
What a terrible night at the Max's Opera.  Was Madame Butterfly getting ready to kill herself?  Gosh, terrible service and high ass prices.

I went there around 9:15 on a Thurday night and they told us they were closing at 10:00 p.m. (they ended up staying open to way after that).  In any case, we were seated  on the Bar/Piano side about 12 feet away.  Big mistake!  The noise from the bar folks and the noise from the piano player made it hard to talk.  Also, the people eating near the bar were very very loud; subsequently, they had to yell to hear each other.  

Next time, I'll go there for lunch like I have done at least 4 times before.  

Now back to the service that night.  There was one lone young man talking orders and fetching the food for circa 25 people;    So herein that starts the problem with attentive  and timely service.  The water lady kept giving me water when I said no I don;t want anymore water.  She just was not listening.  The hot breads that showed up with the water were great.  

 I ordered the Broiled Salmon w/lemon Dijon sauce w/toasted capers, broccoli and smashed potatoes $19.99.  The salmon was cooked just right and had great flavor,   the broccoli was cooked Al dente like I like it, but it needed some type of light butter sauce on it or more seasoning and a light tossing of olive oil; however,  the  so-called smashed potatoes were terrible!!!  They were not entirely creamed and moist like they should be. Throughout the potato mound were here huge chunks of potatoes, so I got 1/3 chunks and 2/3 dry creamed potatoes.  Yuck.  The cooked must have been lazy.   

Now comes the terrible service.  Not once did the server come back to our table to see if we needed something.  I wanted to flag him down, but he was so busy serving that it was hard to catch his eye.  Also, he did not notice that there was was a silent request for an extra beer and well as a silent request for our plates to be taken.  When a server sees an empty glass and the beer bottle at the edge of the table they are supposed to come by and see if the patron wants another one or clear them off the table.  When plates are on the edge of the table with the silverware in the 4:00 position, they are supposed to clear the plates.  None of that happened.   When we were finally able to catch his attention, we were almost finished with our food, (I left a large amount of the potatoes on my plate since they were so terrible). Amount 40 minutes into our meal, another woman was running food to the customers, but was not taking any orders, so our man was stretched thin.

We noticed that tons of people were walking about the are and were coming into the restaurant (I believe that the symphony or the opera just let out 'cause people were all dressed up.)  Also, circa  10:00 p.m. (when they were supposed to close), a huge party of about 25 people all dressed up came in and sat in the semi-private sunken banquet area.  The area does not have any sound-proof windows or partitions, just open partitions.  We were next to the people and it was so noisy that I was getting agitated and could not hear myself speak.  Luckily we were finished and got the check and out out of there.

1 Star for overall service
1 Star for the lumpy smashed potatoes
1 Star for the waiter for not checking in with us at least 5-10 minutes after he left our food
1 Star for Maxes for not staffing the restaurant properly and making the lone waiter bust his booty.
1 Star for expensive prices for a diner type setting.
1 Star for the noise in the Bar area
1 Star for not putting up noise proof partitions in the open banquet area that is within 2 feet of the upper dining area.
1 Star for the loud Piano noise
author: Vanilla C.

description: I have been to the Max's in Corte Madera more times than I can count, and this place is just like it. I ordered the hot pastrami sandwich, as always. It was piled high with Corned Beef. Not Pastrami. Whatever, I was hungry so I ate it. The corned beef had a lot of fat, but it was still good. When we first got there at 10:30 on a Sunday morning it was empty, but it filled up with old Jewish people (of course!) as we were leaving 2 hours later. It is a good standard place that feels like the East Coast. Just try and walk by the desserts on the way out without licking the glass...
author: Allison M.

description: We go to Max's on average once a month and always feel good about our meal.  Crabcakes are a great deal for $17!
author: J.K. S.

description: Max's is delicious.  The food is melt-in-your-mouth flavorful.  The food is a bit expensive, but they give you a lot of it, so it's worth every penny.  My wife and I often share a single entree and leave completely satisfied.  The desserts are fantastic, and often I'm so full from the meal that I can only take a bite or two of dessert and have to take the rest home!  There's constant live piano music and It's fabulous hearing a staff member do a song from time to time.  I've celebrated my birthday here a number of times.  The waitstaff is almost always on the ball, and out of the score of times I've eaten here over twenty years I've only been disappointed once by a waiter who was a space cadet.  It took him a while to get us our food, but it was still scrumptious.  Look for "Max's rules" --- they're very funny.  Max's has other locations around the bay area, and it was a sad day when their sandwich shop near the Embarcadero closed -- it was my favorite lunch place.
author: Chris C.

description: We are fans of the Max's in San Rafael so when we needed a place to have a graduation lunch, it was a no brainer to try the Max's at the Opera house. The menu is smaller, but the food and service were very good.
author: Lisa M.

description: Had a half slice of the Max's Fantasy Torte. More like death by chocolate... (hurts so good)
author: Maximillian M.

description:
ugh going here the other day was the worst decision i've made in a really long time. 

yeah i used to like this place, ya know, good diner-type food i guess. but i only go like every 5 years and i thought i could pop in and out the other day before going to work and it just wasn't a good
author: Georgia W.

description: The food is great and the portions are large.  Outstanding desserts!  In the evening the servers sing.
author: Liss J.

description: Been to this place a million times.  Yummy food.  Better than Hard Rock Cafe.  Great deserts.  I really enjoy the atmosphere.
author: Cynthia B.

description: Waitress inattentive, order incorrect, generally a "we will never return" experience.
author: John F.

description:
OK, so I haven't eaten at this location yet, but I have eaten at the one in the Stanford mall, and the diner that used to be at 3rd and folsom a lot.

BEST REUBEN IN THE CITY hands down.  I have not had better.  (If anyone knows better, PLEASE LET ME KNOW!!!).  Corned beef is good, but Pastrami is better.

If they have the same menu as the one in PA, they have those aged steaks, which are pretty good too.  Service has always been good, esp at the opera cafe, where they sing.

If I remember right, they also have a "fi' dolla shake" that was damn good.  It better be, right?
author: Fong L.

description:
We had Waiters on Wheels bring our food to the office. I had the Shrimp Louie-- big shrimp (deveined, thank GOD), lots of veggies chopped into little pieces, and big slices of avocado and egg wedges. The Thousand Island dressing was their own recipe that had a bit of horseradish in it... of course that was PERFECT for the shrimp. 
I don't know if I'd eat someplace where they're all singing at me, but I might put up with it for another one of those salads!
author: Jessica O.

description:
Everyone that works here is rad, especially Megan.

The recently remodled from tacky to modern tacky....very impressive.

Full bar. Happy girl.

Food? Hey, you want a pulled pork sandwhich, this place will give you a bombass one. 

And they sing...singing waiters and waitresses? Come on! How cool is that??

Downside?....not enough ::correction requested:: raisen ROLLS in the ROLL bowl. I hate sourdough Megan! Ugh.
author: Stacy L.

description:
Big hearty portions of everything, so be prepared to be stuffed at the end of your meal. I asked for one scoop of ice cream after my meal and got four scoops of ice cream. Too big to possibly finish. What a waste of food. I told my server I guess Max's cafe is contributing to obesity within America. Ha ha..

Test your server to see if  the know their stuff, so you can get free food. For example if the server asks you "how everything is" you get a free beverage. Example 2 if your server does not bring you ketchup and mustard before your burger arrives, you get a free dessert. This type of service in restaurants is unusual, very unusual. Our server forgot the ketchup but we didn't say anything because we felt it could have been awkward to call someone out on something so trivial.  

Another cool aspect of Max's is the opera singers are your servers. Pure talent. Huh?
author: Kelli H.

description: Arrrrgh!! This place used to be decent at best and now it is even worse. I will never go back!! normally I write really detailed yelper feedback but all I can say is "STAY AWAY!!"
author: Jack H.

description:
One visit.  Saw latkes on the menu; hadn't had the real thing in years.

Still haven't.  No salt, no flavor or any kind, no schmaltz.  Barely grated -- more like shredded -- potato formed into a patty and briefly browned.  Perfect for those health food nuts that think anything that tastes good must be bad for you.   That took 20 minutes?

Better you should get what are incorrectly described as "hash browns" at your local lunch counter.  BTW:  I make real hash browns, from leftover mashed, browned chopped and turned, browned chopped and turned . . . until they are half fry crust.  Think I'll go make some now.
author: Gary M.

description:
This is the place my friends and I like to go to after a night at the movies.  I love their salads and we usually take turns choosing a dessert and splitting it.

The people who work there are nice and service is pretty good too!
author: Joni M.

description:
Yes, this place is a bit overpriced. But hey, you're eating at a place next to two or three auditoriums that have venues with hungry people. Sometimes its good to experience an overpriced place to understand why it's overpriced, then decide if its worth it or not.

I went there after watching a piano recital; place was conveninet and I didn't have to feel cheap by walking to the burger king. Had their ground sirloin steak entree; it's pretty good. Didn't knew it came with baked potatoes AND creamed spinach, along with onion fries. At $17, yes it is a lot. but then again the next time i had a craving for Max's opera, I opted for San Tung and ended up foring $20 for my meal of chicken wings and black bean noodles. 

Lesson? you may think its overpriced until you go to another joint and end up paying the same amount. Know what to order and you'll be fine. also, buy their creamed horseradish. or not. haha i just found it at bevmo for $2.50; this place charged $4.50, but it seemed more than 12oz
author: Jeremy W.

description:
Sad to say Max's disappoints.  The maitre d' refused to seat us at any of the many empty tables even though we were first in line.  He said we had to wait while he wrote the names of all the folks in the long line behind us and then wait longer until he called us.  Why?  He was overwhelmed and had no customer relations skills.

Food quality and service are inconsistent, sometimes good, sometimes very bad.  The wait staff is overworked.  We've had yummy chopped liver one time and dried up dark inedible pastrami another time.  

Too bad.  Max's used to be so good.  Beware!
author: darcy f.

description:
This is strictly a cheesecake review. I've never actually sat down and eaten there, just taken out cheesecake. 
The cheesecake here rocks - big dense, creamy, awesome crust. NY style. It ain't cheap, but no worse than other places with comparable cheesecake.
author: John A.

description: Great place for lunch or pre-SFS dinner. Good food, good service, and not too loud!
author: Jay D.

description: I love coming to Max's before or after seeing SF Ballet! The menu is full of delicious options. The waiters are nice and efficient, and the service has always been good. It's usually pretty crowded, but I enjoy the busy atmosphere. It's also nice when one of the staff gets up and sings a song! The people working there are quite talented!
author: Leslie S.

description: The Irish Coffee was disgustingly strong. Yuck. But thank God that I tried and saw some other goodies. The desserts were all delectible, apple pie, cheesecake, carrot cake. The burgers looked great. Reminded me of NY in some weird way. The opera looming in the background made it conducive to an avant garde birthday celebration! Late night hours and ample parking on Van Ness.
author: Andrew K.

description: Okay, four stars for food and service because there aren't that many other good options within a reasonably short walking distance of work.  Minus one star because it is so close to work and you can't avoid seeing co-workers and that can be annoying sometimes when you just want to enjoy a juicy pastrami sandwich alone.  They get that star back for the pastrami sandwich though.  And the delicious tuna caper melt and shrimp louie salad.  So why only three stars?  Because for some reason they charge more for food than the Max's in Burlingame and Redwood City.  Add the SF surcharges and that just plain sucks that you have to pay more because you're in the city.
author: Maria L.

description:
Pretty good food overall....I like the matzo ball soup and the pastrami on rye.  The quality here is much better than other Max's locations that I've been to.  However, don't kid yourself, this isn't a true Jewish deli.  This is sort of a half-assed version.....more like a TGI Friday's with a few kosher deli items.  

All in all, however, this is the closest you'll get to a true deli in SF.
author: Aaron M.

description:
I've had consistently good food at all of the Max's restaurants, which has me wondering if everything comes prepackaged. Obviously, it does not, but they must have some expert chefs to make it taste right every time.

I miss the Opera part of Max's, but enjoy it nonetheless.
Just split a slice of cake and be done with it.
author: Drew T.

description:
This Max's has a very different vibe from the Palo Alto location, but same quality of food.  I'm a big fan of the relaxed atmosphere and huge menu.  Even if you are on a diet, you should be able to find something appropriate.  However, with all the selections, you'll probably have a hard time avoiding the gastronomic goodness.

If you're planning on dinner conversation, try to get a place away from the piano.  The waitstaff tend to be hit and miss as well.

Also, when ordering the Iced Tea, specify that you'd like the fresh brewed.  I'm a huge fan of this!  When they give you refills though, they revert back to regularly brewed tea.
author: Matt Y.

description:
The food definitely had huge portions.  Their Mac & Cheese was pretty filling and had variations of cheese. The Roast Beef sandwich was pretty good.  I usually ask for a box and put half of the portion before eating, good food for lunch the next day at work.  I also had my first Matzo ball experience and it was cool.  

Not a big fan of opera but visit the place since it's open a little later.
author: JM C.

description: Ugh, I am so sorry to see what has happened to this place! Many years ago, this was a better-run restaurant with decent food and higher standards. I came in on a Wednesday at 5 PM and the restaurant was practically empty. Even so, it took about 15 minutes for a server to come and acknowledge me because they were "still deciding who's going to handle which area." I ordered hastily because I was uncertain when I was going to see her again. Initially, I got some tea but no sweeteners and I was getting ready to go locate some sugar packets myself when the server finally returned and retrieved them for me. The server's attitude was actually very nice and the food items I ordered came promptly, but I just didn't experience the quality I remembered from 10 or 20 years ago. I received a trio of greasy undercooked sliders and a bowl of bland matzo ball soup - I lost my appetite and couldn't finish either. What really made my skin crawl was that every single piece of silverware on the table was dirty. During a trip to the ladies room, I discovered a filthy environment featuring sticky floors.
author: L. Elise R.

description:
I love coming here after watching a performance close-by.  I've always liked the atmosphere and the waiters/waitresses who sing is just great.  Service is always good.

The food..  We're here to eat right?  Great and sometimes HUGE portions.  A normal meal will be between $20 - $30.  Totally worth it.
author: R G.

description:
So I've had two FANTASTIC experiences here, and one EHHH experience.

The two times I came here with my girlfriend at the time and the food was superb, the service was prompt, and all our servers were amazing singers.

There was one time i was here with my younger brother and his friends for his birthday. The food took forever and the server forgot to bring out the cake (thanks for ruining the surprise).
