We left VERY unhappy and the manager actually chased us down to apologize and give us a $10 giftcard back to Max's. I will give them the benefit of the doubt and assume that that particular server was a bad egg and still give them four stars.
author: Tony L.

description:
It's Max's need I say more. If you're up to pocket some chang and want to show off some out of town guests and also fill them up, go to Max's. I work nearby the Opera Cafe, so it's the one I go to. Gumbo, gumbo gumbo!! It's really good. 

Even though it's pricey, the portions are huge. Salads are huge, sandwiches are moderately large, and the soup is huge. 5 bucks for soup, well worth it. You can easily down 40 dollars in one sitting, but you'll have leftovers. But then again, the prices could be worse in San Francisco. 5 STARS!
author: Michael C.

description:
Great chicken marsala! Love there pear salad too! My bf and I have done the sandwiches there, but not too impressed!

I haven't tried their desserts, but I'll have to go back.

We like the one in Stanford best!
author: Diana B.

description:
In so many ways, Max's is not my cup of tea.  The Broadway singing, the mediocre dessert compensated by giving you an enormous portion of mediocre dessert.  

However, this is the only place open late enough when my friends and I need a non-dinner place to discuss the movies we just saw at the Opera Plaza movie theatre.   And I have had many fond memories, with my legs stretched out on the comfortable booth seat,  eating dessert I don't like, pretend we are a bunch of old farts in a Manhattan all-night diner a la Woody Allen, and feeling my brain cells finally reviving just little bit since college days by a nice, stimulating intellectual conversations on the latest worthwhile film.  

Oh, Max's is good to me.
author: Candice B.

description:
GREAT FUN FOR KIDS AND GROWN UP KIDS

I forgot about this place until I was thinking of a fun place to have dinner with kids. I have such fond memories of eating here and basically gorging myself on too much of everything. HUGE portions make it easy to share and still not feel guilty about sharing a dessert too, which is heavenly. The wait staff take turns singing at the mic hamming it up, which is kind of the shtick of Max's "Opera" Cafe. You can't take it seriously, you have to stay light and breezy, and don't expect any kind of intimacy because it's loud, crowded and has a super "busy" feel. Great place to take someone who's not a great conversationalist, since there will be a lot to talk about.
author: Safiya N.

description:
A unusual place but in a good way. It has a diner like atmosphere but the food is anything but. My g/f and i got apps. entrees and had to get desert after seeing a birthday table get this HUGE piece of choco. cake. Love Max's Laws. The piano player makes for a great atmosphere and then when the waiters and waitress sing accompanied by the piano man who could not want to come back. The food is fantastic and you get a lot of it.
Our waiter asked us if we were going to a show, that way he could get us our food as quickly as possible so we could make the show time...talk about service.
We enjoyed this place so much we came back the next night!

Highly recommended
author: Matt F.

description: Portions are quite large -- the one way Max's O tries to live up to its faux Jewish deli brand. The prices are not low, but not at all bad for the mix of fancy food and diner portions. The desserts are scrumptious. I go to meetings and conventions up the hill, and usually try to hit Max's a time or two each event. I also like it when catching in movie in that part of town.
author: alamedabrian m.

description: Bartender was horrible!  Forgot I was sitting there and when I reminded her about my drink...gave me a rude curt comment and proceeded to be abusive!  Got the manager and sat somewhere else. How does she still work here?  If you want good service...go to Water Bar or 1 Market... They are wonderful, courteous, and professional.  Oh, that might be why she can't work at those restaurants!
author: Janet B.

description:
This is like an upscale Denny's with better food.  

Salads are pretty delicious, but overpriced.  
the rest of the food is just ok...nothing great.

In a city with so many good eats, I am surprised this place gets packed.
author: Matt V.

description:
although i had a bit of an in, my Max's experience has always been good. A bit crowded, but i love the atmosphere!

I originally thought the idea of singing waitstaff would be stupid, annoying, and lame, but i was wrong. The waitresses and waiters who do sing all have good voices which help my hot soup and grilled cheese (with Brie!!) down into my tummy.

I used to love going here on a cold day getting a hot meal, eating said delicious hot meal, and then going to sleep! 

 I miss Max's. 

sigh...
author: angelo b.

description:
I have been here a couple of times and always had a good time. I could be biased since they always sing the songs i like. The size of their portions is crazy and it may not be the best, but it is still good. If on the desserts you need two hands to hold it up, congrats, you have impressed me. 

The idea of having your servers being the entertainers is inventive...and cheap, the idea seems like  a sleazy jazz bar business model, but it works well here. I personally think this restaurant is a good place to eat and be entertained if you are having a brain fart on what to do that night.
author: Ray H.

description:
Service we got was excellent.

Food portion was big but a bit on a pricey side.

I ordered a tuna with asparagus & artichokes, it was ok.

One thing I love though is the Chocolate Sundae.
author: jubi l.

description: Great for large parties.  The singing is good most of the time, but it does get a bit loud for a great conversation.  The food choices are great which means that there is something for everyone.  Most dishes have super large portions, but there are always things available in a smaller size.  Solid wine selection.  The matzo ball soup is  one of the second best in the city.
author: Yevgenia F.

description:
I would recommend this place for desserts, but not for the main course. Food was mediocre. Service was ok.

Great place to go on a date for dessert because on the weekends there are usually singings.
author: Kaitlyn B.

description:
Two, count them two reviews in one!

Take Out:  I've never had an issue with ordering by phone and then picking it up.  Whether it be a dessert or an entree, the food has always been warm and oh so yummy!  I particularly love the blue cheese salad adding grilled steak on top.  Their desserts are huge...and yes I mean Leaning Tower of Pisa size.  My BF and I usually share a piece of their cheese cake although it could easily be shared by three individuals.

Late Night Dining:  It's okay, but you can tell that some of the wait staff sooooo do not want to be there.  I can't remember which salad I ordered but I do know it was okay.  It had chicken, avocado and red onion in it, however the red onion was in extreme abundance and infiltrated the salad way too much!

I like Max's Opera Cafe.  It's right across Van Ness and I can be there in 2 minutes.  :OP
author: Shane P.

description: I went here for Thanksgiving, so this might be kind of skewed since it wasn't a regular day. But the food was pretty tasty, the prices were good for what it was, and the service was not bad. Again, I can't really comment on how it is on a regular day because I haven't experienced it. Although I walk past this place fairly often on the way to class and it almost always looks packed and smells great outside; but for all I know on the inside people might be thinking "...this place is more lame than polio..." So yeah, what I experienced was good.
author: Josh S.

description:
There is something at once charming and really kinda -- um -- weird about a waiter with a ponytail singing Rogers & Hammerstein while you're hovering over your salad bowl trying not to spill dressing on yourself.

Do you make eye contact with the man singing his heart out?  Even though your mouth is full?

Or do you ignore him so as not to chew at him while he's being so earnest?

Or are you supposed to stop eating altogether?  (Which would suck because hi, I'm here because I'm hungry.)

But assuming you can work out the "What am I supposed to do while he's singing?" thing, Max's is fine.

The menu is expensive.  The food is certainly passable, but you don't go to "passable" restaurants in SF unless they have something to offer.  In this case: huge portions, and plenty of kitsch.
author: kristy s.

description: I went to Max's for dinner before the Symphony on Saturday night with three other people. We all had great meals and excellent service. If anything, the portions are a bit too much - which is wonderful... and the food was great!
author: Rachel M.

description:
i ordered the ahi tuna with sweet and sour ginger noddle salad. it tasted really bad. i had already ordered it sans wasabi sauce. there were only about five slices of tuna and the rest was the salad. i expected more noddles than salad. the tuna was pretty tasteless with most of the tuna cooked rather than raw. if it were me i would not pay $25.99 for such bad food and also such little food. it was only because someone was treating us did i decide the ahi tuna which in general was a first time for me. now i'm skeptical about ordering ahi tuna from anywhere!

my bf's cheeseburger on the other hand was very good and so were the fries and fried onions. i'm starting to think max's is more known for their burgers. if i were to come back again i'd order a burger.

apparently most of the waiters who work here are opera students so occasionally they will sing but we werent very impressed.
author: Helen L.

description:
K-RAPPY!!!!!  This place has gone downhill.  Maybe the one in marin is better.
Our red-head waitress had the personality of a wet napkin.  She was so not into being a server...she must not need the tips.
Still tipped her, but not as much as I would have.  Her service matched the  quality of the food.
author: Victor J.

description: Went to wonderful Nutcracker ballet and rated it A+, then evening took a nose dive when we then went to MAX'S for dinner, rated it an F-.   Waiter Michael seemed like he HATES his job and where it was too.  He was so unattentive that we had to ask for service over & over.  Get a new job, Mikey, for everyone's sake!  Don't wonder why u get 10% diss on tips!    And, then to pour salt on a wound -- the food was practically inedible!  I got the Cheesesteak and it was DRIPPING IN OIL, (should be grease free), I had to ask Mikey for more napkins 3 times and even 4 napkins could not soak up the OIL  so that I could only barely eat 1/4 of it.  My friend thought to play it safe with a burger but it was so overcooked that she left half of it.  The dinner rolls were so stale, old & hard that I could barely cut it with a serrated knife.  FOOD - DISGUSTING AND DRIPPING IN OIL!  SERVICE - SUCKS (MIKEY PLS GET A NEW JOB).  This place really ended an a bad note, to an otherwise nice afternoon at the ballet!
author: bette s.

description: We had the freakiest waiter here - I've had him twice actually. He's a white guy, 50s with a receding grey hairline, and he has a crazy smile plastered on his face like he's a clown in a horror movie. He messed up EVERYONE's order at the table and DID NOT LISTEN to a thing anyone said about what they wanted. He brought me something I didn't order after clarifying what I wanted. He was a disaster. The place is comfortable enough and the food is decent. Avoid the freaky clown face waiter.
author: G G.

description:
Unfortunately it appears as though there is new ownership at this location, and the patrons, kitchen and wait staff bear the brunt of the corners which are obviously being cut. The quality of the service and the food has gone way down in the past year, which is unfortunate because I used to adore Max's! 

I've loved going to Max's for over 15 years, both in SF and the former Walnut Creek location. I work directly across the street from the Van Ness location so I've frequented their deli counter quite often for lunch over the past 3 years. Unfortunately, however, the past couple of times that I've ordered in, seated at a table,  the wait staff has been overwhelmed, the orders were mixed up, and the food was not very good quality. For example:

May 2009 - I had dinner before the symphony with a group of about 5-6 people. I understand the restaurant was busy because of the groups of people going to the theater, but isn't that the reason for the location? Max's Opera cafe, next to the Opera house? Unfortunately, however, on a Saturday night they were way understaffed so the experience turned out to be downright painful.  I had ordered the Caesar salad with salmon, a $15.99 dish, not chump change for a salad. It came to the table after I had to wait while all of the other dishes were served, and it did not have any salmon. Or Parmesan cheese, or even dressing. It was a bowl of bare lettuce! The server somehow didn't even notice this (or maybe they were hoping I wouldn't). So when I brought this to the server's attention they responded with, "Oh, yeah, we're pretty busy. I'll see what I can do". After 15 minutes of waiting for them to come back, while everyone else around the table were finishing their meal, another server brought me a tiny little condiment dish of dressing to go with my bare lettuce. And still no salmon. Long story short, I clearly did  not get what I ordered, I was unable to finish my meal because it took so long to straighten it out, and the server didn't apologize or offer to take it off the bill! I couldn't even talk to the manager because apparently they were too busy calming down other irate customers. I was so shocked at how atrocious the experience was that I chose not to return for the better part of this past year.

But since time heals all wounds, and who knows if that was just a particularly off day, I decided to try it out one more time and give them a chance. So, just yesterday, I made one more effort to have lunch before going to see Wicked at the Orpheum with my sister. When we were seated, I had asked to start our meal with their famous cheesy garlic bread appetizer that I've adored since I was in high school. The server didn't know what I was talking about, and apparently they don't serve it anymore. This news broke my heart, it was an institution of Max's for as long as I can remember! If anyone is reading this review that works there, please push to bring it back!

So, instead of the bread, I asked for the Portabello mushroom appetizer, and specifically said we'd like it before our meal. Then my sister ordered a burger and I ordered a soup and salad. 

And a few minutes later, a new server delivered our food, but apparently they had forgotten to put the mushrooms in the system and our main dishes were brought out but there was no appetizer. And my Caesar salad didn't have the anchovies I ordered or the right dressing and the croutons were very hard and stale (I guess I just can't win with that dish!). So since by this point we had a new server (the original one was MIA), I went ahead and asked them to cancel the appetizer since we already got our meals and the kitchen hadn't started making the mushrooms so no harm no foul. But lo and behold, ten minutes later a THIRD server brought us the appetizer half way through our meal, even though I asked for it to be canceled. And we couldn't find our original server, and they charged us for the mushrooms even though we barely touched them through our meal.

All I can say is that I don't know what's going on with this location, maybe it's the stressed economy, but I'm not returning until I know that their service and management has improved significantly and the patrons can expect consistent quality. What an unfortunate turn of events to find out one of our favorite restaurants has gone so down hill. :(
author: Steenie K.

description:
I guess if you want meat, potatoes and dessert, this place would satisfy. But, I was looking for something healthier. I got the beet salad. Big mistake, the nice colorful beets are on top of a mound of coleslaw with mayo- gross. My friend got the grilled cheese sandwich and fries plate. I can attest that the fries are good - meaty with a nice, not too salty seasoning. Plates are large and would fill a big appetite. I do have to give a large thumbs up for the big stuffed mushroom appetizer- I would go back just for that. So, I would say that your experience definitely would depend upon what you order.
A comment to the waiter, you never know who will be providing the tip, so give equal attention to all parties.
author: kim y.

description: I'm glad to see that this place hasn't closed like some of the other restaurants nearby.  I live across the street from this place, so they're my nice neighbors that I turn to for a simple meal every now and then when my time is short.  I laugh every time I walk by their side door that says something to the effect of "We don't care for critics or their critiques, so don't bother us with either."  I suppose that means they aren't reading any of this.  In any case, it's an OK place with friendly service, large portions, and in a convenient location.
author: Tom F.

description: Went for lunch today. Sat on the Golden Gate side. Nice and bright, and great view of the homeless denizens. The menu is vast and my patty melt ordered medium arrived promptly, cooked as I ordered, and very good. The fries and cole slaw were also very good. There is one helluva lot of food on the plate and it is a great value if you are a huge eater. Next time one half a sandwich and salad. When you order iced tea, two glasses with ice arrive and a pot of hot tea. Nice touch. The wait staff is friendly and efficient. I will be back....
author: David L.

description: consistent.  Love the Chinese chicken salad.  very friendly staff
author: Ryan L.

description: We used to come here when it was fresh, and there was excitement in the air. It's not bad, but its kind of stale.  Usually get the giant sandwiches, but we had appetizers this evening. Good, but $16 for 2 crab cakes? Come on. We were too embarrassed to mention to the waitress that the menu shows 3. And, we shouldn't be put in that position. Greek Meze was fine, and lamb meatballs excellent.probably will try other places next time.
author: Mike D.

description: We had lunch at Max because it was on the way to the Theater - Their location is great but food and staff not so good (it seemed they do not want to work). The food was ok but the service was slow. The couple on the next table got the wrong drink and had to return it. The Host is in the middle of the floor - never seen that before - no one by the door to welcome you.
author: Gigi W.

description: I haven't eaten here since I moved from San Francisco but it use to be my favorite for good ole New York style Jewish deli sandwiches. Good soups also. Hope it keeps serving the area through these slow economic times.
author: Johnny B.

description: I hadn't been to Max's in a few years so the reduced menu was disappointing, but that wouldn't have earned it this bad review. It was 5:30 before opera and symphony. The restaurant was busy but there were empty tables, and we were never warned by the hostess or wait staff that there could be a wait for food. I ordered a cobb salad, my companion ordered a lamb burger medium well. 30 minutes later we flagged the server down to check where our food was - only then did she update us. A few minutes later it arrived. The burger was brown on the outside and raw - I mean bacteria cold - on the inside. My salad - the greens were brown and wilted, as if they'd been dressed for at least an hour. Piled on top were dry chicken breast with no dressing to moisten it and a pile of brown and somewhat slimy mushrooms. Have you ever gotten up from a table in a restaurant to walk your own plate back to the kitchen because the wait staff can't be flagged? Incredible! The hostess offered to put our orders back in and comp us part of the bill, but we canceled the meal and walked out. That's my last visit to Max's.
author: Lyssa F.

description: I just jumped over to Max's for my lunch break for some dessert so I cant atttest to the rest of the food. Only the mud pie and the service. Dude was pleasant, moved at a good pace and got me back to work right on time.  The mud pie was purdy f-ing good but I dont recommend eating it on your own unless you are shooting for a diabetic coma, which I am just coming out of as I type this.
author: Dru P.

description:
This is a really good place to go before the opera or
symphony.  I've never been to the opera but my wife 
dragged me to the symphony (turned out to b great).
There are a lot of really trendy small eateries down in 
that area but the menu at max's is unbelievable.  They 
have it all.  Even breakfast but i'm not sure they serve it 
at night.  I bet they'd serve it if you asked though.
nice waitstaff too.
author: delbert t.

description: Probably the best ruben I have ever had, but the sides were fairly lame.  The drink I had was also really gross.  Like, not just medicore, but BAD.  But, its cool.  I love the opera singing in the middle of nowhere and the giant portions.  I feel like this is a total SF place that I should bring friends to.  Even though the food isnt all that amazing, the atmosphere is not to be found anywhere else.  Plus, I love me a good ruben.  Will deff be coming back here
author: Caleb R.

description: Good Restaurant went there late on a friday night the complimentary bread is good and the Sweet poatoe fries with the Chai sauce I believe are a must have. I had the Mojito Skir Steak which was excellent and washed it down with a Mojito, they had live Music playing (Pianist and a guy singing) Pretty good reataurant if its your plan C but not the best the food from the menu didnt seem to upscale for what the restaurant was trying to make itself be like.
author: Alberto R.

description: We've been going to Max's Opera Cafe for about five years now, and have always enjoyed the ambiance there.  It's a bright corner on Van Ness, with large windows facing the street and a lively atmosphere inside.  However, I have to say that the quality seems to have slipped, and on our last couple of visits, we found the food lacking.  First, the menu itself is much smaller.  Maybe the management wants to concentrate on the quality of fewer items, but the tastes don't seem to bear that out.  It also contradicts our expectations of delis with huge menus.  More to the point, their corned beef and pastrami, usually the signature ingredients of Jewish-style delis, were lacking.  The pastrami is apparently grilled, and the corned beef seemed like it came from a loaf of some kind.  Both meats just didn't have the flavors we savor, especially in a $13 sandwich.  Frankly, those meats are more flavorful at Tommy's Joynt up the street, and at half the price!  Perhaps the difference lies in the fact that Tommy's keeps those meats hot and moist on a steam table and hand carves them for each sandwich.  I hope that Max's will reconsider their approach to these sandwiches and entice us back again with an improved dining experience.
author: William L.

description: Bread was great. Food quantity was great. Had the beef brisket and it was tender and hearty.
author: Ben T.

description: Their "Grandma's Roast Chicken" is fantastic and so are the Latkes.  We order in usually from Waiters on Wheels but have been to the restaurant a couple of times.  The desserts are also excellent!
author: Mark T.

description: Very good food! Love the latkes and stuffed mushrooms! Pasta is good as well! Great atmosphere for families!
author: Raymond H.

description:
The food in general  is really not very good. It's busy all the time because it's close to the opera house. 

I ordered their steaks at least 5 times before, and 4 times of out 5 times, they were either too cooked, or they were so raw a dog would not eat it and I had to send them back.  If you just want deseert, I guess it would be okay to go.
author: Nick S.

description: Good food. Service was fast and not intrusive. Very pleased. Would dine here again
author: Xander T.

description: The word Mediocre comes to mind,Matza ball soup standard issue(not very flavorful)and the chicken liver sandwich was almost tastless,how they can make Chicken livers so bland is beyond me.Nothing memorable.Nice service however
author: james m.

description: I use to come here with my boss for lunch on Wednesday for the twice baked potato, bbq chicken, and caesar salad.  Just make sure you are dressed appropriately for this environment (business casual), I've always found it to be a little uppity
author: Rob J.

description:
Max's has been a go to for good food for us for twenty years, this week it moved into the don't go back to category. We went on Tuesday night and the food was ok, but the rolls which are usually great were hockey pucks. I asked for some that were fresher and the waiter brought more that were hockey pucks. We went back Wednesday night after a long day at the America's Cup on San Francisco Bay, looking for warm comfort food before driving home. We wanted a bowl of soup. The waitress told us that we couldn't have a bowl we could only have a cup. My sweetheart said he wanted more since that was what he was going to have for dinner. The waitress just kept telling him he couldn't have what he wanted. This was never about money although they charge $8 for a cup of soup. He got frustrated and ordered something else he didn't want. I decided to try again and asked to speak to the manager and give him an opportunity to make happy customers, His answer was the same, he couldn't give us a bowl of soup. When I asked him he told me that there was not one vessel in the entire restaurant that he could use as a bowl to sell a customer a bowl of soup.
This is from a place that prints Max's Rules on every napkin and they are all about the customer having a good experience. Perhaps they should read their own rules!
We left without eating and won't be back. Max's has gone from a go to to a don't go there place.
author: Linda D.

description: I actually got an upset stomach from eating a slice of cheesecake here. It wasn't worth it....the cheesecake was definitely not the best. The service on the other hand was great, and I got "treated" to dessert, for which I was grateful....but it would have been better if the dessert had actually been enjoyable, and it wasn't. I would never eat here again.
author: Rox M.

description: No wait at noon on a Saturday. Wanted breakfast, but menu is limited at noon. So ordered Mexican omelette. Very very good. The biscut wasn't very good and the butter that came with it was not butter. There was lipstick on my glass of apple juice. Service was fairly prompt. They have a rule, think it's Max #16 that they must come back in 4 minutes after main course is served or the Niagra Falls piece of cake is free. Interesting. Forgot to time the server for our service, but did notice it was leas than 4 minutes for other patrons. They have this gignormous chocolate eclair in the display booth. I don't think even 2 grown adults could eat it. It's fricking huge!
author: Red S.

description: Today I decided to give myself a birthday treat. Lunch at Max's is always the same, tasty, enjoyable, no unpleasant surprises.  Prices are reasonable, certainly in line with the food quality.  The last time there my husband and I, along with two friends were celebrating our wedding vows, taken the hour before at City Hall.  I always like their brew-at-the-table pot of iced tea.  When I do it myself the strength is perfect, the lemon and sweetness just right.  Instead of bread they serve, when requested, two warm rolls, one sourdough, one raisin.  Again, excellent.  Today I had the Chicken Caesar Wrap with Arugula Salad.  Their Caesar dressing may not be totally authentic (but whose is, nowadays), however I really like it. I especially enjoy the salads, crab cake appetizer and vegetable stuffed baked potato. The meal portions are just short of huge.  Every time I eat there I promise myself one of their yummy and huge desserts. Today, as always, I'm too full after my main course and can't even look at the dessert menu.  A few times I've gone there with friends just for dessert and have never been disappointed.  I do have one small complaint.  For some reason I've never been able to figure out the wait person almost always chooses to ask me how my meal is when my mouth is full and I can only nod my appreciation.  It's a small price to pay for an otherwise pleasurable dining experience.  I highly recommend Max's.
author: Sandra S.

description: If I were a swinging member of the geriatric crowd- aspiring to hold the record for morbid obesity- with a handsome (expendable) lump of cash from the craps table in Reno (not Vegas) and owned a wardrobe exclusively from Talbots, Casual Corner and Just My Size (JMS), then, perhaps, I would consider visiting Max's a second time.
author: Christine M.

description: By far, my favorite Max's -- home of gi-normous portions, comfort food as far as the eye can see, and desserts that give me 'the diabetes' just by looking at them. What sets this one apart is the atmosphere, as you see a lot of pre-symphony/operetta goers, so it just feels more elegant. And I don't know about you, but I get a thrill when someone is delivering my food one minute and then bringing down the house with a rousing rendition of "I Like New York In June" the next, given most of the servers are aspiring singers who work there in order to take turns showcasing their talented windpipes.
author: Gregor G.

description: I work in the City and this is my favorite place for both sit down luncheon and take outs. Daily special is my favorite.  Service is quite efficient especially during lunchtime. The quality of their food is good and the price is reasonable. Always ask for a doggy bag to take the extra food home.
author: Kenneth W.

description:
We haven't been back for some months due to my travels and the fact that when WE go here, someone eats a lot of hamburgers (not me). Not much has changed but for the added brunch...  at noon on a Sunday I was surprised 1) we found a parking space and 2) there was NO long line to get a table. The cute hostess wanted to seat me at a spot where I've previously been seated, and I asked for a booth as I didn't want each and every passing waitress/er bumping into the back of my chair. She understood right off and sat us by the big windows in a very roomy booth. It was about four minutes before we were waited on, and we ordered drinks and our brunch items...  I settle for a Vegetarian Spinach Fritta which came with country fries, and I added a chicken sausage which was one fat sausage cut in half and fried...  and was very meaty and big. It's a great helping sure to stuff you for a whole day....  for less than $16. The fritta looked almost like a messy spanish tortilla with big pieces of spinach, onions, zuchinni and even peas - hahahahahaa  - and I commented on that. Of course, a spanish tortilla is much better and very clean...  ;-)  This actually looked like a scrambled egg with veggies...

I was disappointed when a family of three sat behind us and were waiting over 10minutes before our waiter noticed they were still not served anything. He stated a crew turnover had them sitting without service but he would be happy to take their order. We soon left and I estimate they had been sitting 20mins with a very active and hungry child....  I remarked to them that if it were me sitting there so long, I would have departed long ago with a few choice but courteous words to the shift manager. 

In our not-recent last visits to this establishment, I have noticed that the waiters/resses seem preoccupied and would forget order items, refilling drinks, etc. This shouldn't be the experience one has at such a fine place as this but unfortunately, it seems to be happening more often now, as was a point in case the family waiting so long to order and to be served. It doesn't take but a minute to check on your clients and I know in a busy hectic environment such as a restaurant, things change from minute to minute. OH, don't try going to their website as the links don't work either...  as of right now!!
author: Tony L.

description: All I can say is HORRIBLE!!! My husband n I ate here yesterday and I'm just  very very annoyed with the horrible customer service we received after they made a HUGE mistake on our check! 15 min after leaving we decided to check his account and noticed they took out the amount of our check plus another large charge! We called them to discuss the charges n barely got an apology and basically just said nothing they can do about it! We ended up going back there and talked to a manager n he apologized and told us nothing he can do about it but wait! How about I'm sorry for the inconvince how about we understand you are going out I'd town and would like to offer you something for the error??? NOTHING! Didn't offer a dam thing! I worked in customer service and have been a manager as well and I can tell you that if our business made a huge mistake like they did I would be apologizing and offer something to the customer for us screwing up like that! We've been going to maxs for a good 9 yrs now and got some shitty service before but this takes the cake! Thanks a lot for nothing!!!!
author: Naomi K.

description: My friend and i went here before a show at the Grandballroomatoriumaria for a small quick bite. Ill repeat that. A small. Quick. Bite. For one, nothing on the menu feeds less than 23 people. The portions are ginormous. Mid-Westerners named Steve Zerbsky, listen up...this is the place you bring your wife Linda on you vacation away from Downer's Grove, Illinois. I order some nachos, and got a festive mutlicolored volcano that took two waiters to EZ Lift over. My friend got a salmon burger that was so big, youd think they lopped the head and tail off and slapped it on a loaf of Franch (not French, it is pronounced Fronche) bread. Oh, and like 2.64 pounds of potatoes were harmed in the making of the fries. I will return to conquer the 'chos. I will return to hear our server croon, and i will return to see what the hell that Reuben is all about.
author: Mick F.

description: I recommend the broiled salmon, easily some of the best salmon I have ever tasted, perfectly tender and savorily seasoned. Everything is moderately priced so not a bad place to get a delicious meal for a decent cost. The smooth sound of the piano along with the occasional operatic vocals provided by Max's own waiters and waitresses created a lovely ambience for the evening. This place was great for a birthday celebration with a large group of friends.
author: Jason P.

description: Blech.   I had a friend who worked here and that place is scary.  The portions are plentiful and the hot fudge flows, but overall an unpleasant atmosphere and poor service make visits to Max's few and far between.
author: Rose Q.

description:
We ate here last Saturday.  Our previous meals here have been good quality and decent sized portions, but things seem to have changed in the 6+ months since our last visit.

Our server couldn't seem to get our order right and we had to send a couple of things back for a second try.  And what was delivered was pretty substandard.  

Used to be they had a pretty good meatloaf - moist, and a nice sized portion with mashed potatoes and gravy.  But what came to the table was about the size of the meat on a small fast food burger, and pretty well dried out on top of it, with no gravy for the mashed potatoes or meatloaf. 

We sat near the hostess' stand and asked "what happened to Max's famous meatloaf?".  The host said "We changed that item and I like this a lot better".  No attempt at "I'll send your server over" or "I'll get you a new dish" or anything to acknowledge there was a problem.

The mushroom fettuccine was a letdown also - a small portion and bland.

The good news is I can remove Max's from the list of potential restaurants for a casual night out.  

The sweet potato fries were good, and the portion was a nice size for two people, but that was the high point of the meal.  The rest of our dinner was overpriced and awful, and the service was miserable.

Skip Max's!
author: Dennis D.

description:
This review breaks my heart.  Max's is such awesome food and the piano bar is such a great idea.  I've made it my life's mission to find the perfect Rueben Sandwich and Max's is the closest I've come.  But let's be honest here:  The evening service sucks.  

There is a long tradition of show biz people working in restaurants.  Singing wait staff is not difficult to find in San Francisco.  That said, these people are performers and could at least 'act' like they want to help you.  I tip 20%+ for exceptional service, 15% for standard.  We've only stiffed one person in the past ten years, and that was Max's waitress.  She was horrible.  She told us she would be back with our drinks and a busboy delivered water.  Fifteen minutes later a busboy came and took our order.  Okay...I've waited tables before...maybe she's on break?  Maybe they could tell us?  The place was busy, but it certainly wasn't slammed.   Then yet another busboy brought us our food.  She wandered back and forth past our table, yet didn't acknowledge us during the entire meal.  Never came up and asked us how we were doing and I had to track down a mustard caddy for my sandwich.  Finally she approached with our check while the dirty dishes congealed on the table, gave us a cursory nod, and wandered off.  That was it.  On a fifty dollar bill, she should have received a minimum of a $7.50 tip.  She got nothing.  She was there the second the money was in the billfold and stood there as we exited shooting daggers from her eyes.  I met her stare and I must say I was extremely angry with her.  If I'm paying $20 for a sandwich and a soft drink, I expect service.

This was not an isolated incident, merely the most severe one.  I've had some occasions where I've had the one seemingly good wait person in the evening and she was an absolute delight.  The lunch staff is a little more enthusiastic than the evening staff, and the evening staff is, by and large, under the impression that we need them more than they need us.

All of this aside, Max's food is typically very good.  I just don't recommend this particular location for the evening crowd.
author: Pikea M.

description:
This seems like such a let down after having gone to a performance.  But I had uncomfortable shoes on and we were starving after a three hour long opera. 
The portions are truly Midwestern.  Everything was very fatty, it seemed just for the sake of being fatty and not to enhance the taste.  My beet salad was drenched with a thick dressing and had the biggest lumps of feta cheese I have even seen.  Tasted ok, but could have been so much better if they had tossed it in a nice light vinaigrette.  I had to bring about 2/3 of the thing home it was so big.
I had a bite (a big bite) of the bacon cheese burger too.  The Bacon was very weird, it was hard and crunchy, reminded me of dog treats.
And I would like to see the potatoes that the fries were cut from...those fuckers must be the size of pumpkins!  Do they use GM potatoes?  How big do potatoes get?  I think there was a French fry that was about the length of my arm!
The prices are average, maybe a bit high but then you get a bucket, no a trough, of food with each order, so if you are a tourist from middle America, or just a local glutton, this is the place for you!
author: Nilu r.

description: Ate here while in the city for work.  Had a rueben.  Tons of food so that helps to justify the price (but, hey, it's SF).  Our waiter was very nice and attentive (we had a group of 5).  Only real complaint was that we were in early while it wasn't too busy but it still took us over 1 hour to order, eat and pay the bill.
author: Shannon L.

description:
I'm not happy with the health insurance service charge.

For whatever historical reasons, waiters count on tips as part of their income. Part of this is supposed to go towards their health insurance as many restaurants do not provide insurance. Thus, I would think that you deduct the service charge from what you were going to tip anyways. But our party hit the minimum size for automatic tip service charge.

Food was kind of blah... less than I remembered. The chicken pot pie was pretty decent, but other tshings -- such as their matzo ball soup -- not so good. With surcharge, the cost of the meal skyrockets. I will no longer dine at this establishment.
author: Andrew C.

description:
My wife and I drove with our seven year old daughter to have dinner at Max's.  We live closer to many other restaurants that we would have chosen except for the fact that we had a coupon for $10 off dinner. The coupon's only parameters were that we spend over $20, the meal be after 5:00pm and only one discount per table. The coupon specifically listed two Max's locations which would honor the discount (one of which was this Van Ness location), and there was no expiration date.

You guessed it. We ate dinner (not cheap at nearly $90.00  with one kid's meal and one shared dessert ) and they said they were not going to honor the coupon. I pointed out that it had their specific location listed and that there was no expiration date. The waitress simply said, "We're not part of that group anymore". I said, "are you sure this is how you want to treat your customers?" She said "You can use it somewhere else". This after not being able to find her for a single coffee refill. 

So Max, with all of your empty proclamations of "The customer is always right" etc on everything from napkins to banner boards hung on the wall, you would think that customer service would include honoring your own unexpired coupon, with your own address specified, and a photo of your own location's interior printed on its face. Sorry Max, you screwed up. You cost your waitress a tip, you cost yourselves goodwill, and irritated customers in the process.

I guess the economy hasn't hit your restaurant to the point that you care about chasing away customers.

These fast slipping Yelp reviews actually make a difference to many of us....be careful or your customers will all go away.
author: T A.

description: Van Ness Street with all the Opera, Symphony and Ballet Crowd. I don't love the drafty areas but it adds a bit of authenticity to the idea of a deli in New York. The singers range from bad to horrible, it's wonderfully tacky. It's a fun place to come for a huge dessert while out partying it up in the big city. But what I don't understand is why they didn't hire Amanda Lamb, one of the best singers. Or me, for example.
author: fuck you p.

description:
these people are racists!!!

i know that's a serious allegation to make, but i was just as shocked that in this day and age, especially in SF no less, this would happen.

it was pretty late at night and max's was close by.  BF and i walked up to the door at the same time as this other couple.  i won't elaborate, but they were the typical max's customers (you get the idea.  but it's NOT that we looked like vagrants or had boorish manners.)  BF opened the door for them, so they were a few paces ahead of us.

the hostess seated them.  then when she came back, she told us they were closed.  i started to sputter and say how come those people who pretty much arrived at the same time as us got seated?  she spat as us 'well, the kitchen has to close some time you know.'

rather than make a scene, we went to chevy's instead, where I spent the night fuming and envisioning bricks hurled through their window.  and then flames coming out.

to this day, that was one of my biggest regrets in life, behaving like a model minority.  if i could go back in time i would've hit them with a fat lawsuit for discrimination.  or at the very least make an ugly scene.

then, this other time way back (before that incident obviously), i went to max's for my birthday.  had a huge group with me.  i don't know if it was because once again, we didn't look like the typical max's customers, but the waitress served us almost grudgingly.  i wondered, did she think we were going to be stingy asian college student tippers?  but then again, how could she possibly expect a good tip with that shoddy a service? 

so yes, this place SUCKS.  even if they should happen to have the finest food in the universe, they still SUCK.
author: Miss K.

description: This is a great place to pick up a hearty meal or even just dessert and coffee/tea before or after a movie, concert, or opera in the SF civic center area. I give this restaurant 5 stars just on location alone :) The view of city hall at night is reason enough to come, honestly. The staff is awesome, friendly, and attentive. I came here with my sister before a Rigoletto showing just down the block at the SF Opera House--- it's like our thing.... Anway, try the pastrami reuben (Also in peppered turkey for the health conscious). The  matzo ball soup is very comforting on a cold night too. Come hungry because these portions are pretty ginormous. Also... the desserts can be shared among 3 and I like the bread pudding as well as anything chocolate! Come around 5:30 to beat the rush... otherwise wait in line and listen to to live jazz piano or people watch.
author: Patricia M.

description: 5 Stars for their catering!  I hired them to cater my wedding, and everything was perfect!
author: Camille B.

description: The maxarita is my favorite...i usually get the not so mini rueben and the matza ball soup.
author: Nancy F.

description: I come here for the sweet potato fries. the dipping sauce is so good!!!!! Thats basically all I order. The menu is somewhat limited and can't really order togo unless you get a salad. I liked the sweet chili chicken wings but they took it off the menu. sad. service was okay (not super friendly but not rude either...just neutral). probably didn't like us cause we didn't order much which in hospitality terms means less tips.
author: Josephine S.

description: The portions are huge especially sandwiches.  I ordered 2 appetizers: chicken wings and stuffed baked giant mushrooms.  Chicken wings are spicy and tasty, yet a bit too salty for my taste.  Mushrooms are smaller than I thought.   The focaccia bread that comes with the mushroom are just bland even with the tomato sauce.   My friends had sandwiches, and the portions were GIGANTINO.  The salmon dish was quite small and a bit dry.
author: Jessica N.

description: Great standby for huuuuuuge portions of food, just like having your grandmother serving you, eat... eat... eat!! Macaroons are incredible. Max's has always been about quality. I like the remodel of this location and will continue to be a fan.
author: Bubba R.

description: Sunday Brunch at Max's is a noisy affair, but you can tolerate that if they still have Brunch...not so, even if you arrive within the stated hours it might be all gone, as was my experience with simple scrambled eggs!
author: Corinne d.

description: After finding out that they serve brunch, my friends and I decided to eat here on a sunday. They actually accepted a reservation which was good. 2 of us order Joe's special which was an omelet with ground beef, onion, spinach and cheese. When the food arrived, both of our meats were not cooked. I lost my appetite. The waitress couldn't care less and after asking for the menu, we ordered french toast. You can't go wrong with french toast. Well, they went wrong with ham that came with the french toast. We were very disappointed with the food and service. Our coffee was never refilled. When we asked for butter and jam, they brought butter but not jam. We finally gave up asking. I won't go here again to eat any meal. Don't waste your money or time.
author: Julie K.

description:
this was my first time at this place, so i won't completely rule it out, since i hear it's so good.  my burger was pretty dry (after i ordered it med-rare) and the onion ring things were not so good.  next time i try the rueben.  

next time i'll try to eat more than maria as well.  she cleaned her plate.
author: Hammer Time H.

description: Turkey Burger with Fries for $13?    Maybe a little bigger than normal, but if you want size get some triple  thing at Burger King down the block. Nice warm bread basket while you're waiting for the food.   Service is iffy, but always friendly.
author: Dennis N.

description: the food was sub par for san francisco.  had a Caesar salad, and steak, med rare.  salad was fine.  steak was rare-raw, no flavor to it... first time I have asked for steak sauce at a restaurant in my adult life.  the dinner rolls were more like breakfast rolls, too sweet with a touch of cinnamon.
author: Someguythatlikestoeat n.

description: Around the area? just came from the opera house venue? then you have to grab yourself a Max's ruben cause its straight MMMMMMMM!!! i used to live in right next to the opera building like literally 30 second walk from my building and i get here and i would always catch myself grabbing a ruben before i head out early somewhere. Its also great if your on the go a but alsoa  bit pricey due to the fact of SF taxes especially on a startving student budget. Although , its a great find i would always recommend going here instead of that Mcdonalds across the street from it!
author: Aj A.

description: I have not eaten in, I have only had their cakes and eclair's. They are to die for!!! Huge and delicious!!
author: Jess P.

description: Split a Reuben four ways, and maybe you won't feel like you committed the sin of gluttony eating here.  They used to do half a BLT and a cup of soup (matzo ball of course), but for some reason, that's not an option anymore.  That was my choice, and I could maintain some sense of virtue about the whole experience.  And even enjoy it.  How often does one get a good BLT these days?  Never.  Now, the food just seems monstrously excessive, and fine, but not great.  Add to that the vaguely chain experience, and it's really not on my list, except when I come with the occasional group lunch.  I'd rather go to Morty's any day (or night).
author: Laurel B.

description:
Came with a large group of people before Yom Kippur services, 5:30 on a Sunday. Conveniently close to Sha'ar Zahav's services nearby.

HUGE portions. Semi pricey. Dressy casual attire is good-they have white tablecloths.

-Soup: The cup=small bowl, Bowl=large bowl. You get 1 matzoh ball in the cup, 2 in the huge bowl. I traded my bowl for cup.

Matzoh ball soup- so-so. The ball was heavy and the broth was sludgey, not clear like NYC's 2nd Ave Deli.

-Salad: The salad with pear, cranberries and walnuts is excellent. My friend got the dressing on the side.

-Friend's brisket came out cold- she asked them to microwave it.

-HUGE beverages: maybe 20 oz?

-Raisin rolls were better than the regular rolls

You can have a decent conversation in the back area bordering the street- if you are near the piano it might get loud. The music was pretty good, but I want to hear conversation, not overpowering music.

Entrees took a long time to come, even though our group ordered before the big dinner rush around 6, 6:30.

Parking took a while to find, even on a Sunday eve.
author: KD D.

description: Huge, humongous, gigantic sandwiches and tasty too. I usually order food to go since it is busy for lunch or dinner. The tomato tortellini and the Mexican vegetable soups are delicious. Service is lacking at times but the food makes up for it.
author: Teddy d.

description: After reading a few reviews, I can say I was totally disappointed by Max's. Perhaps I should have ordered a sandwich or the matzo ball soup, but ol' Christine is trying to loose a few lb's, so I went with the roasted beet salad. I LOVE beets, but this was pretty bad. The dressing had little to no flavor, the beets were over roasted, and avocado looked brownish. The restaurant space itself is in bad need of a makeover...service was decent though. Just goes to prove that finding a decent spot for lunch in Civic Center is next to impossible.
author: Brianne K.

description: don't come here to have good service or good meals, just get some dessert and go!!!!!     Their chocolate chip cheesecake is the best! try it and you'll become addicted. I apologize in advance for ruining your diet.
author: kim l.

description: Whoa.  My company ordered take out from them and it was stunningly horrible.  Pretty much on par with what you might feed, say zombies or the very, very old.  It's been a while, but I even think that my ghetto public school lunches had to be better than the tins of tasteless bland food that got delivered.  Really guys, is this all you have?  A few shakes of Lawrey's seasoning salt may have even landed you a second star, but you couldn't even be bothered to go that far.  Next time someone suggests food from this place, do yourself a favor and take a sack of white flour, mix it with the liquid that canned string beans come in and eat that instead.  It'll be better.
author: Mark S.

description: I took my mon here over the weekend...and as expected everything was average...I had the corned beef...average.... decent portion but the rye bread was a little on the stale side...my mom had the soup and salad...how hard is this to mess up...they didn't... go here if you enjoy a lot of options on the menu... food and service thats just ok then this is your place
author: Jim P.

description: My boyfriend and I went on a rainy Monday night. He suggested I order the chinese chicken salad. It was good for the most part. I think the chicken was a bit dry and overly fried and there was too much ciilantro piled up on top of the salad. I guess cilantro is a cheap way of making a salad portion look bigger! The sweet potato fries are pretty good. All in all  Max's was ok. I will probably go back next time and try a dessert instead ( they looked incredible!)
author: elliemae r.

description: Great Reuben sandwich!  Good location for pre-ballet/opera/symphony dinner.
author: Todd D.

description:
Max's food is what I am calling the new Old Fashioned style food. It is not our food of the 50's which we call old style diner... it is a newer birth of what is now a bit old fashioned. It is still has it's merits but I see mainly older folks going there as it is a little higher priced and a bit more generic for this day and age. But back in the day.... It was very special...
See a video of the place @ http://sf-lunch.com/2008/03/26/maxs-diner-opera-plaza-the-new-old-fashioned/
author: SF Luncher z.

description: This place is a great environment to eat at. The waiters/waitresses often play live music, the food is tasty, and the selection of desserts is divine. However, the prices are a bit outrageous for what you get.  They have a tasty selection of Jewish delights as well which I enjoy, such as their Matzah Ball soup and their Blintzes.  Only complaint is the price, though, which keeps me from coming here too often. Sandwich + Drink + shared appetizer or side of soup will easily run you over $25 for lunch or so.
author: ben T.

description: Pretty impressive. All waitstaffs know how to sing. The food is typical american cuisine. Whenever I come to Max's, i can only order 1 item because the food portions are so huge.They serve king size sandwiches, gigantic salads, hot comfort food, and homogous desserts. They are definately not measly with the food. I had the double chicken marsala. It was delicious. Service is pretty good too.
author: Michael K.

description: The food isn't the best but the serving sizes are huge! The shrimp quesadillas are good and their desserts are impressive in terms of size and presentation but they are just mediocre tasting. All in all it's a decent place to dine at here and there. It's definitely not a place to go to if you want a real gourmet dining experience.
author: Diane M.

description: I was super impressed. We were... well... kinda behind schedule, and needed to eat before we went to the Nutcracker (which was AMAZING, btw). So, in a super duper rush, we hurry into a much busier Max's than we've ever been to, where my grandparents had already talked to the host. He promised to get us out before our show (which was seriously like 45 minutes away), and BOOM... we were out, bellies happily full, with lots of time to spare. But it may have helped that we go to a Max's whenever we need to see my grandparents, so we already knew what we wanted... the service was still AWESOME. Oh, and the live music was a wicked plus, too. THANK YOU MAX'S AT THE OPERA FOR GETTING US TO OUR SHOW ON TIME!!!!!!!
author: Tavi H.

description:
Damn, what a depressing place.  Like a lot of the other reviews for this joint, I have to agree - why on Earth would one require servings so freaking huge?  Isn't the populace of our country fat enough as it is?  And talk about mediocrity ... a friend of mine called me once whilst I was sitting at the sad, forlorn bar with drunks, ex-junkies, and sad sacks, and said to me, "That restaurant doesn't deserve you."  I can't speak for myself as to that claim, but I do have this to say:  Max's Opera Cafe is about as exciting and vibrant as a funeral home with a torch song soundtrack.  Some voices (the wait staff sing at night alongside a pianist) are worth listening to, but other times it can be downright painful.  Does anybody really need to listen to Frank Sinatra being transformed into a drag revue camp hit whilst eating?  The drinks are expensive, too.  But well made, I hastily add.  You need a stiff drink to dine in this diner/mausoleum.  If you must, order the turkey sliders - they're pretty damn good, if you can stomach the caterwauling.

Also, the letters to the owner posted next to the bathrooms are pretty funny to read.  Dennis (the owner, I think) makes comments on the letters expressing his point of view, and some of them are priceless.
author: Thomas B.

description:
it's your average american fare kinda restaurant.
went for lunch one time... can't remember if it was before or after a movie right there at the opera plaza...
had a sandwich.  it was good... service was alright... nothing special about the place... decent if you're just wanting something to eat
author: charlotte s.

description: Max's serves mediocre food for high prices.  Come on, $12 for a sandwich?  Salads and entrees are nothing special, sometimes pretty bad.  Considering that you can wait a really long time to get seated, I'm convinced that people only come here because the menu has a wide variety.  That said, you could do worse.
author: Joseph N.

description: This is the most overrated place ever.  I used to live in Opera Plaza, so I'd go to Max's and keep thinking, "Well, maybe last time was just a fluke..."  but no, consistently mediocre-to-bad service, mediocre food for the price, etc.  Now that I don't live there, I would never consider going out of my way to eat there.
author: Kim M.

description: Came here with a group of people and made reservations ahead of time. The service was very inattentive and rude. Possibly it was because we are young people. But they shouldn't look down upon us. We came here for dinner before prom and it was just not worth it. The food was not delicious and actually was quite disgusting. I don't think I will try this place again.
author: Rebecca T.

description: Max used to be one of my favorite chain restaurant but they have been mostly hit or miss in the last couple of year.  If I have to eat at a chain restaurant I would definitely go to the Elephant Bar instead.
author: L C.

description: The best time to go is after 8pm on theatre/symphony nights - otherwise, the place is pretty crowded and they don't take reservations.  I go primarily for the desserts, which are amazing.... love the giant eclair - it's bigger than a baby's arm!!
author: sylvia c.

description: I agree with the guy who said that the food was good but ultimately not worth the price. the singing was pretty cool and my friends and i applauded our waiter. but the dining experience left a bit to be desired.
author: Billy S.

description: The Ceasar Sald that we ordered to go was large and reasonably good, but the service was horrible.  the young lad who took my order was barely able to speak english and after waiting a very long time, he got the order wrong.  on top of that, the restaurant charges a 5.4% employment  benefit fee on top on the regular tax and gratuity.  many San Francisco restaurants are doing this and in the future, I refuse to pay this fee and will avoid all restaurants that expect their customers to pay for employee benefits.
author: Jim A.

description: Meant to rate the Max's near Geary.. Ignore this post...
author: Kram K.

description:
I came in looking for a good meal before going to a rehearsal. I arrived before the dinner rush and came in through the side door. I was immediately seated and before I could fully pull my chair in a glass of water appeared at my table with some warm rolls and butter appearing shortly afterward.

I ordered the New York Strip steak, medium rare with a salad, baked potato, creamed spinach, and iced tea to drink. The tea comes hot - they bring you two glasses with ice and a small metal pot of hot water with two tea bags steeping in it. Now that's the way to make sure the iced tea is fresh and not sour.  The steak was a bit more towards medium than rare with too much of the spice mix sprinkled on it (very salty), but it was tasty, and not dry. The good-sized salt-roasted potato came with plenty of butter and sour cream. The creamed spinach was also good - made with fresh spinach but alas a bit too rich for me. I couldn't finish it. The presentation of the food matched the decor, which was old-style but refined. Similar to what you might find in a higher end restaurant, but with some homey touches.

I felt the service was above average as my server did check in on me from time to time with a good balance of leaving me alone, but noticing when things on the table needed a reset. All in all I enjoyed the experience and even though I was dining alone I wasn't rushed like what happens in some restaurants with single diners.

The price range is moderate to spendy. You can get simple fare and probably eat for $15-$20 per person, but there are more expensive options on the menu and it wouldn't be hard to run it up if you're also having drinks with your meal.
author: Blair B.

description:
it all depends on what you expect from MAx's. It will always be one of my all-time fall back restaurants. The food is not the best, but I absolutely love the atmosphere and the environment. (mind you, I only come at night or late night) I love that they have Opera students working there where they sing live Opera in between shifts.

I love their selection of desserts. Every time my cousin and his wife come up from Irvine, we always take the family to Max's for dessert. 

Again, don't come here expecting amazingly great food. Come here for the experience. (& I can only say for the night time/ late night times)

I've had my friend's have their birthday dinners here and I come here when I meet up old friends. Stick with the basics here. They are delic.
author: nightlife i.

description: This restaurant does not care about its customers; Beware the Caesar Salad!!!! they put olives in it (why?), and they are meant to be pitted, only one of them still had a piece of pit in it that broke my back tooth, and I had to spend over $1000 on having a crown fitted. Now, after 6 weeks of chasing down them and their insurers, they are denying any liability and passing me off to the olive manufacturers. Pretty shoddy treatment I think- not even an offer to refund the cost of my lunch- which was $53 - all in all a very expensive lunch, and terrible customer care- they obviously don't care about their reputation either.
author: Vanda M.

description: HUGE. i like any place where the waiters will sing gershwin. the latkes were good. the matzo ball soup was ok. only 1 guy at our table (we had about 15 people) finished. it's a bit too much, especially as my friend had an entire slab of blue cheese on her salad - that's unneccesary and hard to eat.
author: Lijia X.

description: I love music and I love food.  Put them together and you've got Max's Opera Cafe.  Very large selection of food on their menu.  I love their nachos!  Great desserts.  They have huge chocolate covered macaroons which are yummy with a side of ice cream.   Great place for lunch or dinner, except they don't sing at lunch time.  Always dependable for a good meal.  Not very expensive either.
author: Vanessa Z.

description: Big portions and decent pricing, especially since they are a restaurant inside the Opera Plaza and so near the Superior Court/City Hall.  They can overcharge you, but they don't.  Burgers here are of course decent.  Don't order the fries b/c it's not that good, unless you are desperate.  The crab cakes are pretty good due to the tartar sauce that comes with it.  I can dip anything into that sauce.  Their philly cheese steak is good too b/c they do not go cheap on the cheese.  Patty melt.. hm... tons of grease, just like how it's meant to be.  Their salads aren't that great though.  $6 for a ceasars and the romaine lettuce aren't that crispy, and their caesars dressing are only mediocre.
author: AhLin C.

description: We came here for a dessert after a sushi dinner. A word of advice, their desserts are huge much like everything else on the menu. My boyfriend and I split the hot fudge sundae and there was easily enough for four people. The menu here is vast and the service is rather interesting. The waiters and waitresses will take a break from serving you to break into song which is cool if you're into that sort of thing...on some nights I like my ice cream with a side of showtunes and on some nights I prefer my ice cream without.
author: Cathy T.

description: Ginormous menu.  Seriously it takes me about 15 min. to even narrow down what I am going to get here.  Am always happy with whatever I end up going with.  I love their Rye Bread and they have a good selection of soups and sandwiches too.
author: Katie P.

description: Nice place for desserts!  No other food stuck with me from any of my last visits.. and I could really do without the waiters and waitresses singing... have any of them ever made it big because most of them really suck... someone needs to tell them.
author: K M.

description: This place has whatever you could possibly want to eat.  The portions are more than generous and the quality is outstanding.  Sometimes I order dessert for dinner.  It's also great that the waitstaff sings to entertain you!!  What fun!
author: Stephanie M.

description: The singing can be a bit . . .twee, but the potato pancakes are fantastic.  I echo everyone elses' comments about the portions large enough for a family of four. Frequently crowded, so go early or late.
author: Jude F.

description: Long before I moved here my family would visit SF for Christmas shopping around the holidays.  Because the location was conveniently close to Union Square, and because my sisters and I loved the "Laws", we would always come to Max's to eat.  I haven't been recently, but from what I remember the food was good and the atmosphere was fun.
author: Katie S.

description: HUGE portions, SERIOUSLY!!! Food's pretty good though, nothing GREAT yet descent, full bar which definitely helps! One Thurs night was a nice surprise though. Was walking home with a friend after a show and we wanted a drink yet wanted it low key, walking by we decided hat the hell! So in we walked in and there was a pianist along with a vocalist, and it was a good time!!!
author: Rob L.

description: This place totally does it for me. Gigantorous portions (I'm still working on a strawberry shortcake I ordered 2 years ago) and they wait folk actually sing at this location though not enough new wave or hair metal for my tastes. I always go here when I'm seeing a flick at Opera Plaza or the symphony or a reading at a Clean Well Lighted place but it's worth a special trip.
author: Colin S.

description: Max is seriously out of control! Whoever he is, he could learn a thing or two about portion size. Jews don't really eat like that, do they? Things could be a little cheaper and smaller and I'd be fine with that. The food is pretty decent though. Best thing is that Max's Opera Plaza has a full bar and is near the cinema. You can often see blue haired opera/ballet/symphony ladies tossing back Manhattans.
author: Colleen B.

description: Split the Beet Salad and Crab Cake Sandwich, which was a delightful combo. Crab Cake Sandwich bun over powered the cake with all its carbohydrate. Pink lemonade is served in tall double pint glass which I found very nice and in comparison to my companion's tiny coffee - was a jolly pink giant lemonade! Will stop in to grab a chocolate covered macaroon next time I'm about the square. I recommend you do the same!
author: Jenny T.

description: Great place but come if you're hungry! They serve big portions! You'll enjoy the food and have a great time!
author: Mel P.

description: *Cue Fiddler on the Roof music* Traditioooooon!  That's what I think of when I hear Max's.  My family and I go here after every opera, every symphony, and every ballet (or before if it's too late).  Their menu is created in the finest traditions of Jewish delicatessens the world over, but with plenty of other cuisines and choices so as to keep everyone happy.  I can't think of anything better than a bowl of their to-die-for matzoh ball soup and a reuben, along with a Dr. Brown's cream soda or cel-ray tonic.  The Van Ness location still features singing employees on certain nights, which is always entertaining.  I love this place, and you will too.
author: Cameron Y.

description: I go to Max's cause it totally fills that void that San Francisco lacks. For my LA transplants its like Jerry's Deli, have great chop liver, sandwich's are good, and great french fries. Love to bar!! always meet some crazy fun people there!! Depending on the day and time crowds are always fun for people watching!! Love there take out! and when a good crew is working the singing is nice to have in the background!!
author: Danny B.

description: interesting place - waitresses are also good singers, and they will sing to some broadway tunes during their shift....food wise - it's okay  I had better. If you are in diet, not the best place to be. They have BIG tasty desserts :)
author: ji k.

description: This place is good if you are going to go listen to a concert at Davies right after. The good food and lovely restaurant staff give off good vibes. I split a Reuben sandwich with my cousin and it was out of this world.
author: Jason C. J.

description:
everyone that works in the area goes here.  you have to get there about 15 minutes before noon if you want to get a decent seat.  service was good, the sandwich i got was huge, but it was pricey.  you gotta try the reuben & the corned beef sandwhich...lots of meat!

 i love the different types of bread they serve while you're waiting for your food.  they're open for breakfast and people flock to max's in the morning because you can smell the bacon a block away
author: Ray R.

description: Max's is a little pricey for what is essentially a diner experience. The singing is nice, and my Manhattan was actually pretty good, as was the food. But the $ for it was a little ridiculous. I didn't even have to pay, as it was a going away party, but honestly I felt guilty seeing how much everyone else had to pay. The food was a bit greasy, the service was pretty good, I'm just not sure the price was worth what you got.
author: Darcy V.

description:
*sigh* it wasn't horrible, just that...

well, if I hadn't had Reubens recently at Lunch Geek (sadly only an occasional kitchen experiment), Saul's, and The Kitchen Table (okay that last is technically not a Reuben as that is a non-dairy restaurant, but still)

max's takes it for size, and the dressing and bread were good, as was the side of cole slaw, but the corned beef was mediocre

I debated whether to make this a two or three star review, but ultimately I have to give it a two as the meat is the main point of a Reuben

and now that I know what good corned beef tastes like (from the three other places), I can't go back
author: Charles B.

description: Wow...talk about H U G E portions.  Their food was alright but the dessert was my favorite.  My boyfriend and I shared the banana split which looked like it was made for at least 5 people...but so yummy...wish I would have ate a little less dinner because we couldn't finish the dessert!  The singing waiters is also a plus...a little entertainment while you eat...although when we went our waiter seemed more occupied with his singing session than bringing us our food.
author: Jaki B.

description: Good portions, food tastes as it should.  Solid, no frills thrills.  --No idea what the inside of the restaurant is like, however- good luck.
author: yvette l.

description: If you want comfort food this is the place for you!  Have the whole bowl of matzo ball soup.  Their wings are good too...who cares that it's a geriatric crowd their portions are big and the price is right.  Reminds me of a good 'ole Jewish deli growing up in Jersey.
author: Tiberius A.

description:
my wife & i love the food at max's opera cafe.  the waitstaff is decent & pretty attentive to your needs.  the restaurant is clean, it is laid out pretty well & fairly comfortable.  there is live music & the singing is fairly entertaining.

we typically start our meal off with the bbq pork piezzle.  my wife used to order the firecracker shrimp but since they have taken it off the menu she now orders the penne pasta.  i typically will only order the new york steak rare.  the food is pretty decent at max's & we are never surprised how our food comes out from the kitchen.  by the time we are finished with our dinner we typically will not have room for desert. 

if you are a steak or beef lover i recommend getting the new york steak only.  i have tried the angus rib eye steak here & its not to my liking, its tender but pretty fatty which is not a good thing in this case.  the new york steak is just as tender, thick & juicy, with alot of flavor without the high amount of fat.  

overall, it's a great restaurant to get some pretty good food.  its convenient to eat there before or after going to the sf opera house, sf symphony or sf ballet as they are all within walking distance.  they open fairly late so post event coffee & desert are a must.  the prices are not too bad & are fairly reasonable.  the street parking is hit or miss but there are plenty of parking lots within walking distance.
author: larry s.

description: This place has always been reliable for pretty quality food at decent prices.  Try their salmon with crab on top, it is pretty darn good.  Their salads are also a great option for either lunch or dinner.  Its no surprise its a great place for food before or after a theater.
author: Charles C.

description: I go here mainly for the Matzo Ball soup and iced tea. Portions are way too big. I really wish they would make the portions a little smaller and reduce the price point a little. Safe place to take guests from the Midwest.
author: Deno M.

description:
this is my hands down favorite restaurant on the planet. i've loved this place since my parents first took me here when i was 8. it's always been a treat for me, a place i go for a celebration or a date. something special. grandma's honey mustard chicken is probably my favorite dish, but the steaks are great too, the rueben is excellent, the loaded potatoes rule, the latkes, the desserts....everything is good. i especially love the macaroon sundae for dessert. i usually have a hard time ordering because everything on the menu is so good.

all that said recently max's has gone a bit downhill. my last few meals there weren't quite up to par. but that's the way max's has always seemed to go for me...a few years of being great, then a slump, followed by more good years, then a slump, etc. but i'll always end up loving max's and it's so nostalgic for me and part of my growing up that i can't not give it a 5.
author: Dan C.

description: This place has the air of an institution. And while that lends historical context, and a monster of a menu, the word "dated" readily applies. Noone will debate that food quantity is American-style "copious". Nor  mince words that a live piano, multiple lo-slung chandeliers and a lounge singer who doubles as intermittent server doesn't equal a unique offering. But other than rushing to a movie at nearby Opera cinema, as we were, I can't foresee future moment where pressin' need to return is likely. Then again, such urgency may remain the realm of Christopher Elbow chocolate and anywhere serving Toro sashimi and a fine sake. So if you go, make up your own fantastical stories 'bout regulars at the bar and the 80 yr old couple in the corner (what a lotta life they've surely lived..) and expect stomach to leave full & brain to wander quickly to where next feast on more inspired deliciousness may occur.
author: Rachel S.

description: You had a bad day, lost your best friend, your cat died.  This is the place for you!  Have a bowl of matzo ball soup, some rye bread and butter, crispy iceberg lettuce salad, petrale sole, and a chocolate eclair.  Use Waiters on Wheels to deliver to your cave or park in the underground and pick up.  It's enough for two meals.
author: Catherine A.

description: Let me first say my food was incredible. My girlfriend, however, was displeased to find a pool of liquified butter at the bottom of her pasta bowl. The service was incredibly efficient. We were seated immeadiately, waited upon very shortly thereafter, and in almost fifteen minutes were served our entrees. I should mention that our waiter was completely unsure of himself. Max's has a series of rules on the back of their menus; our server broke three of them. We should have recieved free dessert. A table nearby us was rediculously noisy. I realize the staff can't stop them from coming in, but they should have the decency to ask them to be a bit quieter. All and all, I give them three stars for the food but nothing for service.
author: Daniel M.

description: Great service and decent food. I really enjoy their sandwhiches for lunch and pastas for dinner.
author: Veronica R.

description: The Service is great and the food is the closest thing in San Francisco you will find to a real Jewish deli experience.  I highly recommend the Ruben and getting a dessert.  A little pricey so I consider it a special occasion place.
author: M K.

description: Max's always leaves me feeling like I just ate at Chili's.
author: Sean M.

description:
hands down, best  BLTA  ever ......need I say more? 

great food, awesome and fast service, and good location. Even when you order it to go, you just feel good about getting food from Max's. I work in the civic center, and whenever I come back from lunch and my coworkers see the Max's checkered bag, I can sense their jealousy, and they are always asking if i want to share my left-overs. mmm. i am getting hungry just typing this...
